5:04 How does that help to show the left side electrons are not pushing the right side ones? Sure everything is at a stable 0, like in a flowing river any molecule is equally pushed by the right and left side molecules. But if the molecules from the upstream lake weren't literally pushing the downstream molecules to get to the downstream lake, there would be no current.  More precisely, if you were to suddenly cut the current to the left, the intensity of the current to the right of that barrier would immediately fall to 0 locally, only to be averaged later by water/electrons from downstream rushing to fill the sudden gap. Once the intensity of the current averaged throughout the river/cable after a few back and forths at the speed of sound-in-water/light, the intensity would steadily decrease until all the water/electrons are in the "downstream lake".  So I'm sorry but that image and message at 4:51 is as misleading as saying that if I were to push a box at a constant speed, I'm not actually "pushing", since the forces of my push are cancelled by the forces of the opposite push by the ground and air. It looks very much like this video was made by someone with an engineering background. It's the over-emphasis of electric and magnetic fields as though they are not part of the very particles (electrons and protons) that 'create' them. This emphasis causes confusion. Please skip to point (5) if you don't have the energy to read through it all.  (1) Your depiction of electrons moving randomly like a gas is inaccurate; electrons tend to avoid coming close to one another due to both electrical repulsion and quantum mechanical effects. A more appropriate model is the "almost free electron Fermi gas." The key issue, however, lies in the assumption that these rapidly-moving electrons can significantly exchange energy with the surrounding lattice ions. The notion that a non-conducting wire can contain electrons at an effective temperature of several thousand Kelvin, and that adding a small amount of energy through the addition of excess electrons would not lead to heating of the lattice structure, is not correct.  Only the energy levels very close to the Fermi energy contribute significantly to the thermal characteristics of a metal; those below, often referred to as the "Fermi sea," do not play a role in this context. At absolute zero, all electron energy states are filled up to the Fermi energy, which does indeed correspond to a temperature of several thousand Kelvin. This leads to an important conclusion: an electron under these conditions cannot collide with a lattice ion resulting in an increase of the ion's kinetic energy, because the electron must then lose energy. However, there are no available lower energy states to transition into because all of them are occupied. Consequently, the electron cannot exchange energy with the lattice ions under these conditions.  It is only when electrons begin to occupy states above the Fermi energy during thermal excitation, or when extra electrons are added, that some electrons occupy levels above the Fermi level and, as such, there are energy levels (or states) just below them which then can 'fall' into. The available states that are responsible for the energy exchanges are located very near the top of the energy structure, meaning that energy exchange between the ions and electrons is limited to a few energy increments just above and just below the Fermi energy. The extra energy the system gains by 'forcing' excess electrons onto the wire, which is partly manifested as a very slow drift velocity, DOES significantly influence their ability to exchange energy with the lattice ions. This point seems to me to be minimized and presented partly incorrectly in the video by showing the vast difference in the 'speed' associated with the Fermi energy and that extra speed associated with the drift velocity as though that minute extra speed is somehow  insignificant.  Furthermore, it is possible to equate the energy involved in the chemical reactions within batteries (which supply and accept electrons) to the energy dissipated in the circuit, as you are surely aware. This energy originates from the chemical reactions in the battery that either require electrons or result in electrons. When an electron is added to the circuit at one terminal of the battery it disturbs free electrons in the surroundings which cause them to adjust their positions. This disturbance propagates at nearly the speed of light. This push (the force or electrical disturbance) spreads in all directions, traversing the 1-meter gap as well as circulating around the circuit.  One then could ask, which direction facilitates the most efficient energy transfer to the electrons near or in the light bulb? It should be the path around the circuit if it has low enough electrical resistance. This principle is similar to the use of an iron core in a transformer or a dielectric material between capacitor plates, as propagating energy through space over long distances is less efficient than transmitting it through a medium with a high density of particles that respond to the applied force over short distances.  In simplified microscopic terms, one must compare the efficiency of energy transfer from a transmitter (an electron) to a receiver (another electron) with a very small area separated by a large distance, to that of energy transfer through multiple (non-amplifying) receivers arranged in a line, each separated by very small distances (all adhering to the inverse-square law). Typically, the former would be more efficient; however, since a metal wire contains an enormous number of free electrons, the effective area of each receiver along the wire is significantly large. This abundance of free electrons more than compensates for the inefficiencies associated with repeated transmission.  (2) Surface charges ARE electrons, or the lack thereof. So why not just say gradient of electron density along the surface? The reason that charges are on the surface is because EXCESS electrons supplied by the CHEMISTRY in the battery don't like to be near each other, they have nowhere to go, so excess electrons will be found on the surface, such that the potential energy of the system will be minimized. By the way, 1cm cubic block of isolated copper has about 1e23 free electrons, and you only need a few hundred thousand excess electrons to raise the voltage by 1V.  The battery does not magically make an electric field,  it just maintains a separation of electrons and ions - the chemical reactions in the battery would go until all chemical reactants are depleted,  but the force between the ions and electrons eventually becomes too great for the reactions to continue. So an isolated battery always has a 'characteristic' voltage, which is directly associated with the energy changes involved in the chemical reaction(s)).   (3) You say that electrons do not push each other but, instead, the electric field pushes the electrons. Well this amounts to electrons pushing electrons after all (not forgetting the negative ions pulling them).  What you didn't point out, or perhaps preferred not to express, is that, unlike the very short-range forces that push one molecule away from another, electrons experience much longer-range forces. This means that electrons, even at great distances, can influence one another, and they continue to exert repulsive forces on each other. In fact, they can affect each other over vast cosmic distances.  (4) So we can easily form a robust mental picture in which electrons then really do push each other around the circuit and other places they can find them. Its just unfortunate that you didn't define the word 'push' very well. But to my mind, 'push' they do.  (5) Your video (like this comment perhaps) could have been much shorter. In essence, "Electrons can influence each other over large distances, and like all interactions in the universe, they don‚Äôt actually 'physically' touch; instead, the forces appear to act through space. However, the 'push' exerted by electrons can extend over significant distances. When the switch is closed in the circuit, it initiates the movement of electrons, which can then cause electrons to re-adjust their positions in and around the light bulb on the opposite side of the switch (and elsewhere). This phenomenon is a form of electrical or electromagnetic interference that is widely understood. Ultimately, the primary force driving the electrons through the light bulb comes from the movement of electrons around the wire."  (6) To put into perspective the incredible forces involved, and way the free electrons in a metal should not be viewed is a flow but an incredibly stiff solid (stiffer than any know molecular solid). If I were to increase the number of free electrons on 1 cm cube cube copper block by only 0.07% it would result in 1 Coulomb of charge on that block (that is the number of electrons flowing across a plane perpendicular to the direction of current flow per second if that current was 1A ). If I were to get a second identical block, also having 1C of charge. On earth, in order to maintain a distance between them of 1 m, so as to counteract the repulsion, I would need to apply a weight of 900 million kilograms! This shows  clearly that it takes only a very tiny disturbance to one electron's position to make other electrons (even those very far away) adjust their position.   (7) Finally. At least in terms of electron movement, magnetic fields can be too much of an abstraction. They are the result of a correction we apply due to time dilation when electrons move at the drift velocity.  That's all.   Two electrons separated by a small distance will repel each other due to the electrostatic force acting between them, allowing us to predict the speed at which they will move apart. However, if these two electrons were moving across your field of view, you would observe their separation speed to be less than what is predicted by electrostatic forces, because time has slowed down for them from your point of view. To resolve this apparent contradiction, we introduce the concept of a 'magnetic force' that acts to keep them together for a longer duration. Even though the electrons are not traveling anywhere near the speed of light, the electric forces involved are so strong that we can still observe relativistic effects, even at very low speeds. Length contraction can also be incorporated into this discussion.  So while abstract concepts like macroscopic electric and magnetic fields are useful, isn‚Äôt it more intuitive to think of electrons as simply pushing each other around?  For example, the statement "An inductor resists attempts to change the magnitude of the current flowing through it" can be confusing. What does that mean? Why does it happen? How does it work? It can leave one feeling perplexed! Maxwell's equations are also useful, but give little 'physical' insight.

The electron repulsion in a metal is strongly screened, meaning that an electron travelling along at a certain speed will not repel an electron 100 atomic radii away. In many cases, it will even attract that electron due to weak phonon exchange (this weak attraction gives superconductivity, and essentially all ordinary metals become superconducting at some low enough temperature).

Another way to think of this is that the electrical characteristics of a circuit exist in the now (no time needs to elapse for a circuit to manifest these ever present characteristics).  The actual time lapse is the building up of the electromagnetic field between the source and the load that are separated by only one meter of air.  Air is also part of the circuit's electrical characteristics, except it can be represented by trillions of shunt/parallel circuits that are characterized by extremely high impedance (and increasingly greater impedance as each path is further and further distanced from the source and the load).  Nevertheless, when trillions of high-impedance parallel circuits are combined, they can mathematically be represented as a single circuit in which the voltage source is merely one meter away from the load.  Hence, nearly an instantaneous response time (but still not instantaneous because the field must build and there is much resistance to this happening).

An electron carries an electric field in it's static (immobile or not moving) state. When the electrons in it' mobile (moving state) the electric fields around it interacts with or oppressed by the other electric  fields of same or opposite charged particles,so there is a change electric field,which induces magnetic field and thus by creating Electro magnetic field. And it's this electro magnetic field which attracts & repels charged particles  The electric field lines or the electo magnetic field created due to it's interaction or change in the electric field acts as the string force between charged particles (P & E)  The electro magnetic fields formed between particles of same charge acts as a string expanded or stretched force,which causes the particles to repel each other in opposite direction with equal force.This is the string expansion force of electro magnetic field between same charged particles (Repulsive force of electro magnetism)   The electro magnetic fields formed between particles of opposite charges acts as the string shrinked or contracted,which causes particles to attract each other towards one direction (Electron to Proton)This is the string contraction force of Electro magnetic field between opposite charged particles (Attractive force of electro magnetism)

Thank you for the great video, questions like these are fun to think about.  Though the basic idea that the energy is transported by the electromagnetic field is correct, I think you missed some crucial points that I will outline in the following.    In order that a noteable current flows through the bulb, the two lightseconds long conducting wires should have a zero or negligible resistance. Thus, the wire material consists of a perfect conductor and the electrical field within the conductor vanishes. This doesn't imply that there is no current or electron motion since an electric field is only required to accalerate the electrons, or rather to compensate the friction by the lattice wich is usually called resistance. Thus, the electrons in the wire can move at a constant drift-velocity which causes the current. This is neccesary, than without a current there is no magnetic field and hence no energy transport, neither by the electrons themselves, nor by the eletromagnetic field as described by the Poynting-vector.  At the moment the switch is closed, the conducting wires get charged. The part connected to the plus-pole of the battery is positively charged, the part connected to the minus-pole is negatively charged. Because the wires are perfect conducting, the charges are localized at the surface of the wires, the inside of the wires is electrically neutral. In reality, it will take a finite time for the charges to reach the bulb. Neglecting retardation effects (which is of course not correct), the time it takes can be estimated from simple electrodynamics. Assigning a capacity of $C$ to the bulb and a resistancy $R$ to the wires, the potential over the bulb as a function over time is given by $U\left(t\right)=U_0\left(1-e^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\right)=U_0$ where $U_0$ is the voltage of the battery and the latter equation holds for a perfect conductor with $R=0 \ \Omega$. Hence, for a perfect conductor this will not be the limiting factor, instead, it is the speed of light in the wires.  Once the charges have reached the bulb, the charge distributions along the two conducting wires are homogeneous, there is no charge gradient. The surface charges induce an electrical field outside the wires that points radially into the negatively charged wire, and radially out of the positively charged wire. At the same time, the constant drift of the electrons, i.e. the current, induces a magnetic field circling the wires. As a result, along both conducting wires, the Poynting vector points from the battery to the bulb. This is a result also obtained in the video, although the radial electric fields around the wires are not considered at all in the video.  As stated in the video, the energy transport can be interpreted via the Poynting vector. However, since both the electric and magnetic field decrease like $1/r$ where $r$ is the distance to the wire, the bulk part of energy transport is guided by the conductors and takes the lightsecond-long path. The energy portion transported directly through the air or vacuum is way smaller and most likely too weak to make the bulb emitting light.  Hence, I think it takes at least one second for the bulb to emit. Eventually longer because the charge distribution within the wires most likely spreads with the speed of light in copper. At the end, it is this speed that determines the delay time. As long as these charges didn't reach the bulb, there were no electrical field at the position of the bulb and hence no energy arrival by the Poynting vector.  From this point of view, it is a matter of taste wether you prefer the picture of energy transport via the Poynting vector or by electrons pushing eachother...

Here is an analogy regarding electricity for a generator, wires and resistor (load)  A rope, a weight or load and a pulley,. You pull the rope to lift the weight.... You are the generator to generate the energy, the rope transfers the energy to the weight (load) which is lifted. That is, the energy is transferred to the load.  Same with electricity.... The generator is the energy source which is transferred to the load via the wires. If there is no load or resistor there is no energy transfer. The electrons do not travel along the wire, it's the force of the electrons on each other, like a spring. It's the magic of electrons and it works with the telephone as well.  If there is no weight or load there is no transfer of energy.    What do you think?

QED Other types of lamps (not discussed herein) will require more time to actually glow, which will be a function of the current volume thru the lamp itself... And yes I forgot one topic of the charge gradient that develops along the surface of the wire due to the battery‚Äôs voltage.  When the circuit is connected, the potential difference between the battery‚Äôs terminals creates a distribution of charges along the surface of the wire. This charge distribution contributes to the creation of the electric field.  The electric field inside the wire drives the drift of electrons, and this movement of electrons constitutes the current.   However, the energy transfer happens much faster than the drift of individual electrons due to the propagation of the field.
Ok I don't know much but form my perspective,  In a simple circuit, when a battery is connected, it provides potential difference and creates an electric field that propagates almost instantaneously through the wires have speed equal to speed light C, driving electrons to move and create a current.  And  we have question: does elctron really move?  Answer is Yes they do , but here is catch, electrons do move slowly (drift velocity) in fact very slowly, and the actual energy transfer occurs through the electromagnetic field established by the electric and magnetic forces around the wire.  And you ask how EM field move and tranfer energy? Answer is poyntig vector,  The Poynting vector describes how this energy flows outside the conductor, not by the physical movement of electrons.    About bulb .  Inside the bulb‚Äôs filament, electrical energy is converted into heat through Joule heating, causing the filament to glow via incandescence. While electrons play a role, it is the electric field and electromagnetic energy transfer that power the circuit and light the bulb.  I think ü§î this may help to understand all.   for more details For enthusiastic science people,  i want to include quantum mechanics,  elctron are not actual particle, but they create elctron cloud around nuclear in their perticular energy levels, we may also called them 'Fermi gas '. they obey Fermi dirac statistic for charge distribution. And The quantum nature of electrons means that their exact positions and velocities are governed by probabilities. However, the collective behavior of many electrons leads to the observable flow of current.

Me I have zero diploma's about electricity but it has always interested me deeply. So, was I right then?
Metal SURFACE electrons move much faster than electrons in the metal BULK conduction band, that is how electric circuits actually work, but we never learn this at school, not even at universities. Metal surface electrons can have a velocity close to the speed of light, and are described as FREE electrons that move in a 2D space.   A piece of metal that is electrical neutral still has many ultra rapid surface electrons that can travel with almost the speed of light, so when metal is connected to a voltage source (plus or minus battery terminal for instance) it will receive extra surface electrons (minus voltage) or it will give away surface electrons (plus voltage) in a very short time interval. A surface charge imbalance spreads with almost the speed of light over the metal surface, for instance a long copper wire, and this is the reason a light bulb switches on or off so quickly, which has nothing to do with the speed of a TEM wave.  A piece of metal that isn't electrical neutral has an excess or a lack of surface electrons, and then it carries a 'monopole' voltage with respect to infinity (radial electric field lines perpendicular to the metal surface). Many people overlook the 'monopole' wire voltage when considering the Poynting vector of power transport parallel to metal wire.   Since metal has non-zero ohmic resistance at room temperature, the density of surface electrons must have a gradient in a closed circuit that carries electric current. The electron density gradient at the metal surface is necessary to create an electric field parallel to the current that causes the bulk electrons to flow, and that that compensates for the metal bulk ohmic resistance.  I hope my comment helps to understand how electricity (in circuits) works.

I think this video brings to light two very important aspects of the scientific process. Failure & community.   Failure is necessary to improve our understanding of any idea. The First attempt is always usually a failure, however, it gives us the gift of data to start iterating our way toward the right answer. Our society would benefit greatly from no longer shying away from failures, and celebrating them as a necessary valuable aspect of the process of learning. I appreciate this video because if he would have avoided his mistake, we wouldn't have gotten to experience this more in depth explanation of these concepts.   The second aspect I think we should be celebrating is community. Our world would benefit greatly from our celebrating our shared interest in science, and education. Celebrating each other for making educational content. And I personally believe the best way to celebrate this community is engaging each others work, even if there is nothing wrong with it. Often, the most engagement comes from attempts to prove each other wrong. We all benefit from evolving the scope of our engagement with each others content based on the scientific process by reproducing each other's experiments just for the sake of engagement. Attempting to make them better, or changing the parameters of the experiments to add to the conversation.

4:46 I don't fully agree. I mean, if you average over a few atoms like you described, then yes, the average will be extremely close to 0, _but, I would argue, it would still technically not quite be 0._ Think about how fast the change in drift velocity of electrons occurs in electrical wires, it changes at near light speeds, so if you apply a voltage between the ends of a wire, it takes next to no time at all for the electrons to begin drifting, add that to the fact that the drift velocity itself is extremely slow (even to us) and absurdly slow relative to the near light speed of the change in drift velocity, and this creates the perfect storm of conditions to hide the "bunching" and "thinning" of electrons that would occur right at the battery leads or power source. Think of it like the speed of sound in a long rod of a very stiff substance, where the speed of sound is the light-speed drift velocity delay, and the speed you are pushing the object is the drift velocity itself. if you were to push it slowly, and the substance had a high speed of sound (which is the physical equivalent to electrons in a wire), then as you push the rod, before any visible deformation (bunching-up or widening) could occur on your end, the rod would equalize that force and motion would be transferred all the way to the end of the rod, same goes for pulling. relating that to electricity, the electron cloud in metal wires is like a very stiff and dense solid with a high speed of sound that does not deform easily, and since the amount that it deforms is the physical equivalent to a concentration gradient of electrons forming in the wire (a bunching-up at one end and a thinning-out at the other) therefore you don't find a noticeable gradient. but its still there, its just so imperceptibly small that you cant see it much of the time.

Sorry, but electrons do NOT swarm. They are FIXED quanta of energy in an atom. Increasing or decreasing the energy applied to the atom causes the equivalent charge of an electron to be either added to or removed from the atom. The change in the charge of an atom produces a change in its electromagnetic field. It is that change in the field that propagates through "space" (which is not actually empty, but is comprised of what is now being called Planck Spherical Units - thanks to Planck and Nassim Haramein). This change in the field around the atom propagates infinitely out through the entire universe in all directions. If there is no change, the field is static, but it is still there - just like the magnetic fields around a magnet. Consider the DC steady state situation after the switch is closed.  The electric field runs along the wire.  There are electric forces that can move the electrons along the wire.  The electric field force can do work on the electrons.  The magnetic field is perpendicular to the wire. It would force electrons radially towards the center of the wire, except that the magnetic field goes around the wire anyway and the sum force on the electron from the magnetic field is very small.  In any case, the total radial sum force is zero because electrons do not leave or enter the wire.   So, the magnetic field does not do any work on the electrons.  The energy basically moves along the wire.  I dare say that generally the energy moves along the wires for AC as well, except for circumstances like transformers where the magnetic field plays a significant role.  Of course, there is always some leakage of electromagnetic radiation.  Electromagnetic radiation does not have these physical restrictions and energy is transmitted in equal portions by the electrical and magnetic fields.  The electric and magnetic fields are also in phase.  I think Poynting's equation has been misapplied.

How could this be?  Before the switch was closed the wire was charged all the way around the circuit so that there was a voltage across the switch. That means there was a radial charge differential between the center line of the wire and the surface of the wire. There was a radial force separating charges that ran the length of the wire. The wires were storing energy. When the switch was closed the electric field on the switch side changed effecting forces on charges on the load side of the wires. This facilitated energy from the wire feeding the load by dissipating some of the radial forces along the wire on the load side. Some of the radial force remains resulting in a potential drop along the length of the wires.   It seems to me that this demonstration is inconclusive. I am not doubting Poynting's equation but its application here (healthy scepticism).

You've made a terminated folded dipole there, and as you're looking at time of flight for an edge,you have to analyse that across all fequencies of interest, from DC to daylight as they say.  Comparing a transmitted and received pulse (or an edge) over a short time frame, means you also have a wide range of high frequencies involved - a Fourier series. The faster the rise time and the smaller time resolution desired, the higher the frequencies of interest, and the more important physical distances and topology become compared to wavelength. With conductors a meter apart and fed in that way, you have a dc circuit, an ac circuit, a transmission line, various coupling mechanisms, and an antenna (many in fact!).  So in a way, you're not only demonstrating how electricty and em fields work, but how they interact and modify signals like a pulse, and we have to apply different models and methods at different frequencies to be able predict and control desired behaviour, and mitigate unwanted behaviour such as cross talk, emi, standing waves, attenuation, power loss through radiation etc.   This why there are various means of transmitting energy ranging from shielded and unshielded pairs and parallel lines, to twisted pairs, co-ax cables, heliax and waveguides etc, And why RF techniques, transmission line, matching, sheilding, and edge-shaping/re-generation and time of arrival delays etc are used in high-speed digital and mixed-signal chip and pcb design. Even measuring techniques and intsruments have to be analysed and used very carefully because of this.  Signal integrity, it can a hugely important topic for scientists, engineers and technicians, and even electrical installers too, with "modern" equipment such as varianble speed drives that use switched high frequencies to synthesise low frequencies.  Lucky for us/me the clever guys crunch all this down to levels we can understand enough to apply and perhaps diagnose when things go wrong :)

The problem with your question is its a hypothetical where you have to ignore so many practical issues and parasitic effects for the question to be valid. This is why us engineers heads caught on fire.
As an ex-physics teacher I am intrigued by the views of hardened practical electric engineers and those who bring a more theoretical explanation to the effects observed. The history of electrical engineering is littered with physicists shining new light in such areas.   Experienced engineers insist that the energy due to an electric current is carried by the movement of electrons within a conductor.  Others state that the energy is contained in the fields around it.    The actual velocity of electrons in a conductor is far less than the speed of information it carries.  An electron in a transatlantic cable might take say 300 years to cross the ocean.  The battery within a flashlight might go flat before a single electron has travelled once around the circuit.  The magnetic field around a current-bearing conductor does contain energy.  This is the principle of the transformer whereby the energy in a primary coil may reappear at a secondary coil when the varying primary magnetic field links the two.    The charge carriers within a metallic conductor are known to be electrons.  These are not the hard billiard balls so beloved in many explanations but also have wave-like properties, as demonstrated for example in interference experiments.  Under certain circumstances moving electron beams may cancel each other out.  This would not be possible if electrons behaved simply as a stream of machine gun bullets. So chapters one and two of the textbooks are confirmed.  "In electricity the potential energy and the potential energy differences are due to electric fields and electric charges. Voltage is a potential energy difference similar to the potential energy difference in the mechanical case. Instead of being moved by the force of gravity electric charges are moved by the force of an electric field. The electron loses energy as it moves from a negatively charged point to a positively charged point. This is the same as a book losing energy as it falls from a tabletop to the floor. The lost energy of the electron could be converted to heat and light as the electron moves through a lamp. There is a voltage (potential energy difference) between the negative and positive areas. These negative and positive terminals of a battery such as a lead acid cell; this is a common source of voltage. A potential energy difference exists between the negative and the positive terminals of the battery. This voltage is due to an excess of electrons on the negative terminal and a deficiency of electrons on the positive terminal. When electrons move from the negative terminal to the positive terminal of the battery work is done. Energy is taken from the battery and converted into another form of energy.  Like in a mechanical system the electric system can be reversed. That is the electron can gain energy when it is moved from a positively charged point to a negatively charged point. This is what happens when a battery is charged. The battery charger forces electrons back through the battery in the reverse direction."

I saw electrical pulse delays every day in the lab while working as an engineer at a major aerospace company. Since most signals were on PCBs, the time delays were in small nanosecond. While the electron flow is relatively slow, the field change is fast. Matching impedance (capacitance- inductance) of the cable or transmission line with the source and load best preserved the pulse shape. The rule of thumb is 1 nS/ft for delays. That is bs ‚Ä¶ In an electrical circuit that uses wires insulated with the best material available, there is no electrical field. Proof of that is the classical capacitor ‚Äì the charges remain on each armature because they have an insulator between them, which keeps the capacitor charged and prevents charge flow from one armature to the other. To discharge the capacitor, you‚Äôll need a conductor between the armatures (a copper wire, for example). Besides that, what we are talking about here, is an electrical circuit ‚Äì which implies a CLOSED wiring. The presented circuit is misleading ‚Äì it should be depicted like this: the battery at the bottom of the page, both wires parallel to each other to the top of the page and the LED at the end of those ‚Äì at the top of the page. If the length of each wire is imagined to be three million kilometers long (ten light-seconds), the LED would still light up the very moment of turning the switch on. The only thing that would take time (10 seconds), is the light from the LED reaching the observer's eye (who stands right near the battery). In conclusion: the speed of light is NOT the maximum speed limit ‚Ä¶ in fact it is some sort of zero compared to the speed with which events happen in this thought experiment. In a good conductor where there is a electric field there's current and where there is current there is electric field. So where is the energy? Well it's at any point where you have current inside or on surface of wire and in the fields OUTSIDE the wire. SORTED!  As an example, if a wire is surrounded by a conductor current in wire will result in electric field outside wire and this will induce current in surrounding conductor. At a POINT in surrounding conductor divergence of Poynting vector will be negative which implies a SINK OF ENERGY at that POINT and so demonstrates energy outside wire.  So for DC or AC the energy is in every POINT of the wire and surface of wire that contain current and in the fields OUTSIDE the wire. SORTED!  Div(S) = -E*J = -J*E All sorted with a nice little sum. It seems that there are two effects here which are illustrated at about 18:50 into the video. The first is the electric field emanating from the vicinity of the  battery/switch. This is transmitted through the air and results in a relatively small voltage at the bulb. The second is the current transmitted through the conductor. This current is due to the EMF (field) in the conductor and is transmitted through the conductor at the speed of light. Since the main question seems to be about the time taken for transmission of power in a circuit, it is very misleading to include the first scenario, which is at best a second order effect, enhanced in this case by the proximity of the battery/switch and the bulb. There is a good reason we use conductors to transmit electric power... They are orders of magnitude more efficient that using fields through the air.

I removed my negative comment, because this explanation actually makes sense, as opposed to your prior video. That said, electromagnetic forces are not energy. They are body forces that energize electrons or photons. The electrons are what transmit the energy in a circuit. It's really semantics of how scientists define energy. If a rock falls off a cliff and hits something, gravity did not "transmit/carry" the energy. The rock did. By definition, body forces do not transmit energy.
This video is a better explanation. It's a bit long winded. You could have explained this without getting into the weeds. Your first video was incomprehensible. You're also making the assumption that engineers think electricity works the way they're taught in their basic circuits classes. Good engineers know those are models meant to simplify circuit design and analysis. Engineers know they need to account for the fields, especially when the current is high enough to affect adjacent circuits, or the current is switching so quickly, EMI becomes a serious problem. Furthermore, saying the fields carry the energy is semantics. Energy itself, and conservation of energy, is a scalar construct that stems directly from Newton's laws, which are vector laws. The concept of energy is useful for solving problems, and designing machines. However, it's best to remember that energy is merely a construct. Even in the way scientists typically explain energy, they don't say that body forces are the energy. They say that objects affected by the body forces, have potential energy. It's the objects that transmit the energy (scalar of conservation of momentum) from one location to another.

In generator-tech trade school we learned the right hand rule, and that magnetic fields emanate and collapse from the center of the conductor outwards in AC flowing circuits. The magnetic field "cuts" its own wire as it expands outwards, and cuts it again when it collapses. This was how we were taught that AC accomplishes Faraday's rules of induction, that the expanding and contracting magnetic field cutting its own wire, and possibly coils of nearby wire, at a set frequency is the motion of the magnetic field cutting a conductor. This "self-inflicted induction" AC causes is known as inductive reactance. We were taught this is how transformers operate, with AC a must-have to bring "relative motion" into the mix which should induce current in all conductors cut by the ever-propagating magnetic field in and around the wires, and even in wires not physically connected to the circuit. We were never taught that this "breathing" magnetic field in and around the wires were accompanied by an electric field brought on by surface charge differential that was started and maintained by some power source. We were not taught that these two interconnected fields actually transfer the energy which causes the electrons to move. This inductive reactance can get so out-of-hand that it creates a counter-voltage working against the source of power. With more motors on the circuit, capacitors may be needed to reduce the counter-EMF. "Current lags behind voltage" when dealing with an inductive-heavy circuit load, such as motors. This separation of the voltage and current arriving out of sync is known as the power factor, expressed in a percentage. The inverse cosine of the power factor equals the angle of separation between the voltage and current. This video demonstrates that the "conductor hopping" nature of AC transformers that is mind-boggling to us is a more appropriate demonstration of how electricity works than the contemporary idea of electrons flowing through a closed loop circuit inside low resistance conductors. Fascinating. Thank you.

By ‚Äúon‚Äù, most people would understand that to mean that the potential difference across the load (a light bulb, resistor, whatever) at its rated value for the given circuit. You (Veritasium) are correct by saying that a voltage signal is seen at 1m/c seconds after flipping the switch, but this signal has a magnitude that is far less than the rated voltage (although it is still orders of magnitude greater than any leakage-related signal)  A better question to ask here is what are you trying to show/teach here? Yes, in transient response (i.e. something changes in the circuit like a switch closing), all signals respond given the propagation of the electric and magnetic fields in the surrounding insulator (which is some very significant portion of the speed of light), but these responses are often negligible except for cases of high frequency transients or long distances and high impedances (i.e. computer circuitry and transmission lines). The signal we ‚Äúcare‚Äù about propagates along the conductor itself and reflects  at changes of impedances. You even demonstrated that with the field simulations for a conductor that wasn‚Äôt even connected to the original circuit.  So it‚Äôs better to say that ‚Äúelectricity is more complicated than you think‚Äù rather than ‚Äúhow electricity actually works‚Äù.

Imagine the ocean with its vast expanse of waves rolling toward the shore.  The waves represent the electromagnetic signal or wave in an electrical current. Just as the energy of an ocean wave can travel vast distances across the sea, the electromagnetic wave travels quickly down a wire. When you see a wave approach from the horizon and move toward the shore, it's like the electrical signal traveling down a wire.  The water molecules in these waves represent the electrons in a conductor. When a wave passes through a particular spot in the ocean, the water molecules at that spot mainly move up and down (and perhaps a little bit in the direction of the wave, but not much). They don't travel far horizontally with the wave; instead, they transmit the wave's energy to neighboring water molecules through their up-and-down motion. Similarly, in a conductor, the electrons themselves don't travel very fast (they have a slow "drift velocity"). However, they help transmit the energy of the electromagnetic wave by moving and interacting with neighboring electrons.  So, when you're standing at the beach and watching waves roll in, it's a bit like watching an electrical current flow. The overall wave (or signal) moves quickly and covers long distances, while the individual water molecules (or electrons) are more involved in transmitting that energy locally.

Current wars
You're great, and this video is awesome. However, your original video was flat out wrong. You mentioned that the entire energy is carried by fields outside the wires, and made it seem as if this is the MAJORITY of the energy. You even claimed that this is how energy is transmitted from the power plant to our homes.  In fact, as you showed and explained very nicely in this video, this is a 2nd order effect. In this case, you measured 5V on the resistor, which is 25% of the terminal voltage. This corresponds to about 0.25^2=0.05 of the energy! And this is only because the two wires are very close. This "leakage" of energy is a near-field effect and drops way more rapidly than 1/r^2. Finally, this "leakage" only occurs when there's a load (resistance) to take energy from.  So yes, technically, the answer to your riddle is right, non-negligible current will reach the light bulb by t=1/c and if the light bulb is sensitive enough it will turn on.  But your big mistake is actually comparing this to how electricity gets from the power plant to our homes. And you're reinforcing that mistake in the video by stating that this is how wireless charging works. If this is how wireless charging worked, you didn't need the charger to ATTACH to the device. The charger needs to be attached because this is a near-field effect, as I mentioned earlier.  To summarize, I think you could've acknowledged your mistake in this case, rather than claim that you just didn't explain yourself well enough. The big mistake here is not about when the light bulb will turn on, but the fact that MOST of the energy is propagating on the surface of the wires, while you claimed it propagated through space.  BTW - it's also possible to 'steal' electricity without paying for it by putting a load near a high voltage wire. But this is stealing, not the main way electricity gets from the plant to our homes.

What is the difference between Particle Physics and Field Physics?   The main question I would ask is, "How big is an electron?" In the video, individual electrons do not act like little round balls. They act like interconnected fields. Or even better, one field with tiny spikes in energy that we can measure and call an electron. The field's individual power points (electrons) will jiggle when the circuit is complete to the whole field.   So yes, you can measure an individual spike in the field, detect its variables, and call it a particle. However, no single point divides one particle in an area from another. How big is that field?   Could you just lift a tablecloth to make a wrinkle, then ask how big the crease is? The correct answer is because the ends of the fabric move a tiny bit, the entire length and width of the tablecloth. So, we live in a one-electron field universe with a few spikes here and there. The number of particles depends on your frame of reference.

A simpler explanation...  Electrons don't carry the energy, they are the energy. Electricity and Magnetic fields are simply two aspects of the same thing/mutually inclusive (movement of electrons creates a magnetic field, and a magnetic field creates a flow of electrons)  If you disregard material conductivity, resistance, thermal loss, etc., the length of the wire is irrelevant. electrons are already present in the wire (they exist in everything), they don't need to be connected to a battery/power source to receive electrons. It's the movement/oscillation of those electrons between a positive and negative charge that produces electricity.  In liquid terms, there is no delay because the water source/battery doesn't need to flow to fill up an empty pipe, and exit the other end. OMG. Listen. If electrons or their fields push each other or not doesn't matter. What electrons do when they come near each other is passing a photon to each other and this (virtual) photon is the repulsive force (i.e.  electro magnetic field) of the negatively charged electrons. That is a well studied fact. Second. Electric force is actually the magnetic force which is actually the photons that pass trough the electrons when the electrons are pulled toward the positive charge. The atom from which the electron is pulled away shoots a virtual photon (electric pulling force) to the next near atom's electron to pull it in to itself. In turn the next atom shoots photon to the next atom's electron and so is the electric field created. That is why current is opposite to electric flow - because the virtual photon is shooting to the direction opposite to the electron flow (this virtual photon is called pulling magnetic force or bozon). Third - the electrons do repel each other and that is why we have conductors, semi conductors and a combination of the latter - ( transistors). This is also why the longer the conductors are the higher the resistance is, hence the weaker the voltage. and current are. This occurs because every next atom pulls weaker the next atom's electron, hence every next atom that is further from the initial potential has a more stable electron.  Finally in come the oscilators which fix this. Now this is often not taught in school because students then ask - ok what is a charge. The electrons flow through the wire from valence ring to valence ring to the metal that resist them to produce the light to the cathode. All the electricity flows through the valence electrons, the outermost ring of electrons for that particular conductor. This is how chemistry works. The oxygen atom has a negative charge in that it's short an electron in the outer ring so it pairs with another oxygen atom and they share an electron and the natural state of oxygen is O2. Hydrogen has one electron so it takes two hydrogen per oxygen to have a stable oxygen atom. But the combination is made using the valence electrons which is what powers electricity.
You don't understand the power of the electron until you learn chemistry. Take a beginner college chemistry class and then it took me ten seconds to learn and understand electricity. It's called valence electrons and how they travel to perform work or produce heat or to flip a switch. Chemistry makes electronics simple. Edit. I watched more and you don't understand anything. The copper wire is composed of copper atoms with neutrons and protons in the nucleus. I forget the atomic weight of copper but it has various rings of electrons circling the nucleus. The outermost shell of electrons is called the valence electrons. When you attach a power source to the wire only the valence electrons move pushing from one atom to the next. When you have a light bulb in the circuit the filament of the bulb is made of a metal that resists the electron flow and produces heat and light as a byproduct. The interior of the lightbulb is filled with nitrogen because it is non-flammable otherwise the filament would combine with oxygen and burn up. The battery as a power source has a cathode and an anode. The anode has atoms that have extra electrons in their valence rings and the cathode has negative amount of electrons in their valence rings.

At 7:10 you state that electrons move through the battery, this is incorrect.  The electrons move into the cathode, where they combine with ions, that have moved from the anode, through the electrolyte (and electrically insulating separator).  The ions in the anode start as neutral species, they are disassociated from a neutral species to an ion due to a difference in chemical potential of the species (i.e. the Fermi level) in the anode vs. the cathode.  Thus, charge does move through the battery, but the charge is actually carried by positive ions. If the battery could conduct electrons, it would self discharge very quickly.  By definition, a battery has to have a very high Ohmic impedance, and rely on an external circuit as a pathway for batteries.  Of course, this only applies to the battery discharging (doing external work), when you charge the battery ions move from the cathode to the anode.

As I understand,  the electric field generated by the power source exists within the wires of the circuit and extends outside the wires into the surrounding space. Not just moving electrons on the surface of the wires.  The electric field lines extend from the positive terminal of the power source through the circuit to the negative terminal. As the electric field lines pass through the conductive material of the wire, they exert forces on the electric charges (electrons) within the wire, causing them to move and carry electrical energy through the circuit.

TLDR: Energy is transported both by electrons and through the fields. Electrons interact via the electromagnetic field, and the energy related to these interactions is carried by this field, allowing for energy transport both within and outside of conductors.  In the realm of quantum physics, matter is composed of fundamental particles, exhibiting a property known as wave-particle duality. The electron, one such particle, is not just a point-like entity but is more accurately represented by a quantum field, the electron field. Electrons carry an inherent property - electric charge, which is quantized. This charge is not merely a label, but the source of rich interactions mediated by another quantum field, the electromagnetic field. These fields are distinct, yet intimately connected. The electromagnetic field mediates the interaction between electrons, and this interaction is fundamentally governed by the amount of charge they possess. This relationship is captured by mathematical models such as Coulomb's law. However, in our daily language, we often speak in terms of voltage, which is tied to the electric field. This is an electrostatic approximation, and in time-varying, dynamic situations, it's more accurate to speak in terms of the broader electromagnetic field. When we discuss the flow of electric charge, we talk about current, which is typically confined to conductors like wires. But when we consider the flow of energy, we enter the realm of the electromagnetic field that surrounds and permeates these conductors. The Poynting vector is a tool that gives us the direction of this energy flow within the field. The energy within these systems is a conserved quantity and represents their capacity to do work. This is encapsulated in the definition of work, W=F‚ãÖD‚ãÖcos(Œ∏), where F = force, D = displacement in meters, cos is the cosine trigonometric function, Œ∏ is the angle at which the force is applied, and work has units of joules (J), a measure of energy. The potential energy of an electron within a system is a function of its location and proximity to other charges, indicating its capacity to do work. The electromagnetic field is more than just a stage for these interactions. It's a player in its own right, mediating the forces that move electrons and is responsible for transporting energy in electromagnetic systems. Within this field, electric and magnetic components are inseparable aspects of the same entity, influencing each other such that changing electric fields coincide with magnetic fields. Energy is carried within this electromagnetic field, extending around and beyond conductors. In alternating current (AC) systems, the oscillating electric and magnetic fields can carry energy away from the wires, illustrating that energy is indeed transported via these fields. In contrast, in direct current (DC) systems, the electric and magnetic fields are static. The energy transfer still occurs via the electromagnetic field, but the energy remains within the system unless a change occurs, maintaining the principle of energy conservation. In conclusion, the dance of the electrons, mediated by the electromagnetic field, plays a central role in energy transport both within and outside conductors. The story of energy is told both by the electrons themselves and through the fields they interact with.

Existing cabling had significant problems with interference:  "When a number of wires run parallel to one another, either suspended or otherwise, any change in the current flowing in one wire causes currents in all the rest by induction, and the effect may be so great as to seriously interfere with the working of telephonic circuits, and to a less degree of ordinary telegraphic circuits also."  Heaviside‚Äôs solution was the coaxial cable, an inner conductor surrounded by an insulating layer, which was then surrounded by a conducting shield.  "My improvements have for object to obtain perfect protection, and to render a circuit completely independent under all circumstances of external inductive influences. For this purpose I use two insulated conductors for the circuit, and place one of them inside the other; thus, one conductor may be a wire, and the other a tube or sheath, which must also be insulated. When the tube and inner wire are electrically connected at both ends of the line, as through apparatus in the usual manner, the circuit as thus described is completely independent of other circuits, and any number of such circuits, each containing an insulated tube and inner wire, may be laid side by side without any mutual inductive interference, and without interference from other wires worked in ordinary manners."

I occasionally teach electronics. I impress upon students that a volt is a joule of energy per coulomb of electrical charge. This suggests that the energy is in the electrons themselves (as a field) and not because they are flowing like water in a pipe. One of my analogies is, to take the energy (ounce of sugar) in one can of coke. Or this can of coke could have 2 ounces of energy in it. It would deliver twice the energy to your body as the can with one ounce of sugar. The current (energy delivered to your body) only specifies the number of cokes which you consume over some time period. Here too, the product of the sugar delivered (number of cokes) and how many are consumed in the time period, yields the energy-rate or power. The point of this is that the ENERGY of the electrons vary, not the FLOW of the electrons. This dispenses the myth that voltage is akin to water pressure. There is no way you can derive units of pressure that are analogous to voltage when you realize that the pressure on the water doesn't equate with water itself possessing variable energy.

Use one across from the switch called E, one on the far end of the circuit on the closed-negative side called N, and one on the far end of the circuit on the closed-positive side called P. Electric current and electromagnetic energy are two totally separate things. Electricity is defined as the flow of charged particles, such as an electron, through a conductor and measured in Coulombs per second, or amperes. The electric and magnetic fields around conductor are considered electromagnetic energy and are measured in joules. Fields travel at the purported speed of light. Electric charge flow is much slower.  I think pointing out this distinction is important for people trying to understand what electricity is and the energetic forms it takes.

My only nitpicking is The illustration of the electrons flowing between positively charged atoms of the copper wire. I believe that is inaccurate. Because the copper wire atoms are bonded together in an extremely long cylindrical shape, the invisible electronal shell doesn't travel between the atomic bonds, but follows the outside of the positively charged wire as a continuous electronal field that not only propagates out from the wire, but along the length of the wire forming a kind of toroidal tube "on the outside of the physical wire only" similarly to how neruo electric impulses travel along the myelin sheathing on the outside of a neuron, and not through the inner stalk. And once you kick on the power, the impulses will follow the path of least resistance along the outside electronal torus. Also, the toroidal field will extend out as the majority of the load follows the wire lengthwise. Which is why, the higher the electrical load, the bigger gauge wire required and thicker insulation is required. I understand the speed of light is the physical speed limit. But would that be applied to information? I don't see why we couldn't communicate across a distance faster than the speed of light. Obviously we wouldn't use electromagnetic waves to transmit the information. We know matter cannot travel faster than the speed of light, but information is not matter. To get information from one point to another, it simply needs to exist at point B as a result of it existing at point A.  For example, if I have a 1m pole in my hand that I thrust forward at 20mph for just under a second, the matter the pole is made of never exceeds more than more than 20mph, but from the point my hand starts thrusting on the side of the pole closest to me, the other end of the pole begins moving. While the pole moved 20mph, the information of the pole moving traveled from my end of the pole to the far end of the pole as instantly as the pole is ridgid. So hypothetically, if we had an infinitely ridged pole, we could transmit information instantly across space.  I only took high school physics but does what I say not make sense?

...it appears that this experiment is conflating two separate phenomenon: rf transmission and power transmission.  The early, low voltage signal you are seeing is the reception of the rf signal that was transmitted when the contact is closed.  The experiment has essentially setup an ideal radio transmitter and receiver combination.  But the true power transmission does not arrive at the load until much later.

Electrons do not push each other through a wire?  And the electron density all around a circuit is constant?  Thinking about the transmission speed of electricity utterly destroys this notion. You have the part of the wire where electricity is flowing and the part ahead where it is yet to start flowing, so clearly the electron density where there is flow is greater than where there isn't!  As current flows in a DC circuit, there is less and less resistance to be overcome as current travels around the wire because there is less wire in front of it (resistance is proportional to wire length).  Electron density is greatest where electrons come out of the PS, current being maintained all around the circuit by the speed of the electrons being greater as they travel around the circuit, but their density is less!  Conclusion - of course electrons push each other through the wire!

I am a High School Science Teacher. I am glad that EEVblog has pointed out that you neglected to put the Unit "Meters" after the 1 in 'Answer D'. Your original 'Answer D' was "1/c s".  I am always telling Students: "Write Your Units! [or it's just wrong]". In addition, I would like to point out that having the "seconds" there in the answer is also incorrect.  Since the Units of "c" [Speed of Light in a Vacuum] are already "m/s", when you divide your 1m by it, you get an answer already in Seconds. Then if you multiply that by Seconds again, you get an answer in "Seconds Squared". So actually, "D" becomes the worst answer, because of its incorrect units. And without putting in the meters, like they actually did in their video,  it would be even worse... "Seconds Squared per Meter". Even if the other answers are not quantitatively correct, they are "better" because they at least have the units of "Seconds".

After 15min I realized this is, as a PCB design engineer, the so called  Crosstalk.
There's a reason hardware stores sell wire of several different diameters. The *cross sectional area* (not surface area) of wires dictates how much DC or low-frequency AC current they can carry. This is a basic fact of electrical engineering that can be verified from any source including your local Home Depot associate. Sustained transmission line dynamics and the "skin effect" only apply to alternating currents of high enough frequency (usually RF in practice) for EM effects to predominate. This video fails to clarify this distinction and is extremely misleading.

My only disagreement is that the light bulb would not turn on if the wire were broken. Your own animation shows that. If the wire were broken, the other end of the switch would not accumulate positive surface charges. Thus, when the switch closed, the opposing charges wouldn't cancel each other out and there wouldn't be an induced E field inside the wire. We're only able to achieve wireless charging and such by using circuits that are already completed by wire. Same thing with the HFSS simulation you showed of the disconnected wire with the E field inside. That E field was only induced by a circuit that was complete.

THE ELECTRONS ARE JUST PAWNS  "So, to sum up, electrons don't carry energy from battery to bulb, nor do they push each other through the wire. They are pushed along by an electric field, which is created by charges on the battery, and charges on the surface of the wires. With this view of circuits, things that might have previously seemed mysterious, make a lot more sense. Like, if electrons leave a battery at the same rate and with the same drift velocity as they returned, how do they carry energy from the battery? The answer is: they don't. They are accelerated by the electric field before each collision with the lattice. At a junction, how do the correct number of electrons go down each path? Well, they are guided by the electric field, which extends everywhere throughout the circuit. The fields are the main actors, extending everywhere throughout the circuit. And the electrons, are just their pawns."

Wait a minute.  First things, first.  What REALLY is an "electron"?
A lot of the confusion around this issue is because the first time a person is taught the First Law of Thermodynamics, it is a simplified version. It is usually stated as "Energy is Conserved" or "Energy cannot be created or destroyed." What gets omitted is "in a *_closed_* system." That, and and the simplified claim that work is energy.  The actual law, still somewhat simplified, is that the change in energy in a closed, ŒîE, is equal to the heat exchanged between it and its surroundings, ŒîH, minus the difference in the work done by the system and to the system by its surroundings. Heat is easy, it actually is a flow of energy. But energy is destroyed in the system that does net work, and created a system that has net work done on it. That might seem like a nuanced distinction, so I'll use an example.  A tray holding 100 lbs of quarry stone is at the bottom of a 100 foot cliff. A chain connects it to a system of pulleys at the top of the cliff, and a rope connects the pulleys to a horse. The ratio R, which depends on the number of pulleys, determines what the horse has to do to bring the stone to the top. The horse has to pull with a force of 100/R pounds over a distance of 100*R feet. This way, (100 ft)*(100 lb)=10,000 ft-lb of work is done on the stone, and (100*R)(100/R)-10,000 ft-lb of work is done by the horse. Energy is "conserved" in the combined system.  BUT THIS ENERGY NEVER EXISTS IN THE ROPE, PULLEYS, OR CHAIN. It is "destroyed" in the subsystem of the horse, and "created" in the subsystem of the stone. The net work done by a system lowers its total energy, and the net work done on a system raises it. If a system has zero net work, there is no energy.  A better way to describe it is with Power, the time derivative of Work. The power the horse exerts is force times velocity, or F*V. At any point in time, the horse is applying power F*V to the rope. Assuming a massless rope, there is no energy change in it: but it applies power F*V to the pulley. Which applies power (F*R)*(V/R) to the chain, and thus the stone.  The same is done in this circuit. The battery applies power V*I (volts are the analog of force in electricity, and current is the analog of  velocity) to the wires. If no energy is to be created in the wire, it has to do the same amount of work to the light bulb.

This is basically how science works. People put something out there via papers, folks review or try and replicate and feed back. Collectively we all move on having found the right answer together knowing that we tried everything and asked everyone we could and have to therefore conclude that what is left must be true to the best of our knowledge and experience... until someone else can find something different, in which case the process starts over. You set out to show one scientific principle, you accidentally demonstrated (with others) how all science works.
In this video he's saying something completely different than what he was claiming in his first video. Perhaps it's just the way he phrased it, but he made it seem as if the information of the closed switch immediately traveled across the space between the switch and the bulb so that the bulb "understood" that the circuit was closed and therefore current started flowing right away. However, what's actually happening is a completely different effect: induction current. This happens whether or not the ends are connected. Whenever current changes in one wire, this changes the fields in the space around it so that current starts flowing in other nearby wires. This is a well known effect, and it's how antennas work. Or transformers, induction cooking, electric motors, etcetera. The 300000 km wires were just a misdirection, basically. It had nothing to do with closing the circuit and the lamp somehow getting this information without the current having to travel the whole distance. By the way, he only got 4V at a distance of 1m. If the wires were 2m apart, I would guess that would drop to just 1V (inversely proportional with the square of the distance).

I'm sorry I came to this video so late. I still have a problem with the original postulate, that the light will illuminate within a nanosecond. Yes, technically, SOME current will flow through the light due to EM coupling and transmission line effects, but the magnitude of that current is dependent on the configuration of the conductors. Imagine they were sent arcing out in two vast circles perpendicular to one another. I don't have access to simulation tools to test this, unfortunately, but I'm pretty sure it would be a greatly reduced initial current. In the test done with 250m lines, it did indeed take the expected (by me) time of roughly a microsecond for the current to jump up to the steady-state level. The original video did not ask how long it would take for some small induced current to flow in the light bulb, though a brighter engineer than I would have qualified the intuitive answer of 1 second by "not counting a little induced current taking into account transmission line effects etc.", and I think the follow-up skirts around this.

More proof of the ether
The measured data is exactly what the telegraphist‚Äôs equation by Oliver Heaviside would have predicted 100 plus years ago. It‚Äôs the classic step response of a transmission line with characteristic impedance Zo terminated with a resistor R when driven by an ideal step voltage source Vo. Because of the mismatched impedance a portion of the transmitted voltage Vo appears at the load at 1/c seconds (Assuming Er=1) Then the reflected portion of the wave bounces off the incident end of the line and returns at 2/c seconds to cause the next step in the response. Another step from that second reflected wave returns at 4/c second and so on. Eventually the load voltage settles at Vo and indeed all the energy is transferred to the load. It has to since there is no where else to store it in a lossless transmission line. If R=Zo the is no reflected load and the incident voltage is transferred at 1/c but that is a special case. The interesting thing about this is that it is predicted by Maxwell‚Äôs equations and the transmission formula that can be derived from them. Electrons don‚Äôt even enter the discussion. If you try to model this based on electrons moving along the wire you get the wrong answer because it‚Äôs the wrong model. The energy transfer and the time it takes for the response to be seen at the load is about electromagnetic fields propagating at the speed of light because that is what they are. Lumped element models only work for lumped elements. Transmission lines are not lumped elements. To be honest though I really had to stop and think about this even though I‚Äôve been doing this kind of stuff for a living for 40 years now. It‚Äôs nice to dragged back to the basics now and again.
I believe you could greatly simplify the explanation ty going directly to the characteristic impedance.  You figured 550 ohms. The initial current pulse would be limited by the 550 ohms on each side. Assuming an 11V battery, the initial current pulse would be no more than 11V/1100 ohms, or 10 mA (with negligible resistance of the LED). The LED would light if that  10 mA is sufficient.  You could increase that current and decrease the time by placing the wires much closer together. This would decrease the characteristic impedance.  This s problem can be solve much more easily using just the lumped element equivalent circuit, rather than mysterious 3 D fields. You can use the 3D fields to predict that capacitance or you can just measure the capacitance. The use that capacitance in a lumped element  circuit to analyze the currents. Even the propagation time comes out of the circuit analysis.  I would like to see a discussion and demonstration of what happens if the wires were shielded, as coaxial cables, and also place a ground plane below the wires. That would totally change the performance.

Sorry for nitpicking, but the essence of the original hypothesis is that some light (i.e., power sufficient to emit light from the load) would be apparent VERY quickly in your system where the source and load are separated by only 1m, as are the outgoing and returning legs of the connecting wires. Impact from the stimulus should be detectable at the load in 1/c seconds (based on your "1/c" answer in the prior video/quiz), or ~3nS.  However, the timebase of the o-scope is shown (@18:53 in the video) to be 50(!) nS per division. The apparent voltage at the load is negligible at only 3 nS after the initiation of the step input ("in the noise", so to speak). After an initial charging time of ~30 nS, I see ordinary reflections occurring at ~70 nS intervals, consistent with passage down a 20m pathway.    While you're hanging your hat on the small amount of power (14 mW initial vs. 400 mW steady state) that is induced from the source to the load by virtue of their proximity and the large initial voltage step (20VDC), I see this as vindication of those of us engineers who maintain that the propagation time for delivery of power is a primarily function of the (wired) distance from the source to the load. So forgive me if I don't chuck our TDR equipment into the trash.  üòÅ  Also, can you (or anyone) explain how & why you determined a Z0 of 550 ‚Ñ¶ for your line impedance, but then you DOUBLED it to determine the proper load impedance? "The statement in the Veritasium video is an oversimplification of the process of how electricity works. The idea behind the statement is that the speed of light is so fast that if the distance between the battery and the light bulb is a meter and the distance between the terminals of the light bulb is a light second, the electrons can travel from the battery to the light bulb and complete the circuit in an instant. However, this is not entirely accurate.  The electrons in a circuit do not travel at the speed of light, but instead they travel at a much slower speed, typically on the order of millimeters per second. The speed at which the electrons move through a conductor is dependent on the material and the temperature.  When a circuit is closed, the voltage difference between the terminals of the battery causes the electrons to flow through the circuit, generating a current. The electrons flow through the wire and through the filament in the light bulb, which causes the filament to heat up and produce light. The rate at which the electrons flow through the circuit is determined by the resistance of the circuit and the voltage applied to it.  It's true that the speed of light is extremely fast, but it is not relevant to the process of electron flow in a circuit. The time it takes for the light bulb to turn on is determined by the time it takes for the electrons to travel through the circuit and not by the speed of light."  - chatGPT

A bit of a question. If current is carried, directed, by the wire only on the surface and current isn‚Äôt carried in the wire, I should think we would expect stranded wire of the same gauge as a solid wire to carry more current with greater efficiency since there is a whole lot more exposed surface area in a stranded wire compared to a solid wire. But the opposite is true, a solid wire has greater current carrying capacity than a stranded wire of the same gauge. The only advantage a solid wire has in this contest is greater total volume of conductive material, albeit with less surface area. But it wins out in current carrying capacity.

Someone probably already mentioned it, but as an engineer who does Circuits, RF and Transmission Lines, it appears that antenna theory is being blended together with circuit theory.    An antenna is where energy is transmitted out from wires as electo-magnetic waves. Circuits (with wires and light bulbs) is a closed loop system where the electro-magnetic field is contained _within_ the wires. (ie. between the signal path and the ground plane, usually just under the trace on an FR4 board)  In your example, when you say "circuit", every electrical engineer is going to assume a coaxial cable where the energy is fully constrained inside the cable.  Propagation through copper will be slower though at around 66% of c.  That said, it would be great to see a sequel showing the same setup but using coaxial cables.  Sure, a signal delay can easily be demonstrated with just a 3 foot cable, but why not use a mile long behemoth for dramatic effect!  üòÑ

If the electrons drift at such a low speed, why do electrical effects seem to occur immediately after a switch is thrown, such as when you turn on the room lights? Confusion on this point results from not distinguishing between the drift speed of the electrons and the speed at which changes in the electric feld configuration travel along wires. This latter speed approaches that of light. Similarly, when you turn the valve on your garden hose, with the hose full of water, a pressure wave travels along the hose at the speed of sound in water. The speed at which the water moves through the hose‚Äî measured perhaps with a dye marker‚Äîis much lower.

This is STILL misleading.  Your claim should only be that a closed circuit will generate an electromagnetic field that can induce a small but measurable current on the load.  This is different than the primary driver of the circuit which does in fact have to travel the full length of the wire and is limited by c.  The only reason this initial pulse happens quickly is because your source and your load are close to each other.  If you put the battery at one end and the load at the other, you will find that not only is the initial pulse many magnitudes smaller but the current will not start flowing any sooner than light can travel that same distance.

A few simple Electrical fundamentals.      Electrical Current is the flow of Electrons inside the conductive wires.       Current inside a wire will produce a circulating Magnetic field around that wire for a few mm, its strength proportional to the Current in Amps.       Current, that is the on average, movement of electrons down a wire is due to and proportional to the voltage or PD difference between the beginning and end of that wire.   A wire with voltage on it will have voltage gradient or field between it and other conductive surfaces.    But neither this rotating Magnetic field or the Voltage field anything significant to do with the current flowing down inside the wire, you can feed this wire into a screened metal box or through a grounded metal wall, completely eliminating the earlier external fields and the current still flows through the wire.     Electrical power is not driven by fields, but do form fields of their own.
