My simple Solution / Answer to the flow of Electricity is the example of a Diesel Generator Set. The DG Generator Set has a Diesel Generator and a Alternator. The Alternator has 2 - components namely a Stator and Rotor. The Stator is a Stationery magnetic component which encircles the rotor . The rotor composed of series of copper coils. The rotor is connected to the DG Set by a Shaft. Thus when the DG set runs the rotor also rotates along with the shaft with around a rpm of 300 or so. When the DG Set is in switched off state,  there is a constant flux or lines of forces between the Stator and the Rotor. When the DG Set is switched on , these flux lines between Rotor and Stator are cut and thus the electricity comes out of the DG Set through the conductor. The static flux between the Stator and Rotor is the energy at the stable state which is not doing any work, but a disturbance in this state of the flux causes the energy to destabilize and after this destabilization the energy stabilizes itself by doing the required work i.e glowing a light, running a motor, running a train etc. Thus it is the flux which carries the electrical energy.

Most people are getting confused with AC and DC here. The input pulse here is DC ( which is an AC with 0 frequency). In simple terms during transient state( When just switched on) the current can flow through the capacitor and charge it for a short interval of time. The current also flows through the main circuit and finally through the resistor. So for a short amount of time there is a spike in the voltage across the resistor due to both the capacitor and the source voltage.   At steady state current can no longer flow through the capacitor in case of DC due to infinite reactance and current only flows though the remaining circuit. So the voltage across the resistor becomes equal to the source voltage.  This experiment has nothing to do with electromagnetic induction that happens with AC which is how all transformers, motors, generators, wireless charger, and induction stove etc works.  My explanation has nothing to do with EM wave theory which is different and this is just from a perspective of basic network theory.

Another useful illustration of how the field is more important than the circuit is old car engines that fire the spark plug using points, a coil, and a rotor and distributor cap; this setup has the battery and switch on an entirely different circuit than the spark plug (though coupled all transformer-like by fields in the coil), and yet for decades it was what people counted on to keep their spark plugs firing so their cars could run (though this was eventually replaced with electronic ignition, because microcontrollers and transistors can do a better job at timing ignition than a mechanic with a screwdriver and strobe fiddling with point and rotor angles).

The Magnetic field strength is related to the Current, the Amps, and although true fields go on for ever, in practical terms, Magnetic fields do not extend more than a few mm, that is less than an Inch. . . .   Electrical fields are related to the voltage in the wire, and generally do not extend more than a few mm or and Inch. . .  OK, those high voltage power lines carrying over 100,000 Volts of AC can be detected at about 10m or 30 feet away. But most practical uses of Fields around wires are in Motors, Generators and Transformers. . . I'm not so sure about the conclusion. Wouldn't it make more sense to put the load at one far end of the long wires, and the voltage source at the other? Electricity is in fact electrons flowing down a wire, not like water or marbles, but by jumping to the atoms next down the line. This is because a voltage potential exists in a circuit. Metals conduct electricity because of how freely they give and receive electrons. Magnetic fields are the result of current flowing, and magnetic fields can cause currents to flow, but don't confuse magnetic coupling as being the reason why electricity flows. Explain The Schottky diode, a semiconductor that only allows current to flow one way, and only when a certain minimum potential is reached. The transistor, The MOSFET, the JFET etc. these all work by forcing electrons to move a certain way. A plasma arc is electrons flowing between two electrodes when the voltage potential exceeds the resistance of the air gap. Ever seen what happens when a magnet is dropped down a metal tube? Even if the tube is aluminum or another non-magnetic metal, it falls slowly because its magnetic field is interacting with the electrons in the tube, inducing a magnetic field in the tube, creating resistance to the falling magnet. Current flows one way in a DC circuit, because the electrons move one way. DC circuits are not good for long distance transmission however because of this flow. The farther the electrons have to go, the more energy is lost due to resistance. Basically, the further the electrons have to go to balance out the potential, the less willing they are to do so. Because the electrons have to go all the way to the source and then come all the way back. With AC this is less of a problem, because the current keeps switching back and forth, and so the electrons only actually move a little way in one direction, and then the polarity reverses and they move the other way. Instead of going around and around, they just move forward and backward a little. This is why all transmission lines are AC, and DC is only used in small applications with short wire runs. The same electrons effectively just get yanked back and forth, rather than having to constantly move forward and get replaced with more. I say "the same" electrons loosely of course, an atom can gain one and lose another, so its many different electrons jumping from atom to atom, however the energy is transferred anyways. If what this video proposes is true, (Especially the animation showing the electric field going both ways in a DC circuit) then it wouldn't really matter if you used AC or DC for long range transmission. But it does matter, it matters a lot. Ask literally every developed nation's power grid.

One of the first things I paid attention was when we went from Maxwell equations to simplifying assumptions typical of electrical and electronic circuit design.  I saw them as simplifications of the Maxwell equations applied to particular circumstances that, as an engineer, you just want an answer that is "close enough" to the real thing to be useful. Those simplifying assumptions were thoroughly violated in the thought experiment with half light-second round-trip superconducting wire and then a light bulb a mere meter away from the switch.  But the correct treatment of such long wires as transmission lines and the fact that it's the electric field the main driver of energy (which it actually is) and, above all, that such circuit cannot be treated with the regular simplifying assumptions that we use, set this case straight.   Another example is by the founder of Cray Research, creating the fastest computers available back then, until he ran into frequencies in which their printed-circuit board connections started to behave like transmission lines, and all his brilliant design principles went down the drain. Be aware of a circuit physical parameters before deciding if simplifying assumptions can be applied, or else a 3-D field simulation is needed. Thank God, nowadays we have the computing power to tackle such problems.

I think that the explanation in this video is missing something and there is some dissonance whether this is a revolutionary discovery or a vague explanation of wireless power. I greatly appreciated the use of the oscilloscope showing the transient response. My opinion is that the difference between the transient and steady state response is key to the explanation, and calling both "the current" and "turning on" is probably causing more confusion.  I would propose a few more experiments:  1. If we put open switches on both sides of the battery and close them at the same time, what is the transient response? Does the lightbulb need to be initially "charged" by the positive end of the battery (and then cannot respond faster than the length of the wire divided by c)?  2. Keep the open switch on the negative side of the battery and insert a closed switch along the wire at the midpoint between the light and switch. If we activate the switches (open one, close the other) at the same time, will the built-up charge gradient at switch 1 emit the same electric field and cause the same transient response in the light bulb, but with no steady-state voltage because the circuit is never complete? The opening of switch 2 will certainly change the field of the wire, but it would take time to propagate and switch 1 would still see a gradient for the next few nanoseconds.  3. Is there a measurable difference in the transient response in the light/resistor (voltage, time constant, etc.) that depends on the length of the lines or continuity from battery to light/resistor? If yes, then by knowing about the battery, switch, and light within the 1-meter vicinity, we can discover information about the state of a far-away bit of wire faster than light.  4. Finally, can we induce the same charge gradient across the light bulb and switch without them being connected and see the amount of voltage/current in the light when the switch is closed?   Even without #4, I think 1-3 would illustrate that the power transfer is due to the meeting of the two gradients at the switch causing a field to propagate through the air to the light and nothing to do with FTL tomfoolery in the whole circuit. Information about the entire circuit still needs to travel at light speed over a long distance, and in this video that is achieved by having the battery connected initially.   Just my two-cents as a mechanical engineer with very basic circuits knowledge. I'm probably wrong in some parts of my understanding of this phenomenon, so please tear me apart. (E.g. I should probably say field instead of charge in a few spots.) I just think that analogies are very important to get right because then you can explain it to someone who doesn't have specialized schooling.

I feel like he moved the goalposts a bit, here. In the previous video, the insinuation was that "electricity doesn't flow on wires", and then a dive into the Poynting vector without much discussion about the _magnitude_ of energies delivered through EM waves outside of the wire versus inside. If you really think the majority of the energy isn't carried by the wires, put the bulb inside of a metal box (forming a Faraday cage which should prevent any EM waves from getting in) and run your wires through a tiny hole into the box to the bulb. The vast majority of EM wave power outside of the wires should be blocked, but the light will still light.  This video is a _great_ deep dive into transient EM effects on conductors at the microscopic level, but what he's _now_ describing is a radio transmitter with a dipole antenna transmitting a single pulse to a nearby receiver with a similar dipole antenna. You can snip the far ends of the loop (like he mentioned about the far end of the circuit being open) and the light may still light (depending upon the voltage of the battery, the impedance of the bulb, and how close the wires are to each other)... for a _moment_. But then, this is the phenomenon that Marconi discovered over 100 years ago, and it's, essentially, the method Nicola Tesla wanted to use to beam power all over the planet. The EM simulations of the wire _are_ very cool, but they're simulating the _transient_ response of the system, it's similar to why you hear buzzing on an AM radio next to a Tesla coil or near a car without resistor spark plugs. Simulate the system 1 second after closing the circuit, and you're not going to see those wave-fronts hitting the far wire and inducing a brief, damped wave in the wire.

My Junior year in EE, we learned about transmission lines and characteristic impedance. We also learned what happens when you apply a battery to a long XM line that has an open circuit at the far end. "A step voltage is launched along the line and a step current flows with it with magnitude V/Zo where Zo is the characteristic impedance of the line. But wait a minute? How can current flow into an open circuit? Current flows because the circuit hasn't "sensed" the open circuit on the far end yet. When the step voltage hits the open circuit, a negative current step is reflected back to the battery and the current flow from the battery drops to zero. Elapsed time? Twice the transit time between the battery and far end of the line. This was in 1964 at MIT. Since then, I've known that its the fields and Poynting vector, not the voltage and current, although working with V and I is a lot easier.
I hope that Electroboom and the others will make videos to recognize their mistake. But I doubt they will.

Hmm.This is a good video, and this time the author gets it right, and explains what actually happens in commendable detail.  But I need to mention a few backflips in this video in respect of his first video. Here he concedes that the bulb in his first video won‚Äôt actually light up in 1/C seconds, because the initial pulse of current is actually quite small, and not enough to light the bulb. He wiggles and squirms to try to avoid admitting he was wrong, for example by changing the bulb to a highly efficient Led bulb, but he more-or less admits what I and many others already knew, that the initial very fast pulse would not be large enough to light the bulb in the original video, and therefore his 1/C answer was wrong.  But from my reading of other comments, no one has noticed a more important backflip, in respect of the steady state behaviour of his DC circuit. In the first video, he and another professor pooh-pooh the idea that that it electrons that deliver the power and energy to the load. Oh no, we used to believe that too, they said, but now we realise that is completely wrong. You need to look at the Poynting vector, they said, which clearly shows that the power flows radially out from the battery, through empty space, and then converges to the load. And it is the electric and magnetic fields in that empty space that carry the energy to the load, as clearly shown by the Poynting vector. And this is indeed what the Poynting vector apparently implies.  But what a change we see in the steady-state explanation given in this video, which I‚Äôm sure he has taken from a textbook, where now he says clearly that it is ELECTRONS IN THE WIRES that deliver the energy to the load. Personally that is the way I look at it too, but what a change from his previous video. To quote verbatim from this video :-  ‚ÄúThe battery does continuous work to maintain the charge distribution, by moving electrons through the battery against the Coulomb force. (Correct) In the load, the electric field created by the surface charges accelerates the electrons, which dissipate their energy in collision with the lattice. (Correct) So the battery is putting energy into the field, which electrons take out and transfer to the load (Correct)‚Äù   OK. Enough of being critical. I do still think though that he would confuse fewer people if he made it quite clear when he is performing a transient analysis of his circuit, and when he is performing a steady state analysis.

Just to make my earlier post simpler and clearer as to what happens, and why Veritasium still hasn't got a correct understanding:  In his example of a battery powering a light bulb via two parallel conductors extending outwards from the battery and bulb, the bulb does not fully light after 1m/c seconds - a very short time.   The bulb gets a small energisation after 1m/c due to the characteristic impedance of the lines, and THEN, MUCH LATER, full energisation after the energy has stopped reverberating back and forth in the lines due to the end short circuits - a multiple of lv/c where l is the length of the lines in metres, and v is the impulse velocity set by the line's inductance and capacitance, this velocity is always much less than c in real set-ups.    He has not made this clear in this video, indeed it appears from his focusing on the initial small step he didn't understand it.   He just regurgitated what he read somewhere without having insight. Reflection occurs at the far ends because current is flowing in the end but there is no voltage drop, so the end must be imposing a voltage opposite to the voltage arriving from the battery.
He's a lot better in this video than he was in the first one - but he still says things that are wrong.   Getting roughly the right answer doesn't necessarily mean you have a full and correct understanding of the details.   Ordinary electrical tradesmen routinely apply Ohm's Law, though very very few could explain or derive it, just as anyone can competently drive a car without knowing engine thermodynamics. He's getting closer to understanding that in a DC or low frequency AC circuit the fields outside the wires have nothing to do with conveyance of energy from battery to bulb.  But he still said things like the current propagates at the speed of light.   No it doesn't, because any wire has inductance and capacitance to something, which he seems to have sort of appreciated later in the video. He's gone down a rabbit hole in saying that the electrons in a conductor are driven along by an internal field in a conductor, which is correct.  The internal field is possible because practical conductors have resistance.  But you can, with a bit of cooling, have a superconductor - there is no resistance and no internal field then.   But those electrons, having kinetic energy, still can convey energy from a source to a load, just the same - if the source is a DC source (and in practice  a low frequency AC source).    He's glossed over that the rise on voltage across his resistor was not just a simple step to the final (steady state) value - there was a an early small step due to the parallel line's characteristic impedance that he seems to have focused on.   Actually, there will be a series of steps converging on the final full voltage, due to energy reflected at the short circuits at the ends of his two transmission lines, so a packet of energy goes back and forth until losses absorb it - its just that his experimental method does not resolve all the steps. He goes on about wireless charging of battery powered devices - but this has absolutely nothing to do with whether of not energy in a simple circuit is conveyed by the electrons or not, it is merely an example of a specialised power transformer.   Current (which MUST be AC) forced to flow in one winding sets up an oscillating magnetic field inducing a voltage in another winding. Here is a thought experiment for you:   Imagine a vacuum, and inside it a hot cathode, which emits electrons in all directions (thermionic emission), as electrons in a conductor have an average speed that increases with temperature, but with a statistical distribution of speed, so some of the faster electrons have enough kinetic energy to escape the positive electric field from the atom nuclei.  Once these electrons escape, they keep on going.  Now, imagine a sphere nearby with a small hole in it,  surrounding the cathode.  Electrons that happen by chance to to leave the cathode in the direction of the hole pass right through it.   Connect the plate via a return wire to the cathode, otherwise other electrons hitting the sphere will build up a charge on it.   Now, back to the electrons passing through the hole.  They are now not subject to any applied electric field, but they will keep on going, as they have mass and inertia.   Does this flow of electrons constitute a current?    Yep, it sure does.   Can it deliver energy to a remote conductor?   Yep - it sure can.  Even if the mean distance between electrons is sufficient to make inter-electron electric field interaction negligible.    Because each electron carries a little bit of kinetic energy (obtained from the heat applied to the cathode in this case), as it has mass and velocity.
Something seems not right: electrons in any wire are milling around at 1,000,000 m/s, bumping into atoms, but not heating the wire. Enter an electric current, the electrons start to move at 1,000,000.0001 m/s and hey, presto! the wire gets red hot.

The problem with this approach is this only works within a very specific scenario.  Using the example of the gentleman talking about the PCB's, electromagnetic waves come into play far more because you have a significant amount of direct soldered aluminum or copper, not what a typical person defines as a wire.  When you define a wire, most people are going to think of a coax cable, an ethernet cable, a USB cable, or the wiring that's within their houses.  Let's use the wiring in your house for an example, these are shielded wires that are used to restrict the "bleed" of energy being lost into the electromagnetic fields, this is to create a point to point connection, and usually contains two wires in that series to create a circuit, one with positive flow one with negative flow.  The scenario that you're building would be similar to energy generation through the spark effect, where the energy freeflows but loses energy quickly.  Sure, if you create a big enough "spark", it will power the lightbulb but it will be at the loss and inefficiency of energy that's being distributed in a 3D space in every other direction.  This is compared to a PCB, and the best way to think of this is to look at the motherboard on your computer.  That's chalk full of resistors and capacitors, to bleed energy into specific segmentations of the board itself.  Eletromagnetic fields are also unstable, and because of millions of different reasons will not always provide the same level of energy bleed out be it through another thing in it's way that absorbs it, air pressure itself, or the elements within the air will change it.  I've seen a few people bring up how AM/FM radio's work, that's frequency and not directly electromagnetic fields.  You guys have the right idea, but it's a different technology.  It's not that we've been "lied to" about how electricity actually works, it's that we've modernized it in such a way that we contain it to minimize the loss of efficiency when sending electricity.  To answer the original posted question of how long would it take.  The response is in an unshielded wire your calculation is correct, but with the raw amount of power needed to do that the lightbulb would explode after the speed of light traveled through the wire and the voltage "push" overwhelmed the lightbulb itself.  If it was shielded, it would take the speed of light to travel the wire, and cost a fraction of the amount of overall energy.

While you (theoretically) is correct, you forget one important parameter, and that is conductivity.  While the bulb (very theoretically) will "turn on" switch_bulb_distance/c after you flip the switch, it will be with infinitely dim because of the very low conductivity of electromagnetic waves through air. That is why the wire is needed. The wire has very high conductivity, and will conduct the electromagnetic waves through it, at a rate infinitely higher that the amount conducted through air.   So, the real answer is. You will be able to tell the switch was flipped after switch_bulb_distance/c, but the bulb will only turn on after cable_length/c.

Derek is correct, but here is another way to view it. The key is capacitance and the fact that the battery and switch are 1 meter from the load. You have to think of this long pair of wires as a transmission line, such as a twin-lead. With the switch open, the charge on both sides of the load and everywhere in the wire are the same, assuming enough time elapsed to achieve equilibrium and there are no outside charges influencing it. The top and bottom wires have an infinite number of infinitely small capacitors all along the length of the "transmission line" which are initially zero charge on both sides of the load.  Once the switch is closed, one side of the wire at the switch suddenly becomes a different charge than the wire across from it at the load. The "capacitors" on only that side of the load starts charging which causes a current through the load as soon as the electric field reaches across the 1 meter distance. Actually, both sides of the load may differ as one goes more positive and the other goes more negative but the result is the same current. Now imagine that you have a twin-lead line that is infinitely long and open on both ends. If you apply a DC voltage to one end, you will get a constant current that will last forever as if the line was a resistor equal to the line's impedance. This is due to the infinite number of capacitors between the conductors charging one by one forever. If you make the spacing smaller, the capacitance goes up and the impedance goes down and the current goes up. I am an electrical engineer with a BS in physics and I have found that the views are different. Derek explained the same concept in physics terms and I explained the engineering view, but they are both saying the same thing.

The fields are strongest near the charges, which are the sources of those fields. We can make power flow from power stations precisely to millions of homes because the network of wires guides that power. It is infeasible to target the energy on such a scale wirelessly--not merely "less efficient," but practically impossible. Even on a smaller scale, we manage the electron flow to direct power. That's why switches really do control the lights they are wired to, and not everything in the vicinity. The video's insistence on the primacy of the fields obscures the differences between wired and wireless transmission, and the conditions when managing the electrons is important. That failure of clarity is why there are so many puzzled questions about his silly experiment.

I think Vertasium is wrong and here's my evidence: Suppose you have a copper tube with both ends closed (that means the tube will float if you throw it in water). Now take a hack saw and cut it in half. Good. Now take a resistive element and glue it to the part of the tube you've just cut, and re-assemble.  You now have a closed tube with a resistive element of 1k Ohm sandwiched halfway between the tube (the resistive element is 1mm thick). Now open the tube again and solder a Cu wire from one end of the tube to the other. Good. Now add a switch and a 18V battery to the middle of this wire, and again close the tube.       We now have a closed tube with the following properties: 1. It has a wire running the length of the tube. 2. There is a resistor of 1K separating the two halves of the tube. 3. In the middle of our wire (not seen because it's inside the closed tube) there is a switch that's electrically connected to the wire, as well as a battery right next to this switch, such that by closing the switch we'll get current flow through the wire from the battery.  Now here is where we demonstrate Veritasium's folly.  I'm suggesting that we extend the length of the tube to be some fraction of a light-second. How about the tube becomes 300 meters in length? Furthermore, the radius of the tube becomes exactly 1 meter. This means the wire is obviously 1 meter away from the insides of the tube, giving plenty of room for the switch and battery to do their respective jobs. Again, you can't see the switch, battery, or wire, because they're all inside the tube. You're just seeing one honkin' copper tube with a resistor (c=2œÄ ‚Ä¢ r) in the middle of the tube, like it's a gasket or some shi... Now IF VERTASIUM IS CORRECT, we should expect to see exactly 18Vdc appear anywhere along the tube, right next to our resistor, once we close the switch (using telepathy, string, idgaf what is used to throw the switch). That's right: in this video Vertasium got about 4 volts of instant voltage from his 18 volts, but in my experiment, we should see ALL 18 VOLTS appear instantly. Again, only if Vertasium is correct. Expand the idea so that the tube is two light-seconds across. If Vertasium is correct, we should see the 18 volts not after C or a fraction of C, but rather nearly instantaneously (the tube is a meter in diameter. How long does it take light to travel 1/2 of that diameter? 1.6E9 of a second? Instantly, for all practical purposes. Therefore, according to Vertasium, we really do have true Spooky Action at a Distance. Einstein, the dear professor, must be turning in his grave by now.

Very nice, this nails down all of the questions I had after the first video...but it does introduce two more:  1. Surely, in the case of a break in the wire 150,000km away, the bulb doesn't _stay_ on. I assume it would light dimly for 0.5s, then _go out_ instead of getting brighter? Using the transmission line analogy, it would be lit while the capacitors charge, then go out when they're done and no direct current path is available. 2. What happens if the switch interrupts _both_ lines immediately as they exit the battery terminals, not just one, so that when the switch is off the entire loop is electrically isolated from the battery? This reduces I think to two questions:    a. Does the surface-charge effect spread at c _along the wire_ , or does that also propagate at c along the shortest path through open space? My guess is it's constrained to the wire, and as such when the _first_ terminal of the battery is connected to the loop in the original scenario, it takes nearly _two_ full seconds for the surface charge to settle. Is this correct?    b. If I'm right about (a), does this prevent the electric field from inducing a current across the 1m gap and thus mean it takes the full second for the bulb to come on? I'm going to much more tentatively say it does _not_ , that the absolute values of the electric field will differ in this case but the _relative_ values, and thus the potential difference across the bulb, will be the same, and so the bulb will still light almost immediately. Or, using the transmission line analogy, if those capacitors were physically present, certainly the bulb would light immediately even with the switch interrupting both wires...

The presentations contain a lot of interesting detail, all correct as far as I can tell, but this razzle-dazzle of data serves only to distract from the important ideas about not just electricity, but how physics problems in general are approached and solved.   Transmission by wires and transmission through space are related at a fundamental level, and that is good to know. But, there are enough differences between the two scenarios that it may be easier and more transparent to focus on different parts of each system in our analysis.   In energy transmission by wires, the focus is on the charges: where they are, where they move, what propels them. They‚Äôre what we control and manage. The second video shows just how complicated their behavior is! Step back, however, and the story is clear: After the battery separates charges, doing work on them, those charges and others in the two wires rearrange themselves under their own mutual repulsion. (Pause here to reiterate the ‚Äúand others.‚Äù The original charges don‚Äôt need to go all the way down the wires, just their collective push.) As a result the opposite ends of the wires now also have a supply of separated charges, and energy can be recovered by letting them ‚Äúfall‚Äù to each other.   What is wrong with that account? Not only does it tie electricity to charge motion, it also explains what primarily drives those charges, Coulomb repulsion. And, it explains exactly the form in which energy is delivered: a supply of separated charges, kind of a ‚Äúfuel,‚Äù like gas in the tank.   For transmission through empty space where there aren‚Äôt charges, such as with light beams or radio broadcasts, there is nothing around but the fields. So the description focuses on them, what controls their configuration, and how they can carry energy. We‚Äôre firmly stuck dealing with Maxwell‚Äôs equations. There‚Äôs no place else to assign the energy but the fields.   It is correct that the field view must also apply to the electricity case, and that the Poynting vector can be used to calculate the energy flow, and that calculating from charge configuration and motion must give the same answer. But since you can also deduce everything by just looking at the charges, the field view is not so helpful in the case of wires.   Different problems, different formulations.

I think what you are describing are two separate phenomena. In the DC case it is the step change that results in EM waves being launched across the gap between the switch and load. Once the step change has finished, there are no EM waves (apart from those transients caused by reflections in the wires and surrounding environment), so in the steady state the energy dispated in the load is due to electrons responding to the static E field interacting with the lattice. The same induction effect will be present when the switch is opened causing transient EM waves. Transformers don't work with DC in the steady state - car ignition systems work on the principle of pulsed DC causing growing and collapsing fields in the coil. The HT leads are screened to prevent EM waves escaping and causing interference.  In the AC case the field is oscillating at the frequency of the generator, so there will be an ongoing induction effect across the air gap to the load in addition to an EM wave that travels along the axis of the wires causing energy transfer via electrons and the lattice in the load.   Coax cables are designed such that the EM wave doesn't escape into free space, if they did then energy would be lost to free space.  In all cases, photons (or if you prefer, EM waves) are absorbed causing electrons to increase energy levels, and electrons decrease energy levels causing photon to be emitted - this is how the energy is actually transferred. LEDs work on this principle as do filament bulbs, LEDs are just more efficient at emitting photons of a well defined frequency whereas filament bulbs waste energy by emitting photons over a wide bandwidth covering infrared and visible light. You left out something essential in your argument that electrons don‚Äôt push eachother along because the nuclei of the conductor cancel out their mutual repulsion:  If one end of the wire is connected to a charged source of concentrated electrons, then those electrons will be forced down  the wire by THEIR mutual repulsion, because there is an actual net charge in that origin location. Those electrons are an excess over and above the atomic electrons that ‚Äúbelong‚Äù in the conductor, and therefore their mutual repulsion with eachother and with the conductor‚Äôs atomic electrons will force a current. The most apt analogy in this case is perhaps not marbles in a tube, but a compressed air cylinder attached to a rubber hose. The air in the hose will not flow when the valve is shut off, because it is in an equilibrium not unlike the balanced charges in a disconnected wire, but when you open the valve, suddenly there‚Äôs more air at the cylinder end of the hose than the open end, and that air will spread out by pushing all of the air in front of it out of the way until it shoots out of the open end. To turn this pneumatic setup into a circuit, all we have to do is connect the open end of the rubber hose to the intake side of the air compressor that supplies the cylinder, and the suction on that side will create a ‚Äúpositive charge‚Äù which is devoid of air just like the positive side of a battery, which renders itself deficient in electrons.

Well, it's a little controversial, because in maxwell's equations, especifically the fourth, he introduce the concept of displacement current, refers a flow of energy due a variation in electric and magnetic field in a capacitor (this concept was introduced for completing the amper's law called amper-maxwell equation). It means, in a simple circuit like show in the video, if you introduce in series a capacitor, the flow of energy continuous but it depends on if the source is a direct o alternating current. What is that means? the flow of energy occurs if the magnetic and electric fields are variables, for that reason, there are not electrons moving around the circuit (that model tells you, the electrons don't jump from one plate to another). the same happens, in transformers, variables magnetic field induced variables electric fields and then a current appear (maxwell's third law). Let's talk about potential and kinetic energy (the misconception mentioned in the video), How do we can transfer energy  over long distances? the trick is to increase the voltage and decrease the current, because with currents the losses are high, what is that means? that is, we must reduce the amount of electrons moving to the load, increasing the potential energy of the system (electric field). at the end of the transmissions lines (Low Voltage) we use transformers (step down) for increasing the kinetic energy and decrease the potential energy; so the energy reaches the load.   Another concept that are not mentioned are the reactive energy, active and complex power. They are so important for understanding the principles of electricity... Then we conclude that the transfer of energy is carried out by the conductor

I previously commented about this video (2 days ago), saying is wasn‚Äôt wrong to say that electrons push each other (that is, they repel each other by exerting force at a distance), rather than saying that the electrons produce a field that accelerates other electrons. Basically these are equivalent.  After reflection, I would like to make an even stronger statement that at an introductory level repulsion may be the better choice, because it creates exactly the right intuition very economically. The most important thing that happens in a battery-powered circuit is that the battery does work on the charges, separating them, and creating an excess of electrons at one battery pole and a deficit at the other. This energy can be recovered by letting the positive and negative charges fall back together. If instead of letting them fall, a conductive wire is connected to the negative pole, the extra electrons purely under their own mutual repulsion, will advance into the wire, spreading themselves as evenly as they can along its length. A similar process applies to a wire attached to the positive pole. As a result, charges are also separated at the remote end of the wire, so energy can be extracted there by letting electrons fall across the gap at that end, too. (It is important for the teacher to also add that electrons are interchangeable, so the ones that go in at the battery end are not the same as the ones that fall at the distant end.)  I suggest that this view that things that repel each naturally spreading out is very intuitive, that it is easy to imagine them all running away from each other. I‚Äôd be interesting on people‚Äôs thoughts about this.  If the electric field is introduced instead, then it is less immediately obvious why this diffusion occurs, because it isn‚Äôt initially clear where this new field points. You have to explain that the field always points so that like charges experience a force that separates them, and opposite charges are drawn together. That is, the field implements repulsion and attraction between charges. But then you‚Äôre back at the force-at-a-distance view, with little gained pedagogically. You essentially break the straightforward image of spreading, and then reconstruct it under a different guise.  As an extra benefit, the repulsion idea also explains schematically why excess charges are on the outer edge of the wire, because once again they are spreading out as much as they can.  Thoughts?

First thing, Veritasium's videos are great!  They inspire deep learning and fun experimentation!  However, just like the video about gravity and force, sometimes the messages tend to dismiss "old" concepts as incorrect just because something new is learned which seems more profound.  But It is unnecessary to dismiss the "old" view of electrons and currents in a circuit just because we also discover that radiation and fields play an important role.  And I don't mean this merely due to the practical use, I mean as part of the fundamental explanation.  The flow of electrons is still key to explaining and understanding a circuit.  I could go on and on about various details, but instead I'll cut to chase.  The radiated field apparently plays an important role in the circuit, although one must then ask the most crucial follow-up question:  What generates the necessary electric field which the video claims is the "more fundamental" element here?   The direct answer is the charged particles, the electrons.  Although the video does indeed point out that the electrons arrange themselves to establish the necessary fields in the wire, the treatment of the electrons thereafter is set aside for a preference of "the field".  However, as the electrons begin to drift, the only way for the field to maintain its necessary configuration is for the electrons to also continuously shift and move to maintain that field.  Guess what?  That also requires energy!  Energy can also be stored in the charged particle configuration!  In other words, if the "energy is in the field", that energy would quickly dissipate and the field alone could not power the circuit unless the charges continuously rearranged themselves to maintain that field throughout the circuit.  The field would not exist, or at least the necessary field to do continuous work would not be maintained without the flow of electronics, the current.  Thus the current remains just as fundamental a part of the circuit as the field.  Like so many other concepts in physics that are first explained in isolated, pure environments--think about frictionless surfaces and "no air resistance"--when teaching basics of kinematics, as we add more detail and learn how to contemplate more complex examples, we don't necessarily need to drop the old while we grasp the new concepts as "more fundamental".  What if we wrapped the wires in radiation absorbing/attenuating shields... how would that affect the outcome?  Would making such an equivalent "no radiative field" scenario contradict the classic concept of current in the wire?  No.  It could however prevent the lightbulb from behaving as it did in the experiment.  Rather the new knowledge needs to be  incorporated into a more complete and mature understanding.  It is incorrect to say that "all the energy is in the field" when the configuration of the entire circuit system is necessary for the light to continue working as part of the circuit.  Just like when dealing with gravity where both potential and kinetic energy must be included in the same equation, in a circuit we need to include both the energy in the fields and the potential energy of the charged particle configuration.
Regarding several comments about Nikola Tesla and through-the-air power transmission, I‚Äôd say that yes, it can be done, but there are important drawbacks. The thing with wires is that they can precisely direct energy to a huge number of targets like people's homes and even the individual outlets within a home. ‚ÄúBeaming‚Äù the power instead could potentially zap something in line-of-sight between the generator and the appliance, if that thing inadvertently had electrical characteristics that intercepted the power. Or, if the aim were a little off from miles away it might toast your neighbors instead of running your dryer. In conventional transmission the energy flow outside and along wires is largely confined to stay around and between them. To anticipate an objection, yes, the field extends to infinity; but the bulk of the power is channeled near the charge flow.  So although power can be transmitted wirelessly through space by the fields, and sometimes even aimed very accurately, controlling its distribution throughout an irregular network of consumers would be very difficult without using wires to guide it. The wires are not just an inconvenience, they and their contained charges are what makes sure the power goes to the right place.  And those charges are an essential part of the aiming. Consider, why do we protect ourselves by putting non-conductive plastic insulation around wires? Plastic doesn't stop the electric and magnetic fields, but it does stop electrons. We do this because we manage the fields indirectly by wrangling the electrons, and if we keep the charges from escaping the wire we keep the energy where we want it.

When teaching a subject, there‚Äôs always a question of how deep into the details you need to go. This video and the previous one, along with related readings, make very clear that to describe electrical flow a lot of details are needed to be absolutely, thoroughly correct. How much time should be devoted to being perfect, rather than being good enough and getting on to more topics? You don‚Äôt want to give the students wrong notions that they will have to unlearn later, but also you don‚Äôt want to get bogged down forever in minutiae.  With this in mind, how wrong is it to say that electrons push each other through the wire? They are driven by the aggregate push of regions of excess charge, even if the full arrangement is more complex than one might think at first. From the perspective of an electron in the wire, there is a higher density of other negative charges behind it compared with in front of it (and the reverse for positive)‚Äîthe surface charge gradient described in the video, slightly off axis but still generally fore and aft. The aggregate, net force on the electron propels it in the right direction. Their dance is not as simple as a conga line, it‚Äôs more like an elaborate ballet. But if focusing on attraction/repulsion leverages students‚Äô prior experience with forces in mechanics, why not take advantage of that? Individual teachers may choose differently on exactly which details to include or skip, but in general the ‚Äúpush‚Äù picture is not wrong.

As a physicist I find this video more confusing than clarifying.  There was a confusion between what is an antenna and a light bulb. It would be better to just admit the mistake than go through such a confusing (and unnecessary) argumentation.  -The small and fast signal you see in the oscilloscope (19:00) is governed by Electromagnetic waves. -The large and slow signal is governed by circuit physics (Ohm's law).
One of the difficulties in working towards a higher level of understanding of what is happening in a circuit is the limitations of our models. We know the simple model of the atoms as a spherical positive nucleus and small round electrons is inadequate, yet it is used because it illustrates some aspects nicely. We know a quantum mechanical view of the atom would be more accurate, but it makes the visualization quite difficult. Kirchhoff‚Äôs rules work quite well to analyze most circuits, and they do not attempt to model what is actually happening with electrons and E fields. A model can never explain everything about the real system. It seems to me the underlying issue is how accurate we want to make our model.

After digesting this for a bit, I've settled on the idea that the electrons are a thin interface between the fields and the energy source/sink. The chemically-forced movement of electrons against the E field in the battery moves energy into the fields, and the tendency of electrons to vibrate nuclei in the resistive load provides a means for them to transmit the energy from the fields into heat. In both cases, though, the electrons themselves carry almost none of the energy at any time. They are dragged around by the fields and whatever the source or sink of energy is, like a piece of paper in between a heavy pushing object and another being pushed by it.  One illuminating thought experiment along these lines is to consider the value of the poynting vector inside the conductor. It's near zero because the electric fields are small compared to outside, but what power flow there is actually points *into* the wire, not along it. Energy from the fields is entering the wire to be converted into heat due to the wire's resistance, but the power flow along the wire is all outside. Really the only power flow that's actually inside the wire is the (non-thermal) kinetic energy of the electrons, which is minuscule, both because the drift velocity is quite low, and because electrons weigh almost nothing. That minuscule amount of energy is the transfer medium all the power goes through when interfacing with some other physical system, but carries basically no energy itself.
What is your next falicy, underwater radio communications?  Electromagnetic fields do not travel through water. whereas electricity will travel via conductors under water.
This is nothing more than measuring CROSS-TALK between two parallel conductors, that happens for a few nanoseconds.  So what?  This has been known for decades.  And NO, this cross-talk will *NOT* power the LOAD you described in the original video.

Fields don't come from nothing, and they cost energy, so where do they come from, if not electron flow? Also, electrons can't flow through a battery because the positive side is atoms stripped of electrons so any free electrons will be captured by a stripped atom until it is electrically neutral again. That is how a battery 'runs down'. The negative side has a limited supply of excess electrons which push the electrons in the wire around to the positive side. This continues until the positive side is neutral, or the negative side runs out of free electrons.  The various paths taken are controlled by the physical restrictions imposed by each path, not guided by a field because the field is the result of electron flow, not the cause of it, like cars in a traffic jam at a junction, some turns flow faster than others because there is less restriction.  The maxwell simulation is false because the strength of the fields is far, far less than those depicted. A 12v battery will not spark 1 metre with significant force. You can simulate anything, it doesn't mean its true.  PCBs have metal strips that are less than 1mm apart carrying varying current at high frequencies without 'cross-talk'. And similar strips must be the same length in micro-metres or the signals will not arrive at the same time, showing the speed is not connect to light speed, but the material and length.  And no, so far there is no evidence of any field, no iron filings aligning into a direction or shape, compass needle, or magnet moving. No real evidence of any field whatsoever. The oscilloscope itself was not connected to any field because it doesn't measure fields.  And, you didn't do the same experiment with the wires isolated from each other, so we can't confirm what path the electricity is taking, either in the wire or outside.  Are there electromagnetic fields? Yes. Do they cause electricity to flow? No. They translate energy from motion to field and back again, which is why transformers pass alternating current between isolated circuits, but not direct current.  So the experiment does not prove the simulations, and, the conclusion cannot be that fields exist and cause electricity. You need another experiment to prove fields exist outside the wire and they appear ahead of the current flow, before your hypothesis has any merit.
What consequence does this have on Alternating Current? Should we then rethink how we wire our homes for better efficiency? Or better yet, how we transmit power over long distance?

In a way this kind of shows that when we learn science, and we start by learning the "high level models" it makes things *harder* to understand in the long term. It really IS better to learn the lowest level stuff first, so you have something to build on, and you understand what is really going on, BEFORE you learn a lumped element as a shortcut. I don't know what it would take to change education to work that way instead. I feel the same way about math. It isn't until you get into Calculus classes that you learn what's behind all the simple equations to calculate volume and area. Yes they are handy shortcuts but they can lead a "smart" person, a person that knows them, to still make false conclusions! Because it's not really what is going on!  I really think education needs to find a way to reverse how we teach things, start at the lowest level and build UP instead of how we teach right now. It would help students to know WHY something works a certain way. It's my opinion we need an education revolution to switch the order of how we learn.  All of these electricity misconceptions are solved by Maxwells equations and if you have knowledge of RF electronics you will understand how it works and why. Something you aren't going to learn until you get into your later years.  Mind you I am not saying get rid of lumped elements, what I mean is a student should not learn the lumped elements at all until first learning the foundations under them. Right now we learn the other way around.   I have spent a large amount of my life simply trying to decode the lower level stuff that was never taught until you get into higher and higher classes. Personally I think this is a disservice to science and learning, that we don't share the full picture RIGHT AWAY with students. *Start at the bottom and work your way up* . Because we don't do that, this is how the misconceptions start, and in fact it makes subjects *harder* for students because it hides something from them, causing confusion.

12:29 It is misleading to visualize the B-field magnitude here, because it has nothing to do with the generation of current in the top wire. If you visualized dB/dt instead of B, it would present a much sharper wave, and it would be much more apparent that the changing magnetic field induces current in the top wire. Also, it's difficult to tell how big dB/dt is from the simulation because of low sensitivity (B-field magnitude per color intensity) at the front of the wave.  You're quite explicit in saying it's the electric field that causes current to flow in the load, but with electromagnetic waves, it's not just one or the other. In the near EM field in particular, you have electromagnetic and electrostatic induction. I'm no expert, but per my intuition at least, B-fields dominate energy transfer in an application like transformers, and E-fields dominate in a tesla coil. It's not clear cut. In the far EM field where the emitting particles are so far from the receiver that there are no feedback effects, the E and B field strengths are proportional, so I guess the dominant contributor depends on the shape and direction of the antenna (?)

Seeing the original video, then all of the debating responses, and then this follow-up video makes me so happy, because THIS is science.   Science isn't someone doing an experiment and delivering their results. Science is the discussion between different people and different minds, especially with differing levels of exposure in a particular topic (let alone a whole field), that pushes and pulls the information we know AND the way we communicate it to each other into clearer focus. And seeing this process that is so often hidden deep in the world of academic journals and peer reviews (which are the bread and butter of scientific discovery--don't get me wrong) brought into a much more public and easily viewed frame gives me so much hope and confidence in how our current model of video-based science education and discussion on platforms like YouTube will affect human knowledge into the future. The discussion of the surface charges and flow of power is fascinating and not very well known.  Thanks for presenting it. However,  the question can be answered a lot simpler by using the better-known concept of crosstalk.   Designers of printed circuit boards, ICs, and cables know extremely well the problem with crosstalk between a signal-carrying wire and adjacent wires.  If you send a 1V pulse, typically a smaller pulse will show up on adjacent wires. You can show this on a PCB by sending a 1V pulse and see the crosstalk pulse on the adjacent wire. There was no need to construct large-scale models, although it might have been fun.   This is what is happening in his experiment. It is not necessary to talk about light bulbs. There is the signal you send to do whatever job you want to accomplish and then there is crosstalk in adjacent wires that will be smaller depending on exact geometry and configuration. The crosstalk is not the signal you send with the intention of doing the job which in this case was turning on the light bulb.
In the first video there was not a clear line between steady state and transient period. This video now makes it clear that in the transient state the load will receive a small amount of power from the fields until the steady state takes place and provides full power while the power provided by transient goes away

And because electrons are so indistinguishable from one another is actually why electronic communications even work to begin with. Think of a bunch of identical balls inside a tube filling it up from one end to the other, if I push another ball into one end, a ball on the other end will be pushed out almost instantly regardless of the length of the tube. But when the tube gets too long it will take a lot of force to get the one on the other end to push out, and that is sort of why electricity can only go so far on a single stretch of wire before needing a "repeater" to push it further. Another way of thinking about this that might be more intuitive for some people:  Immediately after you close the switch, you have a changing current in the wire extending out of the battery. A wire with a changing current functions as an antenna and transmits some power. The section of wire with the light bulb also functions as an antenna and receives the power.

You should have left the characteristic impedance piece out of it, as Z0 does not come into play for what you were doing and time frame you were interested in. Matching  load impedance with Z0 maximizes power transfer because it minimises wave reflection at the load interface. This implies that impedance matching does not have an influence on the power transfer since the initial power transfer is via capacitive coupling, during which the travelling wave is yet to arrive at the load interface.
When we explain or understand AM/FM radio stations, we imagine a giant coil oscillating in the radio station. It emits waves. The electrons in the antenna vibrate in synch. And we pick up the signal. We never think about return current, completion of circuit etc. So we had the basics to understand this. But because we were given a short hand simplistic model of circuits and currents flowing through wires, it is difficult to unlearn that short hand and understand the wave propagation.
I grew up in deep rural South India. Telegraph was in serious use there and my was a trained telegraphist who can use Morse code. They were using single-wire-telegraphy and my questions about "how is the circuit completed? Where is the return current?" could not be answered well by my dad, nor my high school teachers. The maintenance supervisor said, "The Earth is the return path, the circuit is completed through Earth". It was good enough for a school boy. But now, when you look at the induced current on the open loop wire you understand how the single wire telephony worked. You dont need a return current. It does not matter whether the loop is open or closed. All the elaborate earthing done to the instruments by that maintenance supervisor is basically reducing the line impedance! Now I have a much better understanding of how the single wire telegraphy worked.

Thanks Derek for the concise explanation. The capacitor shorting at t=0 @16:54 is not really a good way to understand it because u can always add a lumped inductance just right next to the bulb and inductance at t=0 is open circuit so the circuit is not complete.
What you have been eluding to is what we traditionally call capacitive coupling. Given there is no shielding between the parallel conductors, you will detect some voltage at the load terminals pretty fast. However, the full voltage will be detected at the load terminals  after a delay based on the loop distance of the conductor and the velocity of the travelling wave on this conductor. The velocity can be calculated as SQRT(1/LC).which is always reasonably lower than the speed of light.

Well no, I agree that energy can be said to be carried by the field, but in your previous video you were suggesting that the lamp would reach its final state quicker because the field has a small distance to travel. But this isn't the final state, this is just capacitive coupling. If the circuit is open somewhere, this capacitive coupling will switch the light on to a very low power and then it will quicky switch off again, so it's not the final state of the lamp. And worse, if you build loop of wire before wires go back to the lamp you can make the charges flow the opposite direction in the lamp during that transient supply of power, and if it's an LED it will not turn on at this point. So that transient power supply to the lamp has nothing to do with the final state of the lamp. It can even be opposite or it can be zero depending how you set the wires and it has nothing to do with the lamp being close to the battery so that the pointing vector can reach it quicker, already with its final value. Electricity is all about the flow of electrons in a conductor which is called current. That's the way transistors and capacitors work. It is not exactly rocket science and fairly easy to understand. If I use a water pipe filled up with marbles (the pipe resembles a conductor and the marbles resemble the electrons in the conductor), then whenever you push 10 marbles into the pipe, 10 marbles will INSTANTANEOUSLY come out on the other end of the pipe. That explains why an electrical switch works instantaneously when electrons starts to flow 2000km away at the source. In an alternate current (AC), many electrons will never exit the conductor because it will just shunt up and down the 2000km long conductor.
4:45 - not quite, I'm afraid, or at least not clear.  Whatever small the speed along the wire, it exists. And it means that there are SOME electrons traversing net along the wire. So, occasionally, an electron crosses the boundary of your selected area, in or out (it's best to imagine it as a thin layer of the wire limited by two cross sections, as that way you can disregard the movements perpendicular to the wire axis). And that causes a momentarily unbalanced charge which repulses (or attracts) another electron from out of your box to maintain a neutral charge. The same goes for the thermal electrons as well, of course, but as it was mentioned they traverse in random directions, so their movements cancel out anyway.

I can't believe so many people have forgotten about a device we have had not only since nearly the very beginning of the use of electricity, but also something so prevalent across all country's power grids. The input and output of a transformer are not connected at all except by an electromagnetic field. When you have a coil of wire it creates a larger electromagnetic field as well around it, and when the power on the circuit collapses that field collapse creates a huge voltage spike as it transfers all that stored energy back through the circuit. These are some pretty basic things, and I find it strange that so few seem to know them.
This concept is why one individual got sued by a power company and lost.  He had setup field collectors under power transmission wires and was powering his HOUSE without being connected to the grid physically at all.  He lost because the power company proved that the field was where the energy was flowing and not the wires themselves.  This is the basis to starting antenna propagation theory.  You pretty much have to understand this to even attempt to understand antenna propagation because it's basically extending the field until the energy breaks loose from the field and floats free. Something we do in the USAF‚Ä¶ check for ‚Äústray voltage‚Äù. We do that after a functional check of an electrical circuit, that we will be inserting an explosive charge, or IMPULSE CART. About the size and shape of a 10 gauge shotgun shell, roughly. Some bigger some smaller, but they all do the same thing. Voltage was always there, when power was on the aircraft. We discovered nuisance voltage. Still framing it wrong.  It's not about seeing voltage and current.  Or even seeing voltage and current "many orders of magnitude greater than leakage current" or "yes, it will emit light...if you use an LED [and don't discriminate between 'emit light' and 'emit its normal/rated quantity of light']".   If you want to make a nontrivial claim, it would be that you'll see peak/stable voltage and current at time=1/c seconds, and/or "yes, it will emit as much light as your bulb will normally produce when on".  Anything short of that and you're basically just taking the concept of EMI and making it way more confusing than it has any right to be.  Propagation of the electrical signal along the wire creates an electromagnetic field orthogonal to the wire, which induces a small (as in, "far more than leakage but far less than peak") sympathetic current through the load; and that's no big deal.  So I guess...make the nontrivial claim, or don't pretend like the original claim was correct in the way that people were invited to interpret it.

In an open circuit, no matter how long or short the wire is or the distance between the switch and the bulb, the electromagnetic field doesn't flow unless you're working with huge voltages and small interruptions of the wire, then the circuit will be closed by an electrical arc. The time difference between closing the switch and lightning the bulb is almost instant because the field could be compared with a rope with no elasticity. When you draw one end of the rope, the force would be transmitted almost instantly to the other end.

This perfectly demonstrates Charles Steinmetz's description of how electricity works. You can see on the oscilloscope the bump in voltage continues for the same amount of time after the rest of the current reaches the resistor. For that time, the voltage across the resistor was raised by that initial voltage. This illustrates a displacement current from the change of dielectric field created by the switch. There are actually three different kinds of current: Electric Current (current that flows in conductors), Magnetic Current (current that flows in ferrous materials) and Displacement current (current that flows in insulators). In order for an electric current to flow, both magnetic and electric fields must be together and in the correct phase. An electric current is capable of delivering power to a load (capable of doing work). You can induce and electric current via magnetic or dielectric fields but those fields cannot directly do work on a load unless converted into either an electric current or mechanical motion first. That's why wires are used for circuits because it keeps both the magnetic and dielectric fields around the wire where you want them.

20:19 is an essence of this video, and this graph was not properly explained. Yes, we reach 4.8V level after some time, but how long did it take? At the bottom row, you can see that each big square is 50 ns. And the trigger (orange triangle at the top of the graph) starts at 133.44 ns. So, it is around 30 ns to reach 4.8V. Within this time, light makes 10 meters, not one. And when he says, "So everyone agrees that a steady, small, but way bigger than a leakage current flows through the load in the first second" (20:52), Derek pretty much entirely ignores the result of his own experiment. Moreover, the experimental result of Alpha Phoenix, which made much better job in designing, conducting, and explaining his experiment, cannot really support Derek's claim, since his oscilloscope trace does not allow resolving these 3 ns (time the light needs to travel 1m), since his oscilloscope resolution is 1 us/div.   I am not saying that Derek is not right that E/M radiation can be transmitted in free space. I am saying that Derek's experiment does not show what he claims it shows: that a light source would ignite in 3 ns.

I think the equals sign in Maxwell's equations means that the idea of field carrying energy and electrons carrying energy are ALMOST interchangeable (displacement current throws this in favour of the field approach). But it is important to have clarity of thought: it's not that electrons pass through the battery, gain energy and the SAME ELECTRONS dump that energy in the load - but the battery will establish a drift velocity in the wire that results in net energy transfer to the load.   I like the Ansys animations, and would recommend anyone trying to really understand classical electromagnetism to use that as a mental model. Also, in Veritasium's original video, think of it like this - the field may transfer the energy, but a current is required to set up the required fields (and that takes time, which is why the bulb turns on slowly - the bulb isn't fully on until the a long time after 1/c, but it does START to turn on at 1/c). The electron flow model isn't necessarily wrong, its just taught in a way that students confuse certain key points.

I guess the problem here is that we never established some things before the problem was stated. We never established what "on" means. Actually, electricity works as follows. There's 3 types of reactions that makes up electric current flow. The first is near direct collisions of free electrons. The second is dragging things along in ones wake as an electron passes by near to another electron that is settled into the lattice of atoms making up the conduit and with their magnetic field interactions, the first ends up pulling the other along behind it, loosed from it's previously settled position, with the first losing a bit of momentum in the process, hence attenuation, while it continues on to find a hole ahead in the direction of it's travel to settle into, followed by the second electron continuing on past it in the same direction looking for a hole of its own to settle into, either just doing that as it may have insufficient energy of momentum imparted, OR it also repeats the chain reaction of pulling other electrons along in its wake, possibly even doing so to the first electron that pulled it out of the lattice of atoms, all the while having a trail of holes opening up just behind the surge of electrons in a rolling offset or wave style of behavior. The third reaction is an electron traveling forward in a direction at a slanted angle, crashing into the lattice of atoms and knocking out a previously settled in place electron, stealing it's spot and causing a chain reaction of the electron knocked out continuing forward in the same direction as the first but with a reversed slant, and so on and so forth till one of them in the chain fails to have enough energy to knock another electron out of its spot and instead only does either the first reaction and halts or does the dragging things in its wake pattern of the second reaction. The pattern roughly would be like strike down and forward diagonally gets diagonal upwards and forwards reaction which gets downward and forward reaction ... , though the angles would be more complex having 3 dimensional axis in real life in most cases, but the pattern still applies as a rough description of it. Reaction one is the least common occurrence as there's relatively a lot of space between atoms and electrons at that tiny scale, reaction two of dragging things in its wake is the most common while reaction three is less often than number two but proportionately not too far behind. Batteries are basically applying a large enough magnetic field of attraction to spark a chain reaction of the second and third reaction going off, primarily, while in side effect sometimes causing the first reaction to take place. Electric motors and generators are basically causing a dragging things in its wake reaction like the second one, primarily, but it can also pull along free electrons as well, as it continues on to secondarily cause reaction 3 occurrences and some reaction one occurrences in side effect. The whole induction effect is basically as follows. When electrons bundle up together like a traffic jam due to the voltage (pressure) differential relative to the size of the conduit, they bump into one another and end up scattering photons about all over the place, creating a spherical ball of concentrated photons (heat particles) in the conduit material, while in the bundle of electrons it also makes a ball of concentrated photons at the relative mantle position, aka outside of the central core of the bundle of electrons but below the crust aka she'll of the bundle. These concentrated photons basically stop and get stuck in the electrons, protons and neutrons of the electron bundle and the atomic material of the conduit. These basically stopped photons transfer their rotational energy to the monopoles making up the dipoles that are the core of the electrons, protons and neutrons, causing them to speed up in rotation relative to one another and/or thir previous rotation speed, but not the rotation speed of the pair together as a dipole generating that 1/2 or 1 full spin charge or whatever the (theoretical) physicists say they have in the Standard Model of physics. It's like the Earth speeding up its rotation on its axis, but keeping the orbital rotation speed around the sun the same. This increased rotation speed skews their originally spherical magnetic fields into more disc like shapes with farther reach outward in 2 dimensions in exchange for losing reach in one direction. Due to the sheer volume/quantity of electrons or nuclei of the conduit around, this becomes a larger spherical reach of the magnetic field in this location where the bundle is at. "Magnetic reluctance"; of the material, aka the speed and proclivity to redistribute back the photons and their momentum, keeps this sphere moving along fairly evenly or shrinking if the material is rather apt to becoming magnetic with its individual fields aligning like Iron, as the default reaction before shape of the conduit comes into play. If the conduit coils around and the conduit size across is small enough relative to the voltage to cause a build up of pressure as high momentum stuff is forced to change direction quickly while turning a corner, then you end up with a pile up of the magnetic field discs in the bundle aggregating into an overall thick disk or cylinder shape with rounded ends like two round nose bullets placed end to end, leading to that 90 degrees to the conduit rule of induction. While turning the corner and losing momentum in the process, that lost energy had to go somewhere and that comes about in the form of photons flying out all around the bundle of electrons in a ball shape, taking a bit of the rotational energy making up the extended reach magnetic field of the bundle, and going off to strike the conduit material, stopping those particular photons, but causing a chain reaction of photons(heat particles) flying out of stuff to continue along till it reaches the outside of the conduit causing a final flying out of photons that get registered as heat loss and/or light emission, and/or mysterious energy loss due to magnetic flux conversations plus the momentum lost along the way definitely counting as a temperature rise in the material of the conduit itself. The electron bundle itself of course goes back to a more even distribution of photons and rotational energy per electron after the voltage pressure issues are settled so they're not bundled up together anymore, with similar photons scattering all about and chain reactioning out the material as with the corner turning situation for similar losses as a final momentum settling when holes are found and dragging things in their wake saps momentum and/or the voltage pressure suddenly disappears.

For anybody who wants to be even more confused: Try to understand RF waveguides. Circular ones can guide very high RF power without a wire, just air, with no current flowing in the walls (no heat). You only have to force E- and H-fields into the right mode.
As an RF engineer who worked in RF Power Amplifier development and is used to think in traveling waves and transmission lines with characteristic impedance this is daily business and old and basic knowledge. All the discussions about these videos are similar to the basic discussions about RF effects I often had with people who are used to think in voltage and current and try to understand RF circuits and especially their strange effects. It is also the reason that RF looks as black art to some people. Derek's explanation is very detailed and based on a physical view. As an engineer you have to develop a more intuitive approach to see most of the effects directly. Use of HFSS simulation is not cheap, very time consuming and normally only done for complex circuits on very high frequencies.
