There are too many comments to make sure that I am not repeating what someone else has already pointed out. So bear with me.  :-)      Someone observed that Derek approached this not as a physics "problem" but as an "engineering" problem. In my opinion, that's where things went astray because, as Derek himself points out, the "lumped model" is what is taught to engineers (as well as in the introductory physics classes which "everybody" takes). Only those who are physics majors go on to explore the wave concepts that are behind all this. But all habits die hard and are also "supported" within academia because "nobody wants to solve Maxwell's equations in three dimensions just to analyze a basic circuit." But here's the irony: those four Maxwell's equations were derived by a self-taught engineer (Heaviside) in order to improve telegraphy.   Those four equations have served us well until now because most of our applications are in air (which is about as close to vacuum in terms of interacting with electromagnetic fields but a submariner would immediately jump up and down and say they are painfully aware of the effects of water on antennas) but they are no longer useful when dealing with waves interacting with plasmas and/or other conducting materials (humble brag: I spent my entire professional life and I did not "totally get it" until shortly before I retired even though "it" had been staring me right on my face from the beginning). That's why the remarks by Rick Hartley are spot-on: once you get into high enough frequencies, your circuit is not just your board but the volume surrounding it (for example, think about a modern cell phone's two antennas, the one for receiving/transmitting and the one for charging).   Which brings me to what Derek said at 12:33 about which field drives the current: he opines that "it really is the electric field and not the changing magnetic field that creates the current." In an oral exam, that would invite considerable scrutiny since there is no time-dependent electric field without the magnetic field and vice versa. They go together and if one were "primary," then Heaviside's version of Maxwell's Equations would be... not true. (And, yes, I agree with Michael Permana that this is how science is done. And how science is kept "honest" because, let's face it, we are all humans and often we just can't give up what is in the text books.)

This is why, when designing pcb's you need to realise that if there's a current through a trace the return current will flow on another trace closest to the said trace. In other words if you have a ground plane the return current is in the ground plane exactly next to the said trace. When no ground plane the current will take the shortest path, creating a current loop with all consequencess for that.

Why is it called circuit? The term "circuit" came from it being the "need to know circuit"‚Äînot only discos, but "in-in-the-know" places in the gay community that even included barbershops.
What does circuit mean in physics? A circuit is simply a closed loop through which charges can continuously move.
What does circuit mean in law? A territorial or geographical division of a country or state.
What does the word circuit mean in science? A circuit is a closed loop that electrons can travel in.
The term circuit can be used in a general sense to refer to any fixed path that electricity, data or a signal can travel through.

We shouldn't forget that Maxwell equations are simplification, too. For that reason I think it's better to say that the energy is carried by photons, not by "fields" (mathematical constructs). Photons have momentum, they can transfer it when they interact with charged particles (electrons). When stated like that it's easier to understand. And the electrons - they don't "bump", they exchange photons and transfer momentum, too, in the wires. "Now frequently an electron will bump into a metal ion and transfer some or all of its kinetic energy to the lattice"  Not quite right. The periodic potential that electrons are subject to results in delocalized states, that is, electrons are free to move about the material without colliding into anything. What they can collide with are impurities/defects (there's no such thing as a perfectly uniform lattice) and phonons, which are quantized vibrations of the lattice (sound).   You are correct that the analogy with marbles or a water hose is misleading (and I had a lot of trouble as a TA convincing my students of this!). But the justification you gave for this is incorrect. The fact that the average charge density is zero doesn't have much to do with it; you could still have a net force even then. Imagine a tube with identical numbers of red marbles, fixed in place, and blue marbles, free to move, both homogeneously distributed: there would be no net excess of blue or red marbles, even if you pushed blue marbles on one end (in steady state). Again, the reason has to do with the fact that it's more useful to think of electrons in conductors as occupying delocalized energy bands, and all collisions happen between electrons and elements that don't participate in the flow of current. If you're in a situation where this doesn't apply (presumably conduction through electrolytes in a fluid) I'd expect conductor-conductor collisions to represent a small contribution to energy transfer, which would dwindle to zero in steady state (since such concentration-driven processes only matter when there's a concentration gradient). Since for this problem we care about what happens before steady state is achieved, collisions should not be ignored a priori.  Finally, I think we can agree there was a lot of knee-jerk criticism to your initial video that was unjustified. However, I still think the way to frame this question -- that this is a flaw in the lumped element model -- is not quite right. After all, if you add the elements that are missing, the capacitors and inductors, you correctly predict what's happening, and perhaps that was the source of so much of the resistance (heh) to the argument. What we're seeing here, after all is "just" capacitive coupling, and you don't need to understand what the Poynting vector does to appreciate that, though it helps.

Amusingly, most ham radio operators already knew this model.  You essentially built a giant transmission line/antenna with elements of the correct size and correct spacing, and pumped an electromagnetic waveform through it at (roughly) 60 hertz AC (radio waves are also alternating current!)  Doing the math, a half-wave folded dipole similar to your setup would radiate 60 hertz best at... 2,500 km long.  Your rig is a smidge short!  Microwave power beaming is getting pretty crazy these days, just last month the Navy beamed 1.6kW of power to a receiving station a kilometer away.

I feel like the problem with the first video was that you didn't mention induction. Imo it's actually pretty intuitive that energy transported via induction would travel with light speed along the shortest path through air. Also the focus on the very long circuit was kind of a misdirection, since as you clarified now a closed circuit is not needed for the effect to work. Therfore I would even argue that the radiated inductive energy which travels through air and the "conventional" electric energy which travels along the wire are two distinct phenomena. So it might be more accurate to say: The closing of the switch has some immediate effect on the light bulb (and everything else around it) that travels with light speed through air. But that effect supplies significantly less power than the conventional current, so the light bulb wouldn't fully turn on from it.

Great explanation. Back in the days at university we had a lab exercise where we did something very similar. We used a roll of cheap Ethernet cable and put a voltage accross a pair of it's wires on one side. It was eye-opening to see that current flows immediately, and what was even more disturbing at the time: it didn't matter if the two wires on the other end were connected or not. Only after the time it takes for the signal to travel to the end of the cable and back would you see the current flow change at the input - and man, the weird up-and-down-jumps of the current flow over time had us puzzled. The exercise was to model the wire so that we could calculate the current over time and as a function of the load at the other end. Definietly one of the Ah-ha! exercises.

I don't doubt your first video about this because by experience in studying Electrodynamics when I was an undergraduate and graduate student in Physics. Analogies using water current and other mechanical systems cannot capture the true essense of the electric and magnetic field.   [I learn this the hard way, i.e., by going around learning general relativity, which has much complexities but similar to electrodynamics in some parts, and quantum field theories, which views fields as the most important ingredient to produce particles using excitations.]   The energy aspect of electrodynamics is not similar to our intuition due to the existence of Poynting vector, which is the reason why I instantly trusted your argument in the first video. The mechanism that you elaborate further in this video is time dependent, not quasi-static which we are most familiar, which then requires Poynting vector since magnetic field is not zero at this non-quasi-static state.   TL;DR Electric field acts unlike the predictions from our intuition. In Maxwell''s EM theory, the carrier of energy is both the electric and magnetic field, similar to how spacetime carries energy in the gravitational wave.

Your entire concept should be a No brainer, especially when you account for the resonant frequency generated by an electrical current with regards to "Cross talk". If your theory was wrong, then we would in a vacuum, never need to have shielded wires. The resonant frequency of the wires beside a shorted wire would not carry over to an exposed wire IF your theory was wrong. In reality, as we have found, the cleaner signals in digital technology always come from shielded wires, and the more "dirty" signals always are affected by the "cross-talk" of neighboring wires. Further proving your theory to be exactly true.

Actually the experiment is very misleading and Derek only recreates something that electrical engineers have known for over 100 years.  His experiment shows that electromagnetic energy can flow through free space.  For over 100 years, circus acts have been lighting electric bulbs that have been bathed with electromagnetic fields separated in space from the generator.  So yes you will be able to light the bulb in a little over 1m/c seconds.  But his 100,000km circuit is irrelevant since the light bulb would light up even if there was no cricuit connecting the bulb, as he shows in the simulation showing the third unconnected wire.  If there was a bulb in the third unconnected bulb the bulb would light up!  The Wire connected to his switch acts like a transmission antenna and the wire 1m away acts like a receiving antenna.  This is the simple case of an infinite length dipole antenna which many electrical engineers learn to solve in school.  If the battery was connected in a loop with the switch and the bulb was connected in the loop, bulb would still light up!  So all the talk of a wire to the moon is irrelevant.  A long time a go, in engineering school, we were taught how to ignore irrelevant "givens" in an engineering problem.  What is misleading to people who don't understand electromagnetic propagation is that most of the energy in the given circuit will be guided by the wires and this energy will in fact traverse the circuit based on the propagation velocity of the electromagnetic field in the wire.  This is typically between 60% and 80% of the speed of light for wires typically used in the real world.  Of course, the miniscule amount of energy propagated by electromagnetic radiation will  reach the bulb in a little over 1m/c seconds.  It's really a trick question that never fails to confuse unwary engineering students. (Not me.)   If there was an electrostatic and magnetic shield between the switch and the resistor (bulb), I am sorry to say that Derek's circuit will not see any energy measurable by his oscilloscope at the resistor (bulb) until the energy propagating through the wire reaches the resistor.  That's why Ric Hartley states at the end that when designing printed circuits "you better define the other side of the transmission line".  In the case of Derek's experiment, the other side of the transmission line is the wire connected to the resistor and the ground plane of the earth.  These are not at all mentioned in his original question. So we can just as correctly assume that the wires are isolated from each other, for example if he used properly grounded co-axial cables or an infinite copper plate between the wires.  Btw, electric current can also be created by a changing magnetic field.  In this experiment, without doing the math, I think that the currents he measured are probably due to the changing magnetic fields arising from the currents and less from the electric fields arising from the 12V voltage present at the switch.  So if he wanted to be precise, he would have to talk about the electric and magnetic fields and the changes that happen as the switch is flicked.    The illustration showing the steady state electric field set up by the battery existing at the bulb are actually irrelevant since these will not materially change until the electromagnetic field propagates through the entire length of wire.  The miniscule currents he saw were due to the electromagnetic propagation through the air.  The Oscilloscope display is an excellent illustration of the superposition theorem which states that you will receive two separate effects from the two separate sources involved in this experiment.  But if what he really wanted to ask was how long it would take the electromagnetic energy that is being transmitted by the current and voltage that is building up in the wire to reach the bulb 1m away, then yes the correct answer is 1m/c sec, approximately.

This is well better !  One important aspect is still missing, leading to confusions:  far-field and near-field approximations (or equivalently radiative and reactive field regimes).  The far-field approximation applies for the first nanoseconds when the immediate areas on both sides of the switch emit waves in all radial directions, explaining the small amount of power received on the load side at that moment (most of the energy is radiated in far space). In the far-field approximation regime, the fields propagates through waves. Technically, Maxwell equations drop to two coupled propagation equations (called Helmholtz equations). A scalar voltage cannot be even defined in this case, you need to add a potential vector.  After a moment, different sections of the wires start to interact (the Fresnel intermediate regime). You must use the whole set of Maxwell equations to describe correctly this intermediate step.   Only when the whole system gets in electrical equilibrium, the voltage can be defined, the Faraday's shielding gets effective (zero field inside conductors) and the Ohms law can be safely used.  In some specific cases, the problem can be cast into regions; some small ones (compared to the wavelength) where lumped model can be safely used and larger ones where the two fields propagate in a guided manner (wave-guide approximation).  This problem is really hard to tackle correctly in its entirety even for the best engineers. May be a second correcting video on this topic one day !

I like how Derek says "the truth is" and then declares his own misconceptions. In fact, the truth is Derek is trying to justify his blunder by appealing to side-effects, such us parasite capacity and induction, which can be effectively eliminated by increasing the distance between wires (lay them in a circle, for example). 2:40 yes, for long distances, electrons in a conductor usually carry energy much better than em waves through air. That's why we use wires. Electrons are the carriers of em field localized in the linear conductor and they both carry that field AND carried by the field. Exactly as water molecules in the pipe carry the pressure and are carried by pressure. When hydraulic piston is engaged, pressure wave moves along the sleeve with speed of sound (in that liquid) while liquid itself almost doesn't move at all. 4:50 in a water hose, liquid density is also the same in all points. Doesn't water flow in a hose? Derek is confusing charge (density) and potential (pressure). There IS a potential difference in any segment of a wire under current, created by electrons localized in the wire and moving through it. Just like there IS a pressure difference along water hose where water flows. 5:20 battery is NOT a magnet and it doesn't itself create em field until its poles are connected, and the current creates it. Poles only have different potentials, not charges. 6:20 wrong again. There's no any charge on a conductor surface. If there were, conductors would attract or repel each other depending on the pole they are connected to. In real life, they may attract or repel only depending on the current direction (if you simply reverse the wire position, you'll toggle attract/repel). 6:52 funny enough, Derek understands how a moving electron creates the field, but somehow doesn't realize that this is exactly how field is created ALONG the wire, not towards its sides. Electrons only tend to concentrate towards conductor surface in cases of very high frequency currents (vhf conductors sometimes make hollow to spare material). 7:30 that would be a "good analogy" if we   assume that the shepherd physically kicks each sheep's butt and the whole flock moves along the path using the kinetic energy of those kicks. The "barking dogs" is just the wire's insulation, which literally guides the electrons along the wire, not letting them out. The fantasy of the surface charges is a voluntary rubbish. Even if they took place, how in the hell would they "guide mobile electrons"? Studying microwave wave guides is a good way to visualize how the field works, because it takes how frequency increases the skin effect to the point it leaves the outer conductor and is held inside the wave guide enclosure, taking the thought experiment from some wispy em wave floating around a wire to using the water inside a pipe example, like in dc. Then it's a little easier to visualize how different shapes of wave guide channel the field into different patterns. Learning the math was interesting for rectangular wave guides. The math assumes light is faster than unity for the short side to calc the long, lol. Wave guides might be a good related topic to add to this series. They help to visualize ac reactance in open air inside a hollow tube conductor.

I have found such differences in understanding across many fields of study.   One the one side: All of the knowledge that a person can accumulate through teachers and texts and personal testing.  On the other side: The very specific results of a real-life set-up. Results of such set-ups can be duplicated and tested, yet sometimes the results of such set-ups seem to contradict ( at least from a moderate examination) the common understanding of how things work. ( not everyone has the same knowledge) If it cannot be explained, then new knowledge ( usually) is added to the field of study. I didn't dwell on the implications for power transmission long, since I was distracted with other shiny things, but the reactions I'm seeing mirror a lot of the reactions I noticed from the other hard sciences like physics, and especially quantum physics. When presented with a problem, they would just parrot back what the textbook or professor told them, rather than think on their own. 'How big is an electron?', 'Oh, it's infinitely small.', 'Really? That doesn't make any sense. What about this Plank length thing where math just goes to crap once you measure lower than that? Seems like a more plausible number.', 'Nope, the book says it's infinitely small, so therefore it is'.  Sure, I was just some EE undergrad trying to think outside the box, but it's almost as if students were scorned for daring to challenge a professor's answer. And when that science is so complex and deep, it necessarily must be built on the backs of others, people tend to take a lot of assumptions for truth rather than thinking through them for themselves.   Now take this discussion forward to things like trying to contain plasma streams in a fusion reactor. If you don't have a real firm belief in charge gradients and currents, you're going to have a hard time struggling with how moving plasmas cause their own fields and currents, which then affects the rest of the plasma as well.

TL;DW: Derek's claim from last video can actually be experimentally verified in the real world, and proves that energy is transmitted faster than anything could travel along the loop (or 1/2 or 1/4 of the loop). This is impossible to explain in most simplified models of electricity, so you have to resort to electric fields (if not Maxwell's equations) or accept that the gigantic parallel wires act like antennas to transmit power wirelessly (at least until the system settles into a steady state).  Everything else in the video is maddening to me. It's desperately trying to make the point that chickens come from *eggs, not* from other chickens as your *lying* teachers may have told you. But then the video conveniently omits the fact that eggs come from chickens, so your teachers were more or less on the mark all along. In case the analogy isn't clear, the chickens and eggs are electrons and the electric field. Sure, the electric field imparts a force on the electrons, but the electric field is determined by the density and motion of electrons! Electrons *are* pushing each other through the circuit, just not in the overly literal sense (e.g., chickens from chickens *must* mean chickens are mammals, right?) imagined in the video.  At any rate, kudos to Derek for correcting his earlier mistakes. That's how science (including popular science) should work.

The timing of a light bulb can be easily explained without "turning on" field theory.   A battery has two exposed ends / contacts called poles (+ -). These poles vary in length. In small batteries they are almost flat, not extending beyond the battery, or longer, such as in car batteries. When you connect wires to these battery terminals, you are simply making these terminals longer than they were at the factory. So whether the connected wires are 10 cm long or 150,000 km long, they will still be the terminals of that battery, and there will be voltage at their ends! (A perfect wire, with no resistance, will show a voltage equal to the battery voltage). Connecting a light bulb to these wires will cause it to light up immediately. (When the switch is closed)

This is a very interesting video. I am an electronics engineer and this aligns perfectly with my understanding of the subject. This was not always the case. My understanding improved when I was helping my physics major daughter who was studying electric circuits. Being a physics major their perspective on the subject was very different then what I got at school for engineering. They viewed it as EM fields and I had to really understand the physics behind the circuit to help explain the circuits behavior. Only then could I answer some of her very interesting questions about electron movement and field formation. This video is perfectly aligned with my final understanding.  With that said I believe that both sides are in many ways correct. The bulb being in close proximity to the voltage source  and more importantly close to the wire that will carry the current will cause what is basically EM noise to be captured by the load and its wire. This will generate a reduced current which can light up a sensitive bulb. This will happen at the stated speed based on the distance between the two. At the same time this circuit is still not fully closed as the full magnitude of the EM field generated by the power source as not formed yet near the load and will only form after propagating through the full length of the wire which is everyone else's argument. You can see this in the provided simulations of this video. So yes you get some current and yes your circuit is not truly on yet.  At the same time both are partially wrong. If the claim is the circuit does not provide power through the wires based on wire length and the EM noise method is how the circuit works then you would be wrong. Simply move the load further away from the source and you will quickly have to wait the longer propagation time to get any noticeable current. The primary function of the circuit does not rely on the EM noise mechanism for power transfer. If you claim that there will only be leakage current when the power source is close to the load then you would be wrong again. The EM noise can be significant and can be measured.

One more (possible) problem with circuit... If wires are superconductors, will they emit any field outside themselves? If not, then we have another problem)
You say that the field is created by charges on the surface of the wire and then shoot youself in the foot, arguing that the charges are distributed "instantly". What the hell is "instantly"?! There is a light second to the middle of the wires! It takes one second for the charges to be distributed throughout the wire.  For 1m/c of a second, the charges will be distributed only over a length of 1 meter, which is 1/300000000 of the entire length of the wire. This means that the voltage on the light bulb will be approximately 1/300000000 of the nominal value. This is even less than the leakage current. That's how small it is!  And the experiment was deliberately set up with an error, because the ratio between the distance to the light bulb and the length of one branch of the wire is only 10 here, and not 300000000. And accordingly, after 1/s of a second, not 1/300000000 of the wire will be involved, but as much as 1/10! No amount of precision instruments can eliminate this. Since we are talking about a relative value and not an absolute one.
To get the answer of "1/c" seconds - do we follow the convention that light has same speed in all directions?

You could also think about the electric wire on either side of the circuit as radiating elements in an antenna. Because the pulse is not continuous, it has Fourier components that will cause a pulse of EM radiation to radiate away from the wires, which is then picked up and carried but the wires, acting as antenna elements on the other side. This is why the circuit need not be closed in order to transfer energy, and in fact of you had an alternating current could induce the full current across the gap without the circuit being connected at all. This is effectively how transformers work in AC systems, and how power transfer systems work in wireless charging. You are correct though, it's the electric field that transfers the energy, not any of the electrons.

I'm still hung up on this idea of "electrons flowing through a circuit." Everything I know about energy and waves has told me that a single electron does not travel from the beginning to the end of the circuit; rather, its motion within the system affects its localized environment, causing a shift in the energy of the electrons next to it, so on and so forth in a sort of quantum compression and rarefaction, so that energy cascades through the circuit but individual particles don't necessarily flow like a liquid/hose through the circuit. The way this has been explained to me is like dropping a rock in water -- a wave of energy cascades out from the initial point of disruption, but individual molecules of water are not travelling in that wave, they're just responding to disruptive forces in their localized environment. Only in the case of electricity, electrons obey quantum forces rather than being impeded by mechanical forces like water.

While it is much better than the first post and while it is true that it is not the electrons who carry the energy from the battery to the load, it is worth remembering that it is the electrons who RECAPTURE most of the energy to ... transfer ... it to the load. So the wording could be misleading with "it is not the electrons who carry the energy from the battery to the load" since, ... they do, but it is not the job of the same electron all the way, but a teamwork, a team of electrons, and the team is coordinated at the speed of light.  Furthermore, around 19:20, while you get 4 volt at the bulb, you forgot to mention that this is a small fraction of the voltage at the source, voltage that will eventually become the one across the bulb. In other word, if you start with a battery of 5 volt, you may get just enough voltage across the bulb to cross the barrier voltage of a diode, not to light a LED, which will turns on later on though.

Atomic bombardment. The field in the wire is the symptom of the atomic bombardment. Think of the desktop toy with where there are multiple steel balls in a row hanging on strings from a shaft above. You pull the first ball back and let it go, then seemingly magically the ball on the opposite end swings out without any of the balls in between moving. Same concept...An electron from the - side of the battery puts pressure on the first atom of copper [or adds to the atom] causing an electron to be released to hit the next atom of copper and so on and do on all the way through the copper circuit [including load] back to the + terminal of the battery [Power source] acting like a wave of energy flowing through the copper wire. As the cascade of electrons passes from one atom to the next, those electrons passing from atom to the next is the motion that generates the magnetic field. Keep in mind, it NOT the motion of electrons, It's the adding of an electron to the copper atom which causes instability in the copper atom forcing that atom to shed on of it's electrons which gets added to the next atom causing that atom to shed the extra electron in a cascading/wave effect moving through the wire. It's NOT a single electron bouncing from atom to atom through the wire.

Potential difference makes the electrons move, bunch of positive charged(lost electron) atoms are stored in the positive terminal of the battery and the same amount of negative charged atoms(has extra electron) are available in the negative terminal of the battery. I feel like the differentiation between the field and the electrons in terms of what's transferring power is a bit odd because they're just not separable things. You can't have the changing fields without the charged particles moving around and you can't have the charged particles moving around without the changing fields. So saying one is responsible for the transfer of energy and the other isn't is kind of confusing. Yeah the layman's understanding of current as electrons physically bumping into each other like billiard balls and pushing each other though a wire is wrong, but it's just because it's a macroscopic classical physics analogy. It's just that the E&M fields surrounding each individual electron are the things pushing and pulling the other nearby electrons, not physical collisions between hard spheres. Yeah collectively all of those individual electrons generate extended E&M fields we can easily understand with Maxwell's equations, but the collective fields are still dependent on the individual electrons and all of their local movements and interactions. So the energy isn't just transferring through some external fields while the electrons are off doing their own thing. The behavior of each is intrinsically linked and inseparable.

I am glad you did this. I design Electrical/Instrumentation and Control systems. I am constantly explaining issue of voltage transferring power into instrumentation lines if laid in close proximity to the power lines, especially over long distances.   As the voltage is increased, say from 120v to 480v 3 phase, the amount of transference is increased. Voltage is that amount of 'Jump'. If you notice in the long range experiment at the ranch (Alpha Phoenix) there was a small, almost instant, response to the circuit being completed. That is the same signal we pick up on instrumentation as a power cable is turned on close to it. You have it in this circuit.   THEN you get the load power, just like you see in the simulation.   It is far lower though - and I think it is important to see that your voltage connection is not fully transferred at that point. It it like a voltage pen. They could pick up the signal, but that is a different beast than actually turning on the light. That will take more grunt to do. The signal may be there - but the 'light' shouldn't come on until the rest of the circuit is complete, and that is shown in the data.   NOW: (and I realize you are busy) IF you move the light/battery further way, can you still get that voltage response? I suggest not. And if you have a wireless current 'pen' or detector near by I hazard you will get a responce at the time of connection at the same rate of 1m/c.   We treat the voltage from electrical power as something to avoid. That is not considered a completed circuit, but as outside noise as I am familiar with the result. We decrease it by moving it further apart. Its a factor in circuits as you run power next to them. I don't see it as something that can turn the light ON at that distance unless the voltage is very high. Just an affect of spill out from the power. That is how wireless circuits work, and it is very low power in the end.   I would hazard to say it is a circuit though. Its more like Noise as I experience it in a controls environment.   Does the Noise run a 1/c? Yeah. You can get that noise though with a broken line, or unconnected system. So it is a signal of circuit closing - the firing up of the local field - but it really isn't the power. It is the field.   Maybe lightening or a bomb is the best way to describe it - You can see the lightening. You can see the bomb explode.   Then later you hear the blast.   The first signal is going the speed of light, so 1/c - but it really isn't the energy that would be needed to turn the light on. It is too low power, as shown, unless you use a little LED. That comes later, like thunder.   Most bulbs won't come on at the flash, but the thunder.   BUT, if the voltage is high enough, as ElectroBoom and anyone with a tesla coil and a lightbulb can attest - if the voltage is high enough you can turn on that light bulb also. Just like really close Lightening.   That is not a circuit so much as bleed off from the field generated.   Lightening is one thing. The light and thunder are different components, and in this case the field and the circuit are different parts also. You are picking up both.   The circuit powers the light, the first signal you get is just the field. It could technically power anything close. The signal you get in the simulation on the wire below the circuit is showing that.   I propose another test, after all of that comment vomit:  Set up a second wire next to it, and see if it gains the same 4mA you get initially on the circuit.   I suggest it will. I might be wrong, but I think you will see the field affect is separate from circuit affect.   If you pick the right light you might get to see the signal light it up at 1/c, but if not, you see nothing till the circuit is created. Matter and energy are all considered to be mass.  Any mass at rest will remain at rest until acted upon by an unbalanced force (energy).  Any mass in motion will remain in motion at a constant velocity and in a straight line unless acted upon by an unbalanced force (energy).  Friction is one of the biggest unbalanced forces that causes a mass in motion to slow down.  Everything has friction.  Electron flow (electricity) and magnetism are interrelated.  Electrons moving in an organized direction will create a magnetic field.  Some chemical reactions will create an organized flow of electrons.  A moving magnetic field will create an organized flow of electrons.  The crystal lattice formed by conductive metals is very stable which makes it ideal for creating an organized electron flow of electrons because it has a very low friction factor.  A moving magnetic field or chemical reaction will introduce an unbalanced force into a conductive metal that causes an organized flow of electrons.  Just because the electron at the location you are at does not reach a light bulb one light second away from your location in one second is irrelevant.  A light bulb will not light up unless electrons are moving through the conductive metal that makes up the light emitting element of the light bulb.  The fact that electrons at the light bulb one light second away from your location start moving through the light bulb in one second is what matters.  The unbalanced force (energy) imparted into the mass (electrons) flows at the speed of light and causes the electrons in the conductive metal to move with it.

This video and the original one are a perfect example of science.  Not circuits, or electricity, or fields.  This is a great example of science as a discipline.  Someone makes a claim.  Others work to support the claim.  Still others work to refute it.  The claim either becomes stronger held up by repeated results, or it is found to have problems.  The claim can then be scrapped altogether or can be modified to address these problems.  This is exactly the scientific method.  Wonderful!

there is a gradient of the charge that is greater from one side of the wire than the other. the reason why  the charge become symetric is the force that opposes the direction of the gradient that equalize the difference across the gradient. to you it seem like the field of the charge is  distribuated equally instantly but if we slow down the inductance we see that the  field of the charge begins strongest next to one of the poles and slowly builds up to the other pole until the force that opposes the direction of the gradient even out the buildup until the charge becomes equal across the entire wire. we see this slow buildup even in ac systems and the reason why a light bulb often flash before it give stable light output when the power company first boot up the ac network after a  short circuit  is because the opposition to the build up across the wire is delayed and not instant.

It's just that you can get away with lumped model for most everyday Circuit analysis since such analysis isn't concerned with transients when there aren't any caps or inductors in the circuit. The fact they are needed to properly model wires becomes evident only when relativistic effects need to be accounted for ( effects with timescales comparable to field travel times) and their omission in the original video contributed to viewer confusion. As far as simple circuit analysis is concerned, with caps and inductor density included, lumped model becomes a good approximation to the field picture, as Derek later included in the video.

I would like to introduce a bit of philosophy into this debate. If you need to overcomplicate an explanation as much as you have done here, I would state that it's flawed from the outset. Consider that all of this is just theory anyway. Energy is all around us all the time. The opening and closing of the circuit is just an enabling technology to be able to harness that energy. All the complicated math and physics theory is just an attempt to explain by using a language invented by man. This language is inherently flawed (being written by humans), but some buy into it (mostly academics). When studying math, I could prove to my professor that all theorem proofs we performed to study a certain proinciple just as easily  could be interpreted to be equal to zero for all theorems as anything else. She thought I was an idiot of course, but found it amusing anyway. This is because she was taught the "correct way".  My point is: who's to say what is absolutely correct, especially when the language used is flawed. Many great mathematicians have used the language to their advantage, and just decided that a certain interpretation works, just because they say so, and have created theories that fits to prove their point... and they have defended it because then the math works as predicted. What if that interpretation was wrong? and who's to say?  Well Nicola Tesla for one. As the story goes (at least one I have heard), he said Newton was wrong about gravity. He also said that all we know of electricity is wrong. Furthermore he proclaimed that gravity doesn't exist, but only electricity and magnetism.  I won't delve much into it here, but another of his fellow countrymen also had differing ideas from our so-called consensus regarding our world view. This man was Ruder Josip Boskoviƒá, and he wrote a book called "the theory of natural philosophy". Here he speaks of the theory behind the ether. He was succeeded by many others with other theories, for  instance Einstein, and his theory of relativity. A competing theory that displaced Boskoviƒá ether theory as flat out wrong, because his ownt theory was better. There was nothing wrong with his interpretation of the mathematical language , but  I for one believe that to be very much true that he was displaced because of "consensus" (lets call it the emperors new clothing). Consensus is dangerous. It has given us a flawed conception about much of the world around us. The so-called climate crisis is one of them. It's very flawed indeed, and based on modelling that is blatantly and obviously flawed, but then again "consensus". Who is to say that the simulation you created is correct? It's based on a model, created in software that a human wrote. When did that computer program become the de-facto standard? How can you verify that it is correct? Because the math works? Remember that interpretation? Let me finish of with a quote from another well known mathematician, George Box: All models are inherently wrong, but some of them are useful". Let's conclude that your explanation seems plausible, but can be debated til the cows come home. Consider this instead: The closing of the circuit enables a completion of a magnetic field allowing you to access the energy which is already in the bulb. That at least rhymes more with the theory (law) of energy conservation. We're "forcefully" being taught to believe what we learn in school, but remember, when we stop asking questions, science is dead. The answer is "out there", but who's to say we have found the correct one yet? Consensus? Einstein? Hawking?I don't think so.... I don't think they thought so either.

Thanks for this great explanation of what is going on, but I do have to correct one statement you make at about 4:53 where you say that the net charge in every volume is zero.  The thermal excitation of the conduction electrons means the electrons are randomly distributed and there are space charges an fields that develop from that.   This then creates what is known as thermal or Johnson noise and is a noise inherent to the material and not noise picked up from something external to the system.  This phenomenon is important in things like communication systems.   It can be appreciable though because it has a huge bandwidth (approaching a Terahertz) most measurements of it register only a tiny fraction of it.

Let's have a circuit with no switch.   And we'll create a battery by creating a positron and electron inside a pair of hemispherical capacitors.   From the time the positron electron pair are created, a field will begin to propagate down the wires.   Remember that before to creation of the pair there is no electric field anywhere.   It would take the time for the electric field to fully propagate thought the entire circuit before the light would light up.  Inserting the battery into the circuit begins propagation of electric field at the speed of light.   Which sets up almost an entire circuit and rearrangement of electrons...with the only field that is not zero is acro the switch.   Closing that switch causes a non zero field in the wire, with everything ready to move and do the speed would be only the time to cross the switch gap.   Because the battery shoved electrons everywhere they needed to to create a zero field inside the circuit.

This is just electrical crosstalk that any working EE should have seen any time you run unshielded signal cables or PCB traces in parallel. What makes this example odd isn't the crosstalk, it's the signal cables being connected together into a circuit at a distance with a measurable light delay, i.e. there would be no pushback showing two long signal cables in parallel with a pulse in one inducing a pulse in the other. It's the idea that these are a circuit that throws people off.

Those are not really "misconceptions" they are just different models representing a physical process. Those models have limits. This is Physics 101. You cannot apply the Drude model (the electricity being generated by the movement of electrons) for high frequency things (which you are in for the closing of a switch since that happens in ns), it's only valid for steady state and low frequency. Even less applying something as simple as basic circuit theory to a high frequency problem.  This the problem of removing all the maths from Physics explanations. Math is the common framework that ensure that we truly understand what we are saying. Without maths you can can say pretty much anything and no one can really prove you wrong, and as you say since it's "vague". If you had used some basic math, most Physics graduates could have pointed out: "yeah that equation breaks down here because it was derived from the Maxwell equation with the x, y assumptions which do not apply in a high frequency issue".  But with vagueness you get vague answers.

This seems bit like the Monty Hall problem ‚Äî there are a couple of seemingly minor nuances in the semantics or assumptions of the question that have a dramatic effect on which answer is right.  In this follow-up, @Veritasium glosses over the part that I think most people (certainly me) get stuck on: the relevance of whether the wires are connected.  If it is not relevant and we are just talking about a minor amount of electricity flowing through the field and causing a sensitive bulb to turn on, then this seems more like a demonstration of "neat, switching on a small amount of electricity can turn on a bulb a meter a way through the resulting electrical field, even when they are not wired together" rather than the original point, which was more along the lines of "when I flip the switch, the distance from the switch to the bulb is what determines when the bulb turns on, and not the length of the wires". matter and interactions S2
The thing that's so messed up about this, is that most US education system (I know it from the 3 universities I've been to, and from many confused posts in physics stack exchange with bogus answers) doesn't teach this sort of stuff. I'm a grad student in physics, and I find the textbooks do way too much cheating arguments. While simple cheating argument is fine to teach, the true explanation should at least be roughly covered so student know that there is more to the story. I feel most professors don't even know the true explanations. 1. This surface charge is one example.  2. Another example is why electrons only occupy energy eigenstate in statistical mechanics. The true answer to this involves time average, but it's never taught. 3. Another example is why is there electrical resistence at all. The textbook explanation is electrons in Block states are scattered and thermalized when colliding with defect or phonon. This is a cheating argument because phonons would then carry momemtum and push the next electron. Another way of seeing the problem is that a closed system between phonon and electron conserve momentum, the lose of total momentum has to come from surface, mostly at the two ends. 4. Another example is why super conductor has no resistence. The textbook: there is an energy gap so there is no where for electron to scatter, is just bad, because it would then be an insolator. The true answer: the gap and BCS state we typically calculate is only at net momentum = zero. There is one BCS state for every net momentum below the gap... meaning the electrons can only be accelerated collectively as condensate. And this collective condensate has extremely small scattering matrix with defect because the interaction is one-particle-one-particles, not one-condensate-one-particle, ie the chance of changing all electrons within the condensate at once, is small. There are so many cheating arguments in textbooks, I think it creates confusion/misunderstanding more than the convenience. While simple cheating argument is fine to teach, the true explanation should at least be roughly covered so student know that there is more to the story.
I think we should take a closer look at Tesla's understanding of electricity. He was somewhat critical of the ideas of Maxwell, Einstein & Hertz (he called their theories "beggars in velvet garb"). Nothing is set in stone. Hence, we should try and find the truth, especially when governments and educational institutions are sequestering away knowledge from the public.
A model must be chosen not for its coolness, but for its usefullness. If i dont, it breaks. Why should i care about your Poynting stuff, to understand the nature of reality? In all honesty it was Dereks initially vague statement that caused this discussion and I think he has ended up on the wrong side of it.  If he was right the step change should be the full 100% of the source voltage. Why wouldn't it be if this is the only way electricity flows? There are two mechanisms at play here. 1. The one Derek has been relying on all the time: transmitting energy wirelessly just like a radio etc. 2. DC conducted current flow through wires forming a circuit.  The test demonstrates this perfectly at the end. The first step shows the AC components transmitted from and induced between the source and receiver wires. This voltage is low due to the low coupling between them. Second, after the 30ns of the speed for light to travel through the loop, we see the full DC source voltage...
I think what a lot of people miss is that at the end of the day these are all just models of reality. The "electrons flowing through wires" model is very successful because it is a) easy to conceptualize and understand (try imaging this for complicated circuits, schematics vs. actual layout) and b) gives accurate results for a lot of practical applications when you don't need to consider super tiny timescales. This is not my area of specialty but I imagine even this model of electricity is probably subsumed by another quantum one that better predicts reality in certain corner cases. I wish we stopped teaching things like "This is How X ACTUALLY works" and instead "here is a more detailed model that' better correlates with certain observations". ‚ÄúAll models are wrong, but some are useful

I still think the explaination is wrong. A battery has no electic field if the plus and minus terminals are not connected together with a wire. So it could never light up a bulb if you connect one with wires.  A battery has two terminals: One with to much electrons (minus) and one with too less electrons (plus) terminal. If you connect them, electrons will start "flowing". But of course there are no "mobile electrons" (5:06) like water droplets at this the point. It does not work like water in a water hose system, electons are not like h2o molecules: The are not freely mobile, they are usually tight bound to atoms. If you connect a plus terminal of a battery with a wire to a minus terminal of the same battery, the battery will immediatelly start to "balance" the electron levels between both terminals. And this will be done completely *without* the need of an electrical field. In contrast: The electrical field, which will appear, is a result of the moving electrons. Without moving electrons, no electrical field.  An electron will not "flow" from the plus to the minus terminal. It will "flow" from the minus terminal right to the first atom of the connected wire. And now this atom has too much electrons, and because it can not "flow" back to the minus terminal (which still has too much electrons), it will instead "flow" in the direction of the plus terminal. But also not to the plus terminal itself, only to the next atom, which is the second next atom of the minus terminal, and so on...  So your assumption at 4:55 ("the truth is, if you average over a few atoms you find the charge density everywhere inside a conductor is zero") is *only* true, if no power source like a batter is connected (according to my understanding how electrical flow works). As soon as you connect a battery (or any other power source), the *first* atom of the used conductor will get a negativ charge density and will pass the electron from one atom to the next like a torch in a torch relay.  If you want to proof, that electrons do not flow without electric fields, you need to find a way to eleminate those fields. But here is the problem: Can other electical fields interfere to the power flow? Can you, e. g. stop the flow or enhance it (to a simple, plain copper wire for example)? The Poynting Vector is horrible physics. The cross product of two vectors is not a vector, nor is it close enough for government work. The idea that nature makes the same mistakes in math that modern physicists do, is a really bad idea. I'll give examples of how bad the physics of the Poynting vector really are. Imagine you have a superconducting loop of wire in which there is a clockwise current flowing. Now lay insulated wires on top of the superconductor, and hook them up to a battery such that if they were connected to a load, a clockwise current would flow. We have both magnetic fields and electric fields, so the Poynting vector tells us there is an energy flow, but there is no such thing, the battery does not discharge, and no lights light up. Want another example? OK, hook up wires to a battery and a load, only use steel wires instead of copper. You'll have much stronger magnetic fields, so the Poynting vector claims much more energy is flowing than there really is. Like I said, the Poynting vector is really bad physics.

Seems to be a confusion between the electrostatic effects that guide the charges down the wire (Gauss' law) and the electrodynamic effects that are produced from the closing of the switch (Faraday's law).  Normally, when engineering circuits, the transient effect due to the closing of the switch is ignored because the power is lower than the power in the circuit and it goes away in nanoseconds.  However, if voltages are switched quickly and the circuit elements are extremely close together, then this effect can become comparable to the nominal voltages in the circuit.  As the animations show, wires in the circuit act as antennas.

I think the biggest thing that blew my mind about electricity was when I realised (a long time ago) that electrons don't get used up, they just move.  When I was young I thought electrons were like a fuel, the sockets on the wall delivered them, and batteries were filled with them, and once they were gone your device would stop working - it really blew my mind when I learned that electrons = "work", that it's only when you drag electrons around a circuit that it does what it's supposed to, and that AC is when you drag them back and forth.  I remember when I was about 13 I came up with the analogy that DC is like a chainsaw with the teeth constantly moving in one direction while AC was like a handsaw where you push and pull the teeth back and forth - the electrons don't power the device it is the mechanism moving the electrons that powers the device, if you stop the electrons from moving the device powers off.  When I learned that it was like my world was turned upside down and I was thrilled and so enthused about learning more.

Unless your light bulb is an unusual design (produces light at a very small fraction of rated voltage), you won't get any light early. You will get voltage going through the resistor, but the amount of energy wouldn't light up any incandescent bulb. I noticed that you were using LEDs of a type that produce low amounts of light at lower voltages by using power regulation circuits. This is the only type of light that would work for this. At the scaled down distance in your experiment, you got 20% of the voltage. If you scale to 1 meter (looks like roughly 3 times the distance), the field will go down a lot. I believe it would be roughly an inverse squared proportion (source is a line of length distance, and spread over a volume of distance¬≥), so from roughly 1 foot to 1 meter is around 1/10 the voltage, so the voltage in the original experiment will be 1/20 of the source. Thus, from your 12V car battery, you would get 0.6V at the bulb until the fields went all the way around the circuit. And it seems that below 50% of rated voltage, incandescent bulbs don't light at all, so you only get the fast lighting If you use something that lights up with much less than rated current.
Maybe circuit textbooks omit the surface charge explanation but any intro physics text explains 1. how like-charged particles in a conductor repel each other until they reach equilibrium with the net charge on the surface, 2. the movement of charged particles changes the electric/magnetic field, and 3. a changing EM field creates current where it does work on charged particles. With these principles you know that attaching a charged body (like a battery) to a conductor (like a wire) will cause all charged particles in the new system (circuit) to move to a new equilibrium with the net charge on the conducting surface. The transient movement of charge changes the EM field everywhere (propagating at speed of light), which generates current in any conductor by moving its charged particles (proportional to distance). So correct me if I'm wrong but that makes the surface charge explanation for circuits elementary.

Your thing about wireless charging isn't really accurate, since those devices use a magnetic field, not an electric field. Current forms the magnetic field, while voltage forms the electric field. The most common place you'll see strong electric fields is high voltage powerlines. I have one over my farm, and the power company says I can't run any metal fences parallel to the powerline. It's not because of the magnetic field, because the powerline only carries 1,000A (about the same as the starter motor in a diesel pickup). It's because of the electric field, which is huge due to the 10kV potential between the wire and the ground. This electric field can induce enough voltage in a long parallel metal fence wire to zap you when you touch it, and obviously this saps energy from the powerline.

6:48 Love this graphic, for anyone who (like me) sees it and compares the proton radius with the drawn radius of the electron and is confused by the relative sizes (shouldn't an entire electron be smaller than the radius of a proton?) then here's the explanation: The proton radius is a normal (measurable) radius like we're used to but on a much smaller scale since protons aren't fundamental particles, the electron radius is tricky since technically electrons are point particles with no radius or volume so instead what we call their 'radius' is the distance from the electron's center which the mass and energy will definitely be within.  TLDR: 6:47 visually compares different types of radii, they're correct for what's being talked about but may cause misconceptions if you try and compare electron and proton sizes with that graphic which is mainly the fault of electrons not really have a size and not so much that of the graphic
Nice that you clarify everything, but still the statement that energy (in a DC circuit) does not travel over the wire is wrong and cannot be concluded by anything you measured. You need wires. Everything that you explain is true and indeed energy is transmitted the way you describe and it is visible on the oscilloscope, but that energy is the change of magnetic field - evident that you can clearly see the same peak you see at the beginning if wires are not connected. However, if you attempt to transmit energy this way you will notice LED just blinks and does not remain lit. Once the fields stop oscillating, no energy is transmitted to the LED the way you described. But in case the wires are connected, the LED remains lit up, even after the magnetic and the electric field stops changing. So in conclusion, in a DC circuit energy is transmitted only by conduits that allow electron drift, so energy DO travel OVER the wire. In an AC circuit, you can transmit energy outside of the wire by the magnetic field, so energy does not necessarily travel over the wire and can be transmitted over disconnected plates (like in capacitor). And any DC circuit behaves like an AC circuit for a short time when the voltage (electric potential / electric field) over part of it changes, for example when a switch is flipped. Or the behavior of DC circuit follows dampened system behavior with stable state after it has been closed.

I have a couple of questions, perhaps the most nagging is why do you have to come in contact with a conductor to experience a shock if the power is in fields?
I'm not convinced that magnetic fields carry energy any more than electrons do.  Electrical energy is what results from potential energy being expressed. The *source* of that potential is a battery or generator that delivers voltage to a circuit.  What is inside a battery? It isn't magnetic fields! Charged particles, electrons, aren't sufficient to turn a battery into a magnet. It is a charge imbalance where one end literally has more electrons than the other. These electrons move out into a conductor even if there isn't a completed circuit. This doesn't turn on all our lights because "magnetic fields", it just applies voltage to a conductor. Completing the circuit is how the flow of electrons across a load is accomplished. In the case of a light, the initial field expansion over milliseconds is not representative of how light is produced.  Let's move on to magnetic fields and inductance now. This entire video and the previous are leaning on the initial, and temporary, induction that occurs. In order to induce *voltage* in a conductor, relative motion through lines of flux is required. This means either the field moves or the conductor does. If neither move, there is no induction of voltage happening. In these examples of a DC circuit, the field expands only once and maintains that strength until the circuit is broken or voltage is lost by another means. This initial expansion of the field will not, alone, constitute a successful energization of a circuit. This is merely a byproduct of the electrons flowing and has no meaningful impact on the lights operation.  "When does a magnetic field cross 1 meter?" is not the same thing as explaining power transmission.

This is an RL circuit, the capacitance is negligible, inductance is 11.85uH ( 17:47 )and R is 1.1kOhm ( 18:08 ) which gives the time constant 10ns.  The time constant chosen is too small for experiment. As such the experimental result (50ns/division) is as expected with an RL theory of circuitry. It is too simple to say that energy are transferred to the load almost immediately (1/c) when the result itself shows a risetime that is comparable to the time constant.   To claim that the energy transferred is almost instantaneous (1/c), the oscilloscope has to display something in the order of 1ns/division, and the risetime itself has to be around to the limit of the probe risetime (less than 1ns for 500MHz probe)   As for the plateau, consider using active isolated differential probe instead of using the MATH function (two probe across the load 18:38 ) this might cause inaccurate measurement. Plus, a different result might be obtained with differential probe, it also ensures that this is not a probe grounding issue

Your original video got me thinking about a problem we've been encountering in developing a high speed communications device. If a data pulse, say 100ps long is launched down a long pair of lines, the IC it is aimed at doesn't behave like your lumped elements would expect. The answer is in the fields. The pulse,  gets to the chip, if the pulse becomes distorted in its pair of lines such that it becomes asymmetric, the asymmetry causes the chip to try and draw a little gulp current. That current now chases around on the chip itself reflecting uncontrolledly back and forth (inverting or not depending where). That pulse ensemble can then get out and onto the supplies, although it's attenuated. If you've got a sensitive amplifying IC a millimetre or two away, it'll see the pulses, and to some extent it'll transfer and amplified version of them all onto *it's* output.  The result? "Leakage of the original data onto the received data, and with a measurable time range on the edges equal to the delay time of the pulses moving across the original "interfering" chip. Absolutely fascinating, even if nobody else understands or cares.  Sadly, as always transfering information between humans and getting them to process it, is FAR more difficult than doing that in circuits. These failed prototype products will remain in junk drawer all easily understood and  fixable after seeing your video, but stopped by opinion. *shrug*

I am an industrial automation specialist, and consider myself an expert in electrical circuits. The real takeaway for me is the realization that my concept of electric power has been wrong for 50 years!
There are two distances at play, the 1 m separation between the input and the output termination resistor, and the 10 m  (times 2) length of the transmission line. Light travels 1 m in 3.3 ns, 10 m in 33.3 ns, and 20 m in 66.6 ns. Those are the sort of characteristic durations we should look for on the scope. The scope is set at 50 ns/division.   The two big steps have a period of about 65 ns separating them, so I would attribute that to the 20 m length. The double pulse looks like the signal is bouncing off a mis-terminated end.  I wish you had adjusted the value of the termination resistor to null out the bounce.  BTW, what was the impedance of the driving signal?  But clearly the initial step occurs at far less than what the 20 m or even 10 m length would suggest. In fact, the ringing artifacts I see with ~8 ns cycle makes me wonder if the assembly is resonating and doing a bandpass on ambient RF energy. Or maybe it's just the step that is stimulating the ringing.  Yes, lumped constant analysis is a convenient simplification of Maxwell's equations.   BTW, your setup is very similar to the well-known "folded dipole" antenna.   Thanks.
I think a good analogy, without being too detailed, is something akin to air/water pressure. Not the particles of air/water and how they interact specficially, but the concept of pressure in a confined medium.  If there were a tube in which the contents were already under pressure, prior to the 'battery' being connected, once the 'battery' was connected the flow of the already established pressure would "resume" its flow, as opposed to originating from the 'battery' and having to make the journey all the way around.   Basically, the potential for kinetic interaction in the wires is already present in electrons, and the lattice of the wires themselves move the electrons via the generation of a magnetic field, not by electrons interacting with each other.

The distance to the light bulb and the voltage source does not define the current. Because voltage is a conservative field. Doesn't matter what path you take from point A to point B. It will always be the same increase or decrease in voltage.   If there is resistance in the wire then the current will peak at first. Then later it will reach I = R*V (after about a second).   Sure, there will be a voltage along the path of the wire that depends on the capacitance between the sides and the resistance of the wire. But that happens first when the wire is connected. Depending on how long time it takes for this charge to build up there can be a dip in the electrical output.

Hey Derek, if you‚Äôre reading this, will you please be the bigger man and admit you were wrong? When you initially brought up the question, how long does it take for the bulb to turn on, you confidently answered 1m/c and not total distance divided by the speed of light. You then backed up your claim by explaining that it is in fact the fields that carry the power, not the current or the electrons. So the distance that needs to be transversed is the lateral distance and not longitudinal. This is obviously misleading at best and just wrong at worst. The most technical answer is that it turns ‚Äúon‚Äù two times at two different strengths, the weaker unintended partial on state due to transmission line effects and the intended fully on steady state. Obviously when you‚Äôre asking this question, people are thinking of the fully on state and not the spurious induced partially on state. You've launched something fascinating. Electromagnetic fields are like quantum mechanics. If you think you understand them then you don't. Consider the language used. If you use the word "signal", then you are talking about the transmission of information - how quickly can the lightbulb learn that it is supposed to glow because a switch has been closed. When you use the word "energy", then you are talking about the transmission of "energy" - a concept which no one understands clearly. For example, it is assumed that energy can be located somewhere in time and space. The idea is that there is energy in the battery. In order for the energy to do work, it has to be transferred from the battery to the lightbulb. One day we will understand that energy has quantum attributes. Energy is non-local. Energy does not travel, though it can appear to do so.

Urrrrk.  I don't think anyone is denying that you can induce a voltage in parallel conductors.  That's how radio works, and that's how many electronic components work. The problem is this is not how normal circuits like "a light bulb" work.  If it did, you could make your circuit into an actual circle with a diameter of 6.37 meters (2x10meters of conductor) and your results would be the same.  Showing that the exact same thing happened to the same magnitude in a circle might convince me that there was something more going on than a simple induced voltage, but at the moment this just looks more like smoke and mirrors for the sake of a cheap parlour trick.  Yes current flow can induce voltage, and it can also influence how the current flows in a conductor, but it's not the main way the energy gets to the light bulb.  Similarly Rick Hartley is not concerned about fields as the main motive force in the circuit, he's concerned about ways of minimising the effect of the fields on the circuit.  One of the limiting factors in computers and especially processors is in dealing with those fields and negating the effects - that's why Rick said you had to define the transmission lines - for very high frequencies, the design of the PCB and the processor is critical.  I'm a bit disappointed you used his words to make it seem like he was agreeing with you.

I STILL DON'T UNDERSTAND ANYTHING
Here is all you need to know to understand what is going on here. I'll give you a real basic run down that I learned in my first two years of electrical engineering. Voltage is a POTENTIAL difference in charges. It's charge's equivalent of placing a ball at the top of a steep hill. At the top of the hill the ball has a high potential energy. It's is only high because it is being measured relative to the lowest part of the hill. If suddenly the bottom of the hill rose to the height of the top of the hill, the ball would have no more potential energy despite having done nothing. That is what a multimeter measures, the difference in charge density, that's what volts are. If you measure 10V in relation to ground, and then 5V in relation to ground, but then measure them in relation to each other, you only measure 5v. The reason current flows is because it is attempting to balance out the potential difference. It wants to have an even dispersion of electrons throughout the entire circuit, so it is actually moving electrons from high concentration to low concentration to achieve that neutrality.       Next, moving charges create magnetic fields. So whenever an electron moves, it is creating a magnetic field. If you connect the two ends of a battery, which have a voltage in relation to one another, the electrons are moving through the wire, and thus surrounding that wire is a magnetic field. It's why when you hold a compass up to a nail wrapped in coil the needle points to the circuit. It is being affected by the magnetic field.       And finally that brings us to what we need to understand about what is going on here; a thing called induced current/electromagnetic induction/faraday's law. If I have a magnetic field, from lets say a fridge magnet, and I pass a conductor through that field, it actually has an effect on the electrons in that wire. Remember, moving charges create a magnetic field, so if I'm moving my conductor through a magnetic field, I must then create moving charges. These charges act in a way of repulsion to the magnetic field, as in the electrons inside the conductor move in order to create a magnetic field that OPPOSES the magnetic field they are being moved through, or brought into contact with, or that is moving through them. Think about what would happen if they created a magnetic field in the same direction, which would amplify the field. You would suddenly get a feedback loop where the electrons moving make the field stronger, and the field is making the electrons move, so it makes sense that it would have to oppose said magnetic field to obey conservation of energy. Now understand that like all fields, the sphere of influence is related to the distance from the source. That means the farther you get away from the source, the weaker the field gets, exponentially. For a really strong magnet I can hold a piece of metal a few inches from it and barely feel its strength, but touch the metal to the magnet and it takes all your strength to remove it. That is because the magnetic flux is most dense near the source, and the less dense the flux the less effect the field has.       Finally understand that what is being said in this video is that the induced current in the wire 1m away from the switch, which is created when the switch is closed (thus allowing electrons to flow and a magnetic field to propagate from the wire, inducing a current in the other wire) is strong enough to light the bulb. It's technically true, yes, but it is misleading because it is not equal to the full current that is capable when the EMF propagates the entire wire and the full current is established. You would see the lightbulb light up some percentage of the full brightness it would achieve with the full current based on faraday's law and the distance between the wires, and then after the EMF has propagated the entire wire you would see the bulb light up to full brightness. It's the reason I cannot charge my phone from across the room with my wireless charger, and why your computer doesn't malfunction every time you turn on your toaster or hairdryer. It is definitely not a completely negligible effect, and when used in the correct way can be powerful. It is useful to help understand what is actually occurring in a circuit as well. But the question is misleading because the assumption is that the question is asking when the bulb will light up at the fullest brightness it will achieve, not when it will barely light up due to the induced current in the parallel wire.   P.S.  I know this video is in response to the hundreds of other videos that said what I just said and that it was very well put together and professional. I just wanted to give others the rundown of why this video even needed to be made in the first place.

Nice job of using HFSS to prove your point. A field simulator is always going to give the full picture compared to a lumped model simulator (like Spice) which misses the nuances of the fields unless modelled with a distributed element RLGC network (R and G representing the losses of a real conductor). The only difficulty with HFSS is that you have to set up all the boundary conditions and it becomes non-trivial and not essential for simple circuits. However, HFSS will model real physical devices such as exotic transmission lines, spiral inductors etc in the presence of other interfering devices once the boundary conditions are put into place.

Assuming zero resistance wires, then the final voltage across the load resistor would be 18V (the launch voltage).  With 4V being the initial quick voltage across the resistor, that is about 20 times less than the final power across the resistor (since power is square law related to the voltage).  With an actual LED, it would have been much worse since the LED resistance would no longer match the characteristic impedance of the transmission line. Or you use a resistor with about 1k resistance but then most of the voltage drop (and hence power) is dissipated across the resistor instead of the LED.  Again, very little light would show up.  It was an interesting thought experiment and is best explained with transmission line theory.
