You say the electrons don't carry the charge, they're just moved by the electric field.... So, you're saying that electrons don't cause the field... so where does the field come from?  As an electronic engineer, with some background in physics, 16:49, the way you're demonstrating capacitors, you talk about charge building up on the capacitor... this is how I understand the wire in it's entirety works. The battery has a field, because there are more electrons on one side of it than the other. when you connect that to the wire via a switch, the wire you've just connected experiences a change in charge as the electrons on the negative terminal want to flow into that wire with a lower electron population density. Likewise, Electrons in the wire that you've just connected to the positive terminal want to flow into the battery as it has a lower electron population density. The electrons themselves don't need to move fast at all, it's simply the desire to move from a higher density to a lower density that creates the field, which then propagates down the wire at the speed of light. The electron population as a whole then flows out of the negative terminal of the battery, through the circuit, and into the positive terminal of the battery. With a sufficiently long wire, it could take years, or decades or more before an electron that left the battery enters it again, but it's still the field caused by moving electrons that moves down the wire.  You also mention wireless charging... this is how a transformer works, one circuit has a coil of wire to the energy source (Battery, mains, whatever) that creates an electromagnetic field. this then induces a current in a neighbouring wire (in the phone or tooth brush) to move the electrons in that. You need to use AC, because it's a change in magnetic field that induces a current.  In summery... this is all a bunch of chicken and egg scenario. You claim the chicken (Magnetic field) came first, and creates the egg (causes the flow of electrons)... I claim the egg came first (The electron density differential) and hatches into the chicken (Creates an electric field). Yes, it's Cyclic, A causes B causes A causes B, but which comes first? I'm not saying you're wrong in what you're trying to explain, but disagree with what you say at the start saying that the electrons don't cause electricity to flow.
"1/c seconds" isn't even in dimensions of time... 1 meter divided by the speed of light is.

I think the thing that confuses people is the "field." The field is essentially the manifestation of the wire's electrodynamic system. The can be "made" but it's not a tangible thing like an electron or proton; More of an abstraction of the universe's behaviour!  I think a case-in-point is that you have no electric field unless you have charges, and manipulating the charges changes the field. Sort of like the quantum conundrum where you can't measure a system without changing it. And electric fields are defined as the resulting force on a hypothetical "test charge." But if you were to insert a real charge at any point, the system and field would change!

Brilliant! (Pun intended). When designing RF or low-noise circuits we make judicial use of ground planes. So, for instance, a wire on one side of a circuit board has a ground plane on the opposite side. This quenches the electric field on the transmission line to prevent it from interfering with other (possibly unrelated) circuits on the other side of the circuit board.  It also creates a more controlled transmission line at higher frequencies (such as a sudden switch closure). At higher frequencies, we also run ground planes on either side of the transmission path. On a circuit board, the capacitance of two parallel traces side-by-side becomes non-trival.

You have fallen into a trap.  Fields and Maxwell's equations are not the ultimate; not how things "really" work.  QED (Quantum Electrodynamics) holds that position.   Field equations can be derived from QED with some simplifications (That's way over my head, but some QM professionals have told me that's true.)   Circuit analysis can be derived from fields with some simplifications (i.e. Lumped parameters).  Your theme is to teach that circuit analysis is not the ultimate truth, but never mention QED.   It is common (nearly universal) that professors of electric field theory tout their specialty as the ultimate reality.  That is just as parochial as saying the same about circuits.

Inductance allows electrical forces to skip what people perceive as the "channels" of electricity and pass directly through insulators.  Both points are explained by electric fields, which are what electrons interact with.

The experiment you are doing Heinrich Hertz performed about 140 years ago to prove the existence of EM waves, he managed to get air spark discharges from the energy received by electromagnetic coupling. There is nothing new here, the same effect is being used in many electronic devices, including the oscilloscope you are using.  This actually confirms what everybody was talking about. The parallel wires cross-talk through electromagnetic coupling has large characteristic impedance (>500 Ohm in your case) and the energy being transferred is very small compared to the case of galvanic connection.  When there is a closed circuit for electron movement the magnetic field is being created not only by "displacement current" dD/dt but also by net charge transfer (electric current) which can be larger by many orders of magnitude, leading to much larger Poynting vector magnitude and much intensive power transfer. Even a led lamp usually needs a few watts of power for normal operation which is 3 orders of magnitude stronger than the power transferred via electromagnetic coupling in your case. The same result was being predicted by almost everybody who criticized the first video.

Video comes across as Veritasium trying to save face without admitting that he was incredibly wrong.  He doesn't admit that he was wrong that power in a wire comes from charges pushing on eachother (what he calls "misconception 2"). Instead he tricks the audience into thinking he was right, by misleading them into thinking that this effect occurs inside the wire. The charges ARE pushing on eachother, that's the charges on the outside of the wire! Why are they only on the outside of the wire? Because they all push on each other and don't like being near each other, so they stay as far away as possible and are on the very outside of the wire as a result!  Of course Veritasium didn't explain this because he either doesn't understand this or is trying to save face to get his reputation back. What Veritasium didn't understand was that all of electricity & magnetism is just charged particles being pushed by eachother. His previous video claimed that this wasn't the case and that it came from the "electric field." This comes from a fundamental lack of understanding that the electric field is really just a fancy way of expressing how electrons push against each other. If he first tried to make a video trying to explain what the electric field is (instead of making clickbait that common understanding is wrong), he would have learned this simple fact -- that the electric field is just basically a 3D map of what forces are being applied to electrons (by other electrons).

The time it takes for the light bulb to reliably illuminate is the time it takes for the field to propagate along the whole circuit. The existence of a small, transient transfer of energy across the shortest space between the conductors, in this case taking 1/C seconds is an interesting effect but not one that is particularly important in the case he chose (it could easily be too small to light the bulb).

This video to me seems again very misleading, trying to deflect from the fact that how the "energy is in the fields" statement was characterized by his experiment as "the energy is outside the wire and doesn't need to travel all the distance through the wire". Now it turns out, the absolute most amount of energy is , yes, in the field, BUT on the surface and inside the wire, so it has to travel all the distance along the wire (as you can see in the simulation) to do work. Yes there is a small effect, by electromagnetic / electrostatic fields jumping the air gap due to the wires beeing in parallel and not very far apart, but that only proves that there is a secondary effect called induction. Yes if you use a powerful enough energy source, this secondary "induction effect" would make a weak LED light up, but that was never the question. The question was how energy is (mostly) transfered. Still not 100% correct. The electric field inside the wire is not the cause for the electrons to generate directed motion. The electric field inside the wire is only because of losses in the material. You can see it if you plot the Poynting vector inside the wire. In Maxwell equations current is a separate entity that depends on the curl of the magnetic field and the time derivative of the E Field. Thus for a DC current, the time derivative of the E Field is zero and the current solely depends on the curl of the magnetic field.

I think this video is still misleading. First you claim that the surface fields create the energy flow inside the resistor, but the surface fields are a secondary effect of the field the battery is creating, thus the battery is ultimately the source of any field excitation in your thought experiment. The strongest electric field is still inside and along the wire due to the much higher conductivity (kappa or sigma) of said wire. It is like thinking of newton's cradle and claiming "It is not my hand that transferred energy to the last ball, it was the second last ball" - yes you are correct, but you are talking about a chain reaction that started with the battery, thus the battery is the source of field excitation.   Your other flaw is thinking that fields and charges are any different. Take a look at Maxwell's equation and you will see that they are the same! Charges are fields and fields are charges.  The combined charges inside an arbitrary surface volume are the electric field (lines) pointing outside this surface.  This is why the lumped model works in the first place. In terms of high frequency, the (equivalent) lumped models just become increasingly complex and thus it is easier to think in terms of fields, but both points of view are essentially the same.

All of this confusion stems from the fact that basic science assumes matter as being fundamentally a particle first instead of a wave. The notion that an electron is a solid particle or even has a defined shape is why this subject is confusing. There is no discrete electron "particle" nor are there atomic "particles". They are quantas of energy that behave like particles when they interact. Once science stops thinking in terms of particle matter and instead, look at physics in terms of an infinite void of energy patterns, I think you'll find many things makes more sense because nothing is discrete, nor isolated.

This is rather fascinating since it demonstrates how systems can be explained differently as they become more macroscopic. In other words, you need to zoom out to be able to see the wire as a pipe carrying electrons because that is a logical equivalent, even if what is going down at the quantum/microscopic level is vastly different and more complex. One of my professors said that "Quantum Mechanics has to be able to explain the macroscopic world", yet at the same time we can condense, simplify, and use logical equivalence to explain our everyday phenomena in a much more mundane matter. You don't NEED to know that the normal force is the result of virtual photons bombarding things until they stop moving and don't touch, it can be condensed into 'touching emits force' which is a gross condensation and oversimplification of what is happening on the quantum scale, but works because it is the same end result. In this video, we're told that the water/pipe analogy of electrons is basically a macroscopic oversimplification analogy but is logically equivalent enough to work despite the micro/quantum explanation being vastly more complex and difficult.   To oversimplify, essentially the energy transfer on the small scale is not what it looks like on the big scale we know and love, but the large scale doesn't need to be examined at every small point to work or make sense.

Excellent explanation of how electrical circuits work and how electricity flows through them.  The way electricity flows through a circuit is usually taught is the "electron pushing electron through the wire" method simply because this is an easy way to explain this, although this method leads to great misunderstanding to the true reality, however, it also leads to wide acceptance of the error of the explanation even at the instructor/college professor level. This same kind of mistake (and accompanied acceptance) is seen with the application of Bernoulli's principle to an airplane wing and lift production (the reason for the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing).  I would very much like to see you do a video on the topic of how lift is produced by an airplane wing.  This will be a very challenging concept to sort out.  Even the FAA teaches this incorrectly in their publications (as well as some college professors).  I look forward to this video in the future.  Thanks

What I find weird in this video and the previous is the complete absence of a word that I think for many would make the videos less controversial sounding. Namely "antenna". If we clip off the far ends of the circuit, what's being described is a simple, but quite inefficient, power antenna pair. This immediately suggests that power will start transmitting as soon as signal can reach from the sending antenna to the receiving antenna, but it will be significantly less (but not insignificant) than the original (closed) circuit will reach in equilibrium. Of course, this is exactly what is seen.  I think both videos are good descriptions of what is actually going on, and this one improves on some ambiguities in the first. I guess you need to understand space to get this.  1) Space isn't empty, it's fields. Those fields communicate at "c".  2) Stuff is made of charges. Matter reacts to fields; fields react to matter.   So yes of course you will see those effects. And they will be transient if not sustained by loops (wire or cyclical pulses).   The confusion for people was that loosely expressed distance of "1". "1 meter" would have been better, since "c" is a constant, and astrophysicists just call it "1" anyways.   Electrons do flow in wires, however. And any flowing charge sets up its own magnetic field, which controls the flow of that initial charge ("Fine Structure Constant"). Electron momentum self-interacts, so it isn't strictly correct to say the electricity flows outside the wire (Nor in the dielectric). It's a density gradient. It flows everywhere.   "Electricity doesn't flow JUST in the wires" would have been an alternative title.
Since you appear fond of being picky <grin> ... The poynting vector maths says that in EM waves the electric field and the magnetic are in phase. My question is can you prove it!   If you use say a hall effect to measure MAGNETIC field and a oscillator feeding a wire you can see the electric and magnetic are out of phase. (Or repeat history with a battery, wire and switch over a compass)  We now have magneto resistive and AMR stuff - basically anything in a modern hard drive, these have a high frequency and sensitivity response. Can you use something like that to show they E and B are indeed in phase.  Yes I know I am setting you up with near field and far field stuff. But while poynting vector maths is ok and so far it works, I would contend it is not that well proven experimentally. See also the steady state aka DC current problem - energy flows into the wire at right angles - what the ? See also circular polarization left and right versions exists. Can be decomposed into two orthogonal linear but what happened to the right hand rule...

It sort of proves what you said in the first video but also doesn't. The induced voltage is significantly smaller than the voltage transmitted through the wires which arrives later. It's not what people would imply from the title of your first video. The bulb turns on when the electric field reaches it, true, but then turns truly on when the whole circuit is fully charged. That's different from saying the bulb turns on after 1/c seconds period.  Some power arrives after 1/c and if you keep the wires really close that power is noticeable but full power only arrives after the circuit is complete. That's a much more nuanced answer than what you said in your first video. But hey, it's a interesting experiment and I'm not saying  you were completely wrong either.

I don't agree, the reason there are surface charges is in essence due to the mutual repulsion of like electric charges.  This is because of the Faraday effect, and so the electric field might move along the wire for a nanosecond before the electrons migrate, but once they migrate electrons will have moved to cancel/shield any electric field along the wire.  It is then more about the repulsion/attraction from the charge imbalance across the gap.  If electric fields moved though wires the skin effect wouldn't be a thing.

Sorry buddy, words carry meaning and you (as an individual) don't just get to arbitrarily change them to pretend you weren't wrong.   And the "misconceptions" are not misconceptions. The particle and field models are, for all practical purposes, exactly equivalent. The difference is only semantic. The net effect of all the electrons throughout the entire apparatus acting on a single electron in the wire is equivalent to the effect as measured by the field. Saying that one or the other is the true cause and true nature of reality is not science. That is metaphysics. (And even in such a metaphyical discussion, you need to give your justification, but that was just as absent as your acknowledgment that you stopped doing science). Science deals with correlations between observables. That is it.  It does not make absolute claims. It can not make absolute claims. The possibility for revision is built into its core. You and basically all the other science educators need to stop conflating philosophy and science. It will only ever add confusion. (I have not formed this opinion from a single video. It happens again and again.) Thumbs down.

Still misleading! 18:52 the time between two vertical dashed lines is 50.0ns. Lets count after switching (the green line):   3.3ns the voltage is zero as expected 8.3ns  the voltage is 1V, 0.001A = 0.0001W 13.3ns the voltage is 2V, 0.002A = 0.0004W 18.3 the voltage is 3V, 0.003A = 0.0009W 23.3ns the voltage is 4V, 0.001A = 0.0016W  So to get 1mW you need 8.3ns which is lets say 2.5 times the pointed time of 1m/c and to get the 14-16mW you talk about you need 7 times 1m/c.  Little calculations explanations.  The time between two vertical dashed lines is 50.0ns The voltage start to rise after  ~5ns(1m/c = 3.3ns but well measurements) and it reached the equilibrium of 4 volts after another almost 20ns So 3.3ns is the time after which the current starts to flow, you need another 20 ns to reach the 14 mW equilibrium.(14 mW equilibrium depend of the distance between the wires and the wire surface(thickness)) (I just calculated 4v = 16 mW, maybe 14mW is more correct value)  Derek, this video is much better than the first one but don't make more shocking videos please.

Being DC, this then dropped off, to be replaced by the steady electrical current from the source that had had time to run the length of the wire. I don't think the test indicates that an electrical field, not running through the wires, radiated out and was present on the second conductor.   It seems like what you proved was that the magnetic field created by electricity can create electrical spikes (capacitor style) in nearby conductors? Important point: the characteristic impedance of a transmission line is defined in terms of *distributed* inductance and capacitance, not the total inductance and capacitance. In fact, it's fundamentally different than 'impedance' in ordinary circuits, it's dependent on the wave-behavior of voltage and current in an electrically large circuit, so in transmission line theory we talk about voltage waves and current waves, and their ratio on a transmission line is called the characteristic impedance. It has nothing to do with what you would measure with an LCR meter, or at least it would require a more convoluted interpretation- it's just not the same area of discussion, it doesn't quite make sense to talk about measuring a characteristic impedance directly, you would do it by e.g. imposing boundary conditions (connecting electrically small components to one end and a generator at the other, for example) and measuring the voltage and current at the feed point of the transmission line; a known termination, and you can infer the behavior of the voltage and current waves. But that's not what most people think of when they hear "impedance"

It's a mistake to bring charge carriers into the discussion IMHO, it makes it seem as though the behavior is dependent on quantum effects, or even the discrete nature of electric charge. These phenomena (and any predicted by Maxwell's equations) are classical effects, true whether charge carriers exist or whether charge is a continuous medium. The actual motion of electrons (or any charge carriers) is secondary to the charge density and current density terms which serve as sources classically, and it makes the whole thing confusing when you throw in random mentions of solid state physics. Just look at the fact that people come away from the other video thinking about electrons carrying kinetic energy, something that, while physically true, does not express the dominant factors here (electromagnetic force, or for the field-purists out there, the electromagnetic field). Fundamentally, from a classical perspective, energy is simply a conserved quantity that appears in calculations, and the energy here is dominated by potential energy, not kinetic energy of charge carriers. That all being said, as a thought experiment, considering the behavior of the charge carriers in a circuit is interesting. Just remember that as soon as electrons come into the picture, you're in firm 'quantum' territory, and that's only useful for explaining phenomena that are dominated by quantum effects

Regardless, it's STILL induced electron flow that is doing the job. You still have the two conductors close enough to each other for this induction to function (even though minute). But that effect falls off rapidly according the inverse square law. All this only works for conductors near to one another. Move the conductors several meters from each other and the whole thing falls apart. Thus what you are describing is not universal. It only works, to any appreciable extent, when conductors are relatively close to each other. That is important and something you never really emphasize. I think that is where most of the confusion and misinterpretation lies.   Of course, in the vast majority of real world cases, the conductors involved ARE right next to each other so the effects described work quite well In ordinary life.

At the start of an engineering project, you must determine the least complex simplification that will still result in a successful project. To select more complex simplifications means you are wasting time. This is why no one hires an expert in particle physics to design a bridge.  Sadly, many people confuse the simplifications with what is actually going on.  The worst simplification, IMO, is "current follows the path of least resistance".
You still don't get it. The concept of "field" is a convenient abstraction for engineering calculations but isn't a good explanation of what's actually going on in a circuit, namely electrons being pushed through a medium in every direction through electrical pressure similar to water molecules by mechanical pressure in a pipe. This is why arcs occur, because electrons are literally being pushed through the wire (which we often simplify as the only path for electrons to take because it's such a less resistive path compared to surrounding air). You can invoke "field" like a Harry Potter spell a thousand more times and it won't change that.
When trying to make information accessible to everyone, there will always be some pedantic scientist somewhere that says you're wrong (I do it sometimes, too, since the urge can be impossible to resist).  By simplifying things where everyone can understand, the information will become imprecise.  Imprecision can lead to assumptions that become misconceptions.  That's just how it goes.  The initial information usually wasn't wrong, but the inferences  taken from it may have been.  So it is good to dive back in like this when finding one was misunderstood.

Excellent work on shining a light on this complicated subject.  hehe. I think a difficult thing about this is that the origin of the fields *is* the charges, but those fields direct how the charges accelerate.  It's a feedback cycle.  The Coulomb force is negligible when the charge density is 0, but that's not necessarily the case when wires go around bends and corners. When we look at a corner, we find non-0 charge density on the outside of the bend.  This charge disparity redirects the electric field around the corner, keeping it "in" the wire.  We see the same non-0 charge density on any non-spherical equipotential surface in the electrostatic case, as well.

Although there are no technical errors in the facts presented; there is general impression that whilst the energy travels through the field  that this is primarily outside the cable. This is shown explicitly by the Maxwell's Equations simulations. To give this impression is not a fair representation of the facts; for which I present two arguments.  First, the simulations and the experiment itself refer to transients when the switch is closed. This is completely true and if analysed as frequencies this relates primarily to very high frequencies. The edge shown at 19.07 has a rise time of about 5ns (50ns/div) which suggests components above 200MHz. In this sense, when viewed either as a lumped transmission line model or simply as an antenna then everything explained is correct and true. The energy is contained in the field which at these frequencies has significant power contained in the area surrounding the cables. The cables and the surrounding air make up a combined system. This is NOT the case, however at DC or much lower frequencies. Indeed, the PCB designer presentation given at 21.30 is out of context as this only relates to signals which contain frequencies of interest. These PCB rules are irrelevant for a DC circuit (although decoupling of transients IS important in many DC supplies to distributed systems of ICs - but that is not the point here).  Secondly, the presentation does a superb job (one of the best I've seen) to highlight the relationship between the analysis of Maxwell's Equations and the lumped circuit analysis. This extends to a microscopic/macroscopic linkage between V and E and I and B. Whereby the Poynting vector E X B is equivalent to V * I making the transmission of power in this way evident. Similarly, the dB/dt and dE/dt terms, when considered against dI/dt and dV/dt make the yet more important linkage between Œµ and C and Œº and L. This really leads to the crux of the analysis.  When the transients (higher frequencies) are considered the terms in dB/dt and dE/dt dominate, and the Poynting vector is indeed primarily in the air around the cables; this is all correct. At DC, however, the values of dE/dt and dB/dt vanish and the dominant factor is the current density J. Combined with the voltage potential in the cable this becomes the dominant carrier. Indeed, any field in the cable itself will be extremely small, but as the resistance is small the current density will be very high by comparison. In this scenario the power is most definitely transmitted in the cable, B and E still have important values, as will the corresponding Poynting vector but they will be constant and the value of B and thereby its magnitude will depend only on the current density INSIDE the cable.  None of this is new, indeed the 'skin effect' covers the transition from DC through intermediate frequencies and describes the mechanism whereby the current density having a uniform cross section of a cable at DC slowly migrates to the outside of the cable as the frequency increases, venturing outside as illustrated in the presentation at high frequencies only. Ultimately, of course, if we only consider high frequencies at the moment of closing the switch (as in the presentation) the nearby parts of the circuit become an antenna, and the rest of the circuit - whether it extend to Mars and back becomes irrelevant.  So; the presentation wasn't wrong, but it could be misleading. It would be easy to ask "Why do you need the cables at all?", which of course is a nonsensical question. Completely true for frequencies so high that the electromagnetic wave carries all the energy (such as visible light), although in this case the wave is not normally directed. The particular set-up provided the wave-guide to support power transfer through the vacuum. But it is important to see that this is the exceptional combination of frequency and waveguide. The pedestrian scenario of a circuit and a lightbulb do not lend themselves to this viewpoint in their normal DC environment; in which the current density within the cables is essential. For this reason I do think the presentation is correct but in many ways misleading.

Your initial presentation of the thought experiment with concrete objects immediately rose red flags in the minds of people who believe they have a good understanding of such concrete objects. They spent the rest of the video trying to reconcile their previously held beliefs (or assumptions, or even experiences) with the first idea they were presented (the car battery and light bulb), completely missing the in-depth explanation of what the model was supposed to represent. Even watching a second time wouldn't help, because their mind was already made up that the first information they received was wrong and therefore further information was irrelevant, or must also somehow be wrong.

What you are seeing is the same functionality of all transformers and is no big secret/ mystery. But you have intentionally made it sound otherwise in the first video. The effect only happens during the ramp up and ramp down of energy flow in a DC circuit, which is technically AC, even in a DC circuit, until steady state is reached. When a changing current (AC) is applied to one of two conductors running parallel to each other, a current will be induced in the other conductor. This is how a transformer or inductive charging across an air gap work. And why we use shielded cable for certain circuits. The light is just an indicator, it doesn't need to be there. Additionally, there's the very real problem with the overabundance of information currently, and the schools never really gave people any tools to handle that. It was reserved for the academic world and made practical sense back then, but now we almost have the opposite issue where any person can interact on any topic. Yes, overabundance information can be bad if not treated properly. As we've seen with a lot of conspiracy theories or such is that single debunked, withdrawn, and redacted science articles keep being used as a source of valuable information.  My teacher told me that I need to know the multiplication table even if she woke me up in the middle of the night and forced me to answer what 7 times 8 is as I won't be carrying a calculator in my pocket at all times. This mindset is appropriate before the internet era's biggest breakthrough, 2010-ish or so, when you more often will be forced to make simple calculations on the spot to guide your actions as finding information can take some time. But now, the kids in elementary schools today should be better off if they place a much greater focus on being able to think about *HOW* to go about making a calculation.  Trivial example, but I can demonstrate with thinking about personal economic budget. Say there's certain items you always buy regularly in the grocery store and you always end up using up with consistency, and these items have a heavily reduced price. Sometimes you can buy a lot more than one or two, and they are maybe even half the price or something. The way to think about this should _not_ be to focus on each month separately, and each month's budget. That's harmful in the long term as if you can buy 6 laundry detergents that you _always_ use anyway at the price of 3, then if you are able to break your monthly budget and have space to store it, then you save yourself the cost of 3 laundry detergents in the following year. Repeating this with other items can have quite the impact in the long run. Kids don't need to calculate the price of the laundry detergent at reduced price beyond knowing that it's a lot cheaper and that stocking up will do them good. Creative thinking will only become more important, and often doesn't really require calculations even past "half price is half price". If they do need to make a calculation they have the calculator in their pocket, but knowing how to think will make the kids navigate our society easier.

The problem that still exists in this video is the assumption that the switch is either open or closed (that it changes between open and closed instantly). You have to change the leakage current before you can close the switch. Changing the leakage current doesn't mean that what you're measuring isn't leakage current. What you're measuring there could still be just the changed leakage current.

Borderline philosophical point i want to make deals with "light bulb sensitivity". Yes, a small fraction of energy is transferred at the speed of light across the 1m gap. Yes the inductive coupling of the wires is then responsible for further rise in voltage. All that matches well understood physics models. However the comment about light bulb coming on at the initial low voltage is a cop-out answer. I could argue that a light bulb can be made that turns on with an extremely small amount of current, which is induced by the motion of very small number of quantum entangled electrons at the battery and in the bulb, the information between which is transferred instantly, not at the speed of light; hence the bulb would turn on instantly after closing the switch. Of course this is just a philosophical mumbo-jumbo and has no practical applications for currently existing light emitting technologies. Overall a good video though, which agrees with well understood physics models.

What you see in 1m/c time is not the result of current flowing through the circuit, but the result of a changing electromagnetic field being transmitted from one wire to the other, as when the switch is closed, both wires act as antennas for a short duration of time. You might get a bit of current, but that will decrease by a factor of 1/d¬≤ with the distance of the wires. So if you would put them 2m apart, you'd only get 1/4th of the current. And at 10m it would be 1/100th. No matter how long your wires are. This obviously has no effect on the current flowing *through* the wire. You could also prevent the electromagnetic transmission entirely by shielding the wires and connecting the shield to the ground, because then the electromagnetic field would induce a current in the shield, rather than in the opposite side of the wire. Conclusion: your measurements are the result of arbitrary choices of the setup, completely unrelated to the actual circuit. And yes, the main actors are the fields, but the fields in the wire, not between the wires, and the electrons in the wire are carrying these fields.

Electrons don't "bump" into ions. I understand that this is supposed to be a simplified picture, but it's a completely wrong simplified picture, and I'm getting tired of it. Electrons do not scatter from crystal lattice. They scatter from crystal lattice defects or imperfections. This includes vacancies, misplaced atoms, impurities and thermal vibrations (aka phonons). In ideal crystal at zero temperature there will be no scattering at all. Since all wires are polycrystals, there's also scattering at grain boundaries, but again, no bumping into ions is involved.

As if that's not even enough, a lightbulb that turns on with any amount of flow of electricity, you have proposed a lightbulb with 0 resistance, yet you use a resistor as a stand in for it in your experiment. Excellent video, excellent explanation. This is a topic that's not generally covered when people are trained on electrical circuits. The lumped components approach is a useful model for most everyday needs, even low frequency AC where you supplement Ohm's/Kirchoff's laws by phasor diagrams and  complex impedences. The minute you go to high frequencies you're forever in that transient regime where the switch has just been connected and things become very counter intuitive. You see this in things like the design of radio antennae like the Yagi where induced currents in carefully designed passive elements can be used to focus the electromagnetic energy.

I think one ineresting experiment that would potentially give an even better way of making the point would be to use a system to move the parallel wires to various distances between them, say 1 meter, 50 cm, 25 cm, 10 cm, 5 cm, to demonstrate how this affects both the times involved, as well as the fact that you are looking at a field effect rather than things like leakage. 2 ways to do that would be to use 2 lead screws with a gear between them to reverse them, and a mechanism to either rest the leads upon the lead screws or to create "lead" screws that are half left hand turn, half right hand turn, so that again the process of turning the screws one way or the other brings the parallel span closer or further apart.  I would also recommend that these screws be a non-metallic, or at least a material that is not readily susceptible to magnetic or electric fields so that no one starts complaining that it is the screws that are acting as a surface effect for the current. (and as noted in your video there is such a thing as a surface effect, and even insulators can 'leak' some of this current.   Optionally, adding a third wire, in parallel, with just a load in the middle of the the span, also measured with the same equipment on a third trace, would demonstrate that the effect happens regardless of whether the lines in question are a complete circuit or not. This, in combination with the ability to move the other two wires closer and further apart, would also demonstrate that it's not just someone moving the sample rate on the monitoring equipment between runs.  As a side note, these field effects are exactly why telephone cable, and all of the variety of category 3 on up copper solid and stranded wire cable have twists in them, and cat 6 and 7 cables have different twists on different pairs of strands. As the cable twists, the two wires that are twisted together are not parallel with each other, and you end up with fields that do not have a parallel wire for them to energize. Examples of this done poorly are why many of us grew up with phone lines that might just as well have been party lines, as we heard other people's conversations on our own calls. Those wires are not shorted to our own wires at any point except possibly where they get power from the phone company, That power is (was) generally highly isolated between pairs with filters that would eliminate cross talk there. VoIP phones and phone systems are far less susceptible to this except in facilities where hundreds of long (hundreds of meter long) analog drops happen after the VoIP AT. They have their own share of problems, but you're far less likely to hear the crooks down the street talking about contracts or shading deals.  Have a great day.

Outstanding!  The transmission line model at 16:14 also does a great job of explaining the phenomenon at a lumped element level.  In that sense, each wing of the circuit is a shorted stub, which behaves like a simple short at certain frequencies.  If you fed an AC signal at such a frequency (eg roughly 300/length MHz), it would be as if the long wings weren't there at all.¬† ¬†  What people might find weird is that, if both ends were open, each wing would still behave like a simple short at other AC frequencies, notably 150/length MHz, these lengths in meters.  You could open the ends, drive it at that frequency, and run a light bulb "normally." . This fact is used to measure the electrical length of parallel transmission line:  you can drive one end with an AC signal while leaving the other end open, and finding the lowest frequency where it behaves like a short:  c=fŒª, and the line is¬†Œª/4 at this frequency.  You can also measure the characteristic impedance with similar tricks.

Story time.  Around the time your first video came out my dad was working on a small electronics project. He had a handful of battery powered LED ornaments that he had wired in parallel to a low voltage power supply. It worked when he turned it on, but, to his surprise, switching the ornaments off didn't work.  Even disconnected from the power supply the LED's would slowly dim over several days.  As a certified technician I understood what was happening immediately, but it reminded me of your video.  Magnetic Induction is such a small thing in your average circuit that the short hand explanation is good enough, but with very efficient components like LED's and large (by the standards of an electron) circuits the effects can be interesting sometimes.  Ultimately I told him to use a dpdt switch to short out the circuit in addition to removing the power supply.  In case anyone was curious.

This explanation is still wrong on many levels, as is the interpretation of the experiment. Turning on DC instantaneously is not DC, but AC at many frequencies, including radio frequencies (Fourier expansion of the step function). The RF is transmitted across the wires and leads to a small current through the bulb after a time = distance/c. This contribution quickly dies off when the circuit turns DC (as seen from the brief overshoot). In the steady state, no energy is transmitted across the wires. You can also prove that no appreciable portion of the energy (certainly not all of the energy) is transmitted by fields far from the wires by using coaxial cables. They will work just fine for DC. Also note that household AC behaves essentially as DC, as there is no radio transmission at 50 or 60 Hz. Of course the (net) charges and fields in the wires are on the surfaces, that has been a well-known fact for many decades.

I agree with everything you said, the only inaccuracy in this video is you saying that the Poynting vector indicates the direction of energy flow. It does not.  Imagine a charged capacitor having a constant and time independent electric field E. Now imagine putting a constant and time independent magnetic field normal to the E field using some kind of magnet. The Poynting vector is given by E x B and is nonzero, yet no energy is flowing! We should all agree that no energy is going anywhere because literally nothing is happening.  The solution to this conundrum is as follows:   The only thing that is physically meaningful about the pointing vector is its closed surface integral which tells you the energy flux across that surface. This result is called the Poynting theorem.  In the setup presented in this comment the closed surface integral is always zero.  Great video but this was a common misconception about the Poynting vector.  cheers!  PS I am sorry for my English

GAAA!!!!!! So much diligent effort to propagate another mix of correct and distinctly incorrect ideas.  Correct on the 1m/c time to turn on the LED partially, as easily concluded by identifying this as a simple transmission line problem. But incorrect on other parts, including the assertion that the energy is carried by the field(s) and not by the electrons in the wire. There are multiple phenomena at work, and in a simple battery-lamp circuit, the energy is carried in the wire, or to put it another way, the electrons are lifted to a higher potential energy position in the electric field by the battery and then deliver energy to the lamp by falling down an electric field gradient through the lamp back to the "lower" (electron sparse) end of the battery. Similar to pumping water up the gravity field to a higher potential energy state in a water tower, then piping that high water to a turbine where the water falls down the gravity field, exchanging potential energy (wrt gravity) for kinetic energy of the turbine.  At 5:40 Once you connect a wire, the electric file is no longer that of the battery in free air, so that entire line of argument is false.    At 6:27 The whole argument that it's the surface charges that drive the electron movement in the interior of the wire is highly suspect: If true it would imply that in a coax cable, a steady current along the shield would drive a current on the center conductor, and that is not the case.  So I think this is where Derek starts to conflate "instantaneous" or high frequency effects with what happens at DC (zero frequency).   Much of the discussion revolves around the battery putting energy into the field, and the field somehow delivering the energy to the lamp, unaided by electrons.  *Energy to and from fields*  Yes, you can impart energy to a field, a familiar example being supplying a current to a coil to produce a magnetic field, or charging the electric field of a capacitor. Energy is not required to sustain that field: The capacitor can stay charged with no input of energy, and the coil can sustain the magnetic field if connected as a loop for the current to continue flowing around, as implemented in the superconducting magnets used in MRI machines; very little energy is required after the magnet is started up.  And you can later get the energy back from the field, when you connect a load to the capacitor, or block the current in the coil, the latter idea showing up in the transformers of switch-mode power supplies. (OK there are some complexities:  in practical implementation of both there is an intermediate dielectric or magnetically susceptible material helping things out, but the principle applies to plain components in a vacuum.)  And also you don't get the energy back into the original system if you arrange the apparatus as an antenna where a fluctuating combination of electric and magnetic fields will radiate energy into space instead of maintaining it locally.  *Steady State*  What you can't do is somehow transmit energy via the field alone if it has reached steady state. So a battery cannot be driving a lamp solely by virtue of an unchanging electric or magnetic field.  To have some energy effect, there has to be some dynamic element to the picture, and in the case of the DC battery+lamp, that dynamic element is the movement of the electrons along the electric field gradient in the wire.  At DC there's an (unchanging-in-time) electric field gradient along the wire, in which the electrons both participate in creating that gradient by their distribution of their charges, and are driven along the wire by it, and impart energy to the filament by "falling" down that gradient.  It is the interaction of the elecrons with the electric field along the wire that transports the energy from battery to lamp.  *Fields, not electrons -- only for fluctuating fields*   So statements like 14:12 "because energy is carried by fields and not electrons, it can go straight across the gap" are true for fluctuating fields only, and not for DC steady state, and not even dominant for a range of low but widely-used frequencies. Sure, the simulations demonstrate what happens in the initial nano-seconds of _dynamic_ activity, to correctly predict the 1m/c initial turn-on. But Derek doesn't show what the picture looks like at steady state.  *Rick Hartley misused*  Some twists and turns later, to support his "fields are the main actors that carry the energy (not the electrons)", Derek references Rick Hartley "the energy in the circuit is in the fields" -- this takes Harley wildly out of context. He is speaking about designing PCBs for very high frequencies, where the challenge is to get a fast-changing signal from one location to another, degraded in shape as little as possible, while turning as little as possible of the energy from the rapid fluctuations into unwanted (illegal noise) radio wave radiation. And his main thrust in those lectures is that you must understand return signal's path, moving beyond a naive view of the circuit ground (even if a ground plane) as a steady 0V reference with unlimited ability to absorb transient currents... a  a lesson which,  if taken to heart, invokes a LC transmission line model in which there are inductors in _both_ legs of the line, unlike 16:30 but like Dave Jones at 23:09 and Z Y at 23:13.  The version with inductors in just one leg is fine if treating the line as a 2-terminal black box, but not if trying to probe inside the model at intermediate points.  So Hartley's comments on the matter have little bearing on the steady-state DC battery and lamp situations. In the DC battery/lamp situation is a field involved? Yes, but it's non-changing and energy only gets delivered thanks to the movement of the electrons in that field. Both elements are needed.    *Lumped-elements maligned*  And finally, at 21:13, Derek repeats the "what nobody tells you" theme of "the thought experiment was to reveal something that's normally hidden by the way that we think about and teach electric circuits. You know, we use voltage and current and lumped elements because they're more convenient than working with Maxwell's equations, but we shouldn't forget that the main actors are actually the fields."   .... but but but... anyone whose formal education gets as far as "lumped elements" for transmission lines is surely aware that Maxwell's equations are exactly what's condensed into the R's and C's. The distillation of the problem into a transmission line which can further be distilled into just an impedance, immediately "reveals" the "something" of the 1m/c initial turn-on, including the initial step voltage and current calculated from that impedance.  And repeating -- none of this confirms that "the main actors are actually the fields"... they _can_ be in highly dynamic situations, but DC or low frequency situations are dominated by actual electron movement in a field along the wire, and plain old Ohm's Law.

EM fields are real, they emit and carry momentum and energy without knowing when or what they'll hit and interact with. This crucial concept is perhaps taken for granted by physicists or people who learn UG physics, but it's very easily skipped in schools. As a high school physics teacher, what I really appreciate it the overall conversation about how detailed and "correct" our models should be as we teach. I think many recognize that at each stage of learning, we have to use simplified analogies to help students visualize a system. Each model is correct for the predictions asked of it, but as we approach more  detailed, complex or extreme real-universe scenarios, the simple visualizations break down. Whether it's Newton's Laws of Gravitation moving toward Relativity, or a flowing charge down a wire vs. electromagnetic fields, the simplified model has an important role. The more complete description, however, gives a deeper insight into what is happening in a system. If we can help students understand that models are useful, but incomplete, versions of nature, then they can become the scientists that will push our best models even further.

I don't understand though, how you can explain that the electrons do not flow... but somehow extra electrons end up on the negative side, while electrons are scarce on the positive side. How do you explain how the electrons got out of the battery and into the wire, and then out of the wire on the other side of the load and into the battery, without considering them flowing? That is how the battery loses charge, because the excess of electrons leave one side, and then not necessarily the same exact electrons, but electrons none the less from the other side of the load go into the positive side of the battery and balance out its charge over time. The flow rate is ridiculously slow, but there can't be one conventional description of electrical theory without electron flow theory. That is why amperage, the measure of current flow, is literally define as one coulomb per second. 6.25 x 10^18 electrons through one specific given point per second.

The inrush pulse of current is most likely causing induction from one side of your loop to the other side of your loop (essentially "short circuiting" it), because of the physical design of your experiment and lighting the bulb much faster than the calculated time from using the length of the wires and the speed of light. Once the DC current has stabilised, there is no changing magnetic field and the distance between both sides of your loop doesn't matter any more, hence your statement at 5:41 (that distance between the sides of the loop doesn't matter for brightness of the bulb).  Either do the experiment using an actual, big loop of wire without closely running parallel sections (as you have now), or it won't be taken as the "final, definitive answer" as you are trying to make it.

I'm glad you explained it a bit at the end. Ultimately it is not how electricity actually does real work, but a small undesirable side effect called cross talk. While the closing of the switch will cause an electric field to cause the electrons in the parallel running wire to become excited, it is not really strong enough to do real work. Magnetic fields greatly lose strength with distance. This is how electric generators/motors work after all, this is how transformers work, this is how wireless charging works, in this you are right, but it always requires proximity and loses efficiency with distance squared. Do your software  simulations on a square box of 100m by 100m?  Move your parallel wires 10 meters apart and you will get zero measurable energy transferred by the electric field. Two, the amount of energy transferred to your parallel wires here, is extremely small compared to the energy that can be transferred by the real connected wire, this is just a cross talk effect, it is not how the actual circuit works to do actual useful work at full power. Three, do your simulations not with wires running parallel, but rather at 90 degree angle, and the field transfer will also be a lot smaller, because the field will transfer a lot less energy on crossed wires.

Good video but the electron  doesn't really exist. It's an imaginary particle based on theory to explain how electricity works. People imagine that electrons are like little balls that move through a wire. We never see a pile of electron balls building up in a pile inside the lightbulb. Wires are made of metal so they are actually a reflector of magnetic fields. Nothing travels through a wire. The wire acts like a solid tunnel that a magnetic field flows around but not through. The magnetic field flows around the wire and follows the wire like a train on a track. A positive polarity magnetic field flows around one wire and a negative polarity magnetic field flows around the second wire. When the two opposing magnetic fields meet at the end of the wires inside the lightbulb, the magnetic fields oppose each other and terminate each other in a flash of heat and light. Magntism turns into electricity which powers the load. This is how generators work. A spinning magnetic field induces electricity to flow around a coil of wire. And in the reverse process, electricity moving through a coil of wire will induce a magnetic field around the coil of wire. There are no electrons carrying charges of electricity. The magnetic fields do all the carrying of electricity. I know this is difficult to understand because it's new information. But this is how I understand it.

Derek has not addressed the key learning concepts in their entirety and the question remains poorly posed. In his first video, he did not adequately distinguish between the initial transient field effects and the field effects near the wire surface that will dominate at steady-state. He needed to explain that the evolution of the circuit behavior is highly dependent not only on line and load impedances (as stated), but also on line orientation. I think that both videos would have been improved by exploration of initial circuit behavior with various line orientations. If we twist the circuit near the bulb 180 degrees, for example, we can achieve a transient current that flows in the opposite direction of the steady-state current.

So a few odd things that occur based on the description- 1: If you put a light on the far end of one of the lines (so, halfway between the switch and original light), even though it's half the distance from the switch following the wires, it would actually still turn on half a second later than the light 1 meter away from the switch.  2: The placement of the battery makes no difference, only the placement of the switch itself. You still made a major error with the disconnected or broken circuit part. The segment of wire that will be but isn't initially connected to the switch will be at ground state initially but it is not connected to the ground terminal of the battery so it will lose its ground state almost at the speed of light (as the field propagates) after the switch is closed. This this is because when you close the switch and the segment of broken wire connected to the switch is connected to the charged terminal, the electric field of that segment will be brought to the charge of the terminal it is connected to, thus current will stop flowing from the battery into the segment of wire. This means that the bulb will turn on after 1m/c seconds, but will turn off very shortly after.  Edit: it is analogous to your capacitor part but with a single capacitor. Other than this Good work!

A great follow up video and your clarifications certainly seemed to address most of the confusion around this concept.  One detail I would however question is on the point you made in your original video and also repeated in this video about the assumption that the conductors should be thought of as superconductors.  I would question why you make this statement  - if you simply assumed that the conductors are made of copper then this would make no appreciable difference to either the original or your scaled down model.  Also,  I would question what exactly do you mean by superconducting wires?  If you consider any real superconductors known to man they all still have resistance  - just a lot lower than that for any normal room temperature conducting wire.  So practical superconductors do have resistance so clearly stating that the wires are superconductors doesn't seem to make any real appreciable difference.  If by you statement that we should assume that the wires are superconductors  - you are actually meaning that we should assume zero resistance then I would actually challenge this statement and question if you actually fully appreciate the absurdity of this statement.  Do you actually understand how zero resistance would break the laws of physics?
And this is the reason why radio looks like magic. The lumped element model is insufficient to explain it.  What you did is basically radio-ING your way back to the lumped element model.
Also, yeah, basically a capacitor is just a couple "eloctrodes" i.e. metal or other relative conducting wires or plates, that are separated by a gap which is relatively resistant, whether air, plastic, a vacuum, etc.  and it is the electric field that surrounds them that makes them work.  So it makes perfect sense that the negative charge near the  switch would essentially form a capacitor between it and the light-bulb/led or resistor near it.  Capacitors don't exactly work like a valve or even a one-way valve, but more like Tesla's Valve.  Tesla's valve essentially restricts the flow of water or other fluid one way and lets it flow freely another, but some current still can go the other way.  In any case still a bit different, but althought the electric field and the magnetic field are related, there is a little juice in both.  This is one reason why, for example, traditional car batteries should not be stored on a concrete floor-- the slight moisture in the floor, as well as the concrete itself, creates a slighly conductive, though resisting, surface like a wire, and the air around the electrodes and the concrete form capacitance.  Some electricity will flow through it, and this will not only deplete the battery, but degenerate it as the acid eats the internal electrodes, and deposits the metal ions in the electrolyte onto the plates, effectively ruining the battery. This is still WRONG and has been corrected numerous times by Ron Maimon on Physics StackExchange. In the completely obsolete Drude model, electrons move slowly. In this model, you imagine the current is carried by a classical gas of electrons, and you divide the total current by the density of all electronic charge to get the drift velocity. This predicts a completely bogus drift velocity of a few cm/s, which is total nonsense, because only electrons near the Fermi surface contribute to the conductivity. Nevertheless, you see this hypercorrection repeated endlessly. The best answer: the electronic wavefunctions are spread out in a metal. The correct notion of electron velocity is the Fermi velocity, which is enormous typically, because the wavelength is about 1 atomic radius. While it isn't the same as the speed of electricity going down the wire (which is the speed of the field perturbations, some significant fraction of the speed of light), it is enormously high. Impurities which can scatter electrons will alter this speed, but not as much as the naive hypercorrection says.

Derek.  Video point 14:21 is also misleading.  Cell phone chargers only work with time varying signals (AC).  They don't work with DC.  In your circuit, at the time = 0 seconds when you initially flip the switch, the circuit initially acts like an AC circuit or transient.  However, the circuit will quickly reach equilibrium.  So the light bulb will only turn on briefly.  This is also true for the wire that is is close proximity of the circuit but is not connected.  There will be a momentary current in the floating wire but it will current will stop flowing as soon as it hits equilibrum.  After the electric field is in equilibrium, the circuit is DC.  You circuit is initially a transient (AC) and then changes to DC.  You need wires in order for a  light bulb to stay on when using a DC current.  However, the lightbulb doesn't need wires when using an AC current.  Phone chargers use AC current induction.  Not DC.

OM?! I have to change my pants!  What I've been saying all along-- Electronic's Theory, like any Scientific Theory, is a gross oversimplification that works!  But it isn't the Truth!!  There is a deeper level Theory (or could be) that explains closer to truth what is really going on.   Same reason NASA uses Newtonian Physics to land things on the moon or Mars, etc, but in reality, it is still a gross oversimplification.  But it is one that works very nicely for certain purposes.  However, there is always a deeper explanation.  More than that, no human can know the absolute truth of reality in any way that would be transmitable or understandable to other humans.  And that would not be useful.  Yet people look on many levels how they can understand things according to their purpose.  This is what a Scientific Theory is all about-- "The best _working_ explanation."  Not to say it is the Truth, The Whole Truth, And Nothing But The Truth.  But to say, this particular description works really well for what we are trying to do here, right now, on whatever level that is.  After all, no matter what the theory, it is fundamentally limited by language, the transmission of meaning, and the human mind's ability to simulate that thing.  But it is also the beauty of it.  We can use simplified version of whatever Theory that works for a particular purpose.  And that allows us to do incredible and powerful things!

This is one more time in misleading the audience by trying to avoid being accused of being wrong. The action of turning on a switch would cause EM wave in the space, so yes it would affect the bulb 1 meter away in 1/c seconds. But this is what people call "Interference". It is something engineers work their ass off to minimize. Yet, in your demonstration, you make the source voltage so high and the coupling between the two wires SO big that the interference would be big enough to turn on an bulb. That is never the intension of energy transfer by any sane person. People want controlled energy delivery, so they built wave guide to make sure the energy is delivered exactly when and how we want. Yes, that guide is the wire!!!! The original video was trying to say that the energy is efficiently delivered from the battery to the bulb. If that is true, you can try do one more experiment where you shield all the wires and only leave the bulb very close to the battery. Because then you will only have the coupling between the bulb and the battery without the help of too long wires. You will not turn on anything even you use an LED. You will have wait for the wire guiding the EM wave go all the way through the wire and reach the bulb. The time for the bulb to really turn on is precisely depending on the location of the switch relative the the bulb. At 6:00, there is no gradient of charge on the wire.  This would contradict your previous point that the electron and atom core charges balance.  There is a VERY slight excess of electrons on the negative wire and a balancing deficit on the positive wire; but it us uniformly distributed along the wires and it causes the electric field between the wires and across the battery and resistor.  WHILE current is flowing in the wire, the wire's resistance will require a VERY slight electric field within the wire to keep the charges drifting, but most of the field is perpendicular to the wires except within the resistor and battery.  Any charge gradient is ALWAYS balanced by 1) an electrostatic field or 2) an electrodynamic field and current.  At every point in space, the electric field and the electric potential are affected by EVERY electric charge -- closer and larger charges affect the point more.  Almost everywhere the balanced charges cancel and effectively affect no points in space.  When charges move, the changes in the potential and electric field propagate outward at the speed of light and exert forces on any charges there.  At 19:00, if the resistance matched the transmission line's impedance, there would be no reflection.  Since the reflected voltage is bigger than the initial voltage, the resistance is too big.  Alternately, you could increase the characteristic impedance by moving the wires apart and decreasing C.

Since a Battery is being used, I do not agree with the diagram shown at 4:26 --- 4:48.  In these diagrams, the electrons are shown going through the battery. The electrons will go through a voltage source only if the voltage source was a generator, say one with copper windings being rotated in a magnetic field by a prime mover, where this sort of voltage source does not store electrons but pumps them up continuously. If the generator stops the voltage disappears, but not so in a battery.  A Battery has to first be charged up. So a battery goes on like this. Let us assume that, to start with,  the two plates of a battery, (capacitor)  each have 1000 electrons, hence, the battery is uncharged with no voltage across it.  Then an external voltage charger with copper windings rotating in a magnetic field will rob electrons from one battery plate ( capacitor) to transfer them through the copper wound external voltage source to the other battery plate.  Thus a charged battery could finish up with say  1500 electrons on one plate and 500 electrons on the other plate. When the charger is taken off then the Battery can retain this state of charge indefinitely. Now when a lamp is connected to the battery, the electrons that were moved to the plate with 1500 electrons will travel back to the other plate through the lamp, and slowly the battery will discharge when the plates have no difference and the electrons on each plate are 1000 in number as when the battery was not charged. We can assume that the resistor in the lamp can pass  10 electrons per second flow and this trickle of current will slowly discharge the higher number of electrons to equalize the electrons on the battery plate, where the battery( capacitor) plates need to be large in area/volume to sustain the current flow. Hence the ampere/hour rating of a battery.   A copper wound voltage source, a solar cell, or a current source, unlike a battery with large area plates,  cannot accumulate and transfer many electrons to their terminals. The voltage that appears across the low area of the terminals of the copper winding is through an electromagnetic pumping action inside the voltage source due to the magnetic rate of change. So unlike a battery, a  copper-wound generator is a copper bar of moderate length moving in a magnetic field. The rate of change of the copper bar within the magnetic field will act as a pump in series with the copper bar, pumping electrons from one end of the copper bar through the pump in the bar and over to the other end of the copper bar. As the area of the ends of the copper, the bar is small compared to that of a battery, ( Say 5 electrons on each end)  then the number of electrons finishing on the ends of the copper bar is, let us say 10 electrons on one end, and  0 electrons on the other. It is this difference in electrons that exists between the ends of the copper bar in the rotating generator that causes its voltage potential.  If the resistor in the load lamp is now connected across the terminals of this rotating wound generator and this takes the 10 electrons at one end of the generator and passes these 10 electrons to the other end of the generator copper bar then the electromagnetic rotating pump will quickly pick up the 10 electrons and pumps them up through the copper bar to keep them circulating throughout the circuit, in this case, a series circuit where the electrons will be pumped up from a lower potential to a higher one THORUGH THE ROTATING COPPER WINDINGS/ BARS, IN THE  GENERATOR.   *The electron current flow originating from the previously charged plates with the electron memory store of a battery or a capacitor never goes through the battery.   ( In a capacitor or a battery, there is an AC  displacement current when there is a rate of change of voltages but this displacement current is not an electron conduction current through the  gap between plates of a battery or a capacitor.) *The electron current flow between the ends of a copper bar or wound generator goes through the copper bars. *The electron current flow in a solar cell is not accumulated as in a battery but it is made to flow in the NP junction as in a copper-wound generator by the electromagnetic pumping effect of the sun.   *A transformer does not accumulate electrons as a battery or a capacitor and again, its potential is due to pumping electrons through the copper windings where there is an effective electromagnetic pump pumping them through to make them reach the end of the copper winding.

This kinda reminds me of one of Faraday‚Äôs experiments with transformers. Two separate circuits with coils of wire, one with a battery and switch and the other with a lightbulb/voltmeter. When the battery circuit was switched on or off, the lightbulb flashed/voltmeter picked up a voltage as the changing electric and magnetic fields in the battery coil induced current in the lightbulb coil. This experiment is pretty much the same principle only instead of coils, it‚Äôs long linear parallel wires.

So, in a simple circuit (with a battery and bulb) A battery creates an electric field. Electrons move because of the electric field. (Not because electrons bump into each other)  Thus, the electrons in the bulb, move because of electric field. In the bulb, the electrons transfer the energy to the bulb, lighting it. So, the energy flow is Battery -> electric field -> electrons moving -> bulb.

THIS is how science should be. You suggest a theory - not make a claim, you just suggest something works a certain way and back it up - and then the community challenges it. That's a good thing, if you think a hypothesis sounds wrong, you do the maths, run the experiments, work with the data and try to disprove it. If it can't be disproved, it's accepted. If it can, you accept it as incorrect and we have all that new information and knowledge that didn't match what you thought but is still knowledge.  I know things get pretty heated, especially with the internet allowing basically anyone to weigh in on things with no barrier to entry and it can be difficult to distinguish carefully prepared arguments from opinions or the ol' armchair 'experts' but this is awesome to see, same as the wind powered car argument.  I try and enforce this stuff on the new people I deal with at work who are worried about not knowing things, asking questions, being wrong, feeling 'dumb' or whatever. If someone asks a question, *everyone* should try and help them with an answer. Either your answer is wrong, in which case someone else will correct you - meaning you also learnt something new as well as helping the asker to learn - or you're bang on and you've both reinforced your understanding and taught someone else.  Share information, accept when the facts disprove what you thought, teach others as best you can and try to have an open mind. If someone else disproves Derek, that's just as good a result as if it's proven right since we find the truth either way

The ‚Äúsurface‚Äù claim for the E field is suspicious. The field knows nothing about the surface. The current capability scales according the cross-sectional area, not the surface area. As noted in the video, the resistor is a reduction of cross-sectional area - not surface area. Another proof of this is that the shape of the conductor also has no effect on the field in a DC circuit - a cylindrical conductor of the same cross sectional area produces the same field as a conductor with a square cross section. Your claims of ‚Äúsurface‚Äù depend on frequency, and so does not apply to DC, which is all you have in your battery examples.

Derek, the problem is you title your videos things like "How electricity actually works" and imply there is something wrong with how electricity is taught/understood, and then use a trick/misleading question to "prove" your point. That is very misleading and I think counter to what someone who calls themselves an educator should do.   The problem with your question is you neglect to mention that you apparently define "On" as some voltage above noise/leakage but below 1/4th steady state DC, you also leave out the fact that you assume the load is perfectly matched to the impedance of the transmission lines. Those are some very atyptical and specific assumptions. Obviously, you left it out to trick people and make a bigger reveal. Also, BTW, try applying the full 20V across your little milliwatt LED and get back to us; the "lightbulb" in your example would fry as soon as the DC current arrived (16x the power in your best case experiment that used a perfectly matched load), so it is a pretty silly setup that nobody would expect. That's why people get the "wrong" answer, not because of some misunderstanding of how electricity works.

The trick to getting all electrical engineers in the audience like me to agree with the original explanation was to correctly identify and represent the loop as a transmission line, using a method like lumped sum elements as shown this time.    As soon as one draws the circuit w simple lines, we are encouraged to assume all transmission line like effects are not relevant to the problem, which is the case for the basic problem of supplying power for steady state illumination.   When asked for realistic transient effects from a flawed start, off everyone goes into their own particular assumptions.

The scope at 18:57 still shows the 1m/c answer to be incorrect. At time 1m/s (~3ns), the voltage at the resistor starts to rise as the initial trickle of electric fields reaches it. As more and more of the electric fields manage to reach the resistor (due to participation of increasing length of wire), the voltage rises until it reaches the 4V level. This takes closer to ~12 ns, which is closer to 4m/c.   My original criticism, of there needing to be time for additional length of wire beyond a single point to be involved, still stands. I'll change my answer from 10m/c to 4m/c though, like what's shown in the scope. If the true answer were more like 1.1m/c, then the 1m/c answer would be acceptable, but there is a pretty big difference between 1m/c and 4m/c.
