I design of electric cables as a profession and I still have many issues with this video:  1. Saying that it is a misconception that electrons carry energy from the battery to the bulb is a deceitful way to twist the definition of words to gain a baited reaction from your viewers.  It would be the same as saying that it is not the flowing water in a hose that transports the kinetic energy to a water wheel, it is instead the combined effect of pressure gradients and the flow of atoms, then go into integration of these variables in 3D space just to confuse.  2. You are mixing/using the same explanation for how the light bulb lights for both the steady state and the transient cases.  a. The external electric field in the air is only relevant in the transient case since it relates to the capacitance between the wires and the capacitive charging current when the voltage changes when the switch is flipped. Exactly as in the simulations you show (great simulations by the way) b. In a steady state (DC) case, only the electric field inside the wires themselves is relevant, you can show this by using different voltages applied to metal plates that you wave (like a magician) around the circuit. This waving would drastically change the external electric field, but the current through the resistor would not change. The Poynting vector field at this steady state is not useful in explaining how current flow through the light bulb, in fact it is very hard to find any examples of practical use of the Poynting vector in static fields, not the other way around! In fact in my entire life I have never seen anyone using this in any practical example involving cables to deliver power (hence I am a bit rusty on this topic even though I work with electric and magnetic fields in cables every day).  3. Finally, I agree that this was a thought experiment. However for someone who works with characteristic impedances every day, it was obvious that a light bulb would never light up with the spacing of the wires you had chosen, hence a more experienced person would give the "wrong" answer according to you. Designing a thought experiment that way is bad practice and will divide your audience. I believe you did this intentionally to gain extra views and push over the responsibility of teaching the correct conclusions to others.   For example, you significantly changed the geometric layout of the wires in this video compared to the previous video. You deceptively used copper tubes instead of electric wires, this significantly decreased the characteristic impedance by about 5-10x (higher resistance and lower inductance). You also used a much higher resistance of 1100 ohm, while a normal 12 volt light bulb from previous video would have about 10 ohm resistance (14 W bulb) while fully on, but importantly, the resistance would be about 1/10 of that at low power since the filament is cold = about 1 ohm compared to 1100 ohm in this video.  In this video you had about (4V/20V)^2 = 4 % of the steady state power in the resistor during the initial transient stage. Hardly visible!  In the previous video it would be much worse:  Assuming a characteristic impedance of Zo = 2000 ohm, total Z for left and right loops in series with bulb = 4000 ohm, bulb resistance of ca 1 ohm at low power when cold -> Power in light bulb during initial 1[m]/c period would only be 0.62 ppm of the steady state power!   (12V*1ohm/4001ohm)^2/1ohm/((12V)^2/10ohm) = 6.24e-7

i would say the lumped model still plays the role, just like people use gravity as 9.81 m/s2 at lower atmosphere rather than keep calculating the gravitational force using the Universal Gravitation Equation.   yes the true numbers are different from what we normally used but given the scale of the problem and the error we are tolerated (using significant figures). they are not making any difference in a general scale. if we are looking at a microscopic scale those difference will come out because the units are now really small and even the measurement will need to have more precision (as the video said: a very fast scope, which is another way of saying a very sensitive measuring device).  so the conclusion is how precise do you need to come down to the solution, if we are talking for general purpose just give up and use the general rule of thumb with some tolerated error on it. if you need to be precise then yes go for it but note all the initial measurement need to be precise too.

Let's see. 3:59 No, the electron inside the wire IS NOT accelerated simply by one big electric field gradient. The *higher density of electrons* behind the electron than in front of it (pressure difference) biases each electron to drift forward (pushes it forward). Yes, the 3-D [net] charge density everywhere WANTS TO BE zero. But the [net] charge density of a wire CANNOT BE zero if there is a voltage on the wire. The described "charge gradient" on the wire [surface] is a gradient of *LINEAL CHARGE DENSITY*, which varies above and below zero. The charge gradient coincides with a voltage gradient, which is a local electric field, which pushes the electrons. A region of wire with a voltage on it has more or fewer electrons, by the relationship V = Q / C. C is very small (say 1 pF/ft), so the Q difference is small (1 picocoulomb per volt, per foot). The stored energy is very small. E = ¬ΩCV¬≤, so at 1V, it's 1 pJ (picojoule) per foot;  at 10V it's 100pJ/ft; etc. The "electric field" strength along the wire varies in proportion to its resistivity, NOT the distance along the wire. In steady-state current flow, total resistance decides the current, and current (amps) times resistivity (ohms-per-foot) decides the voltage gradient (volts-per-foot). Your "fields" explanations descriptions match what actually happens in this circuit; okay on that. But you did not hint at the craziness that happens immediately after the switch is closed (traveling pulse and reflections) or how it damps down (rf emission?). You merely asserted that the surface-charge gradient "is established almost instantly (at the speed of light)", without saying why or how. Varying fields are way more complex than static fields. Field theory could, with a lot of work, explain the entire switching-on process and establishment of equilibrium, but Ohm's law explains the equilibrium state quickly and easily. The electric field in the wire "has the same magnitude everywhere" ONLY IF the wire has constant diameter (constant ohms per foot).

The fun thing about your experiment is that utility locators actually have to deal with this every day.  We call it bleed off and it is directly a result of various conductors being in close proximity to each other.  Higher the frequency used, the more likely it is to experience this "bleed off" of signal.  We actually have to carefully curate what frequencies we use to maximize the distance we can locate while also limiting how much bleed off we have.  It's actually a pain with telephone and electric lines that are grounded incorrectly.

The key is that the wire is the pipe for the field to flow to the load with the speed of light.  However, it's not an "ideal" pipe. It's unable to 100% contain the field within it, some could leak out and propagate through the air (also with the speed of light). The amount of leakage depends on how good the shield of the wire is.  The first detecting current in the scope is from the leakage field. The travel time is the distance between the detector (load) and the source of radiation (switch). The detector could be another circuit with a component acting as an antenna to pick up the leakage field.  Meanwhile, another portion of the field goes through the wire and reaches the load within wire_length/c.

@4:42 you explain that in any bounding box that contains several atoms there is a perfect match between charges, no excess of positive and negative, everything matches.    @5:51 you explain that the battery drives a charge surplus and lack in (or on?) the wire.    This is a contradiction, and weakens your argument.     In the steady state, there is a charge imbalance that causes electron flow and energy transfer through the entire volume of the wire. Your sheepdogs are lying down and panting, the electrical and magnetic fields are stationary.    In the initial few nanoseconds you do not have a steady state, but a transient. High-frequency signals such as this do cause EM field changes that induce current flow - but in this simple circuit (no high-frequency signal after that first bit) they are a minor and mostly ignorable contribution. There is also a 'skin effect' that causes a measurable reduction in current flow because the inside of the wire is not available and is why UHF transmitters use hollow tubes instead of solid wire - the center of the conductor doesn't do any work, so why make a center.    Your contention (@21:19, for example) is that this initial flash of EM waves is the *sole mechanism* of energy transfer, and is false as shown by your own experiment and on the screen of that oscilloscope.     It *is* important to realize that transient effects do occur; inside microprocessors and on circuit boards switched at high frequencies they become significant and must be controlled lest you flip gates you didn't intend to.

The important takeaway here is, Derek. Fields, especially, those quirky Quantuium Fields, are real. They affect reality at the macroscopic level. They should not be discounted as purely theoretical, pie in the sky, markings. Understanding that there is OBSCURED MEANING in our theory when working with APPLIED MATHS is imperative.  F=MA  wtf? is not the extent of Physics It is similar to people MISREPRESENTING Special & General Relativity, by excluding the full equations OR the special assumptions that are considered when they are ELLUCIDATED. eg Isotropism, Homogeneity, Relativity, Spontaneity, Locality, etc.
As I prepare to teach circuits 1 for the first time this fall, I both love the debate and different experiments this has driven in the community, but fear the rabbit hole of unproductive debate at the same time. Physicists and Electrical Engineers look at the world through two different lenses - one in fields and Maxwell, and the other in circuits. They are both fine models, and with the right parasitic components (the transmission line LCs), the result is the same.   You did reinforce one mis-conception that I work hard to dispel - by matching the impedance for maximum power transfer in your experiment. By picking your load to match the loop impedance you did in-fact optimize the circuit to get the most instantaneous / transient output (and a bit of a cheat to make the instantaneous transfer look as big as possible vs the steady state power), but then engineers think impedance matching is ALWAYs the right solution. In most power circuits, we are no where close to matched. If the load matches the source impedance, you are 50% efficient, with half the energy lost to the supply. To make any switching power supply, the supply impedance must be as small as possible (to maximize efficiency), and very mis-matched to the load impedance.  If your battery has a 10mOhm source impedance, a 10mOhm load will deliver the maximum power, for a few milliseconds, until the battery explodes!! A car battery with 0.01 ohms source impedance should never see a load below 0.1 Ohms - a >1C discharge rate.  In practice RARELY do we design circuits for maximum power transfer - RF antenna and Solar MPPT inverters aside.

I watched this entire video, the original one (The Big Misconception About Electricity), and a lot of the criticism videos. My big is take away is that scientists, like most human beings, have a really hard time saying "I was wrong." Instead of a "I made a mistake and really didn't represent the physics that well," from Veritasium, we got a "people misunderstood what I was saying and actually I was right all along." It's actually quite disappointing. I hope the producers will actually take the time to read this entire comment and try to do a better job next time.  If you go look at Veritasium's original video, the analysis he conduct was based primarily the Poynting vector of the fields. The discussion is the original video is largely about how these Poynting don't actually follow the wires. He had diagrams where the Poynting vectors start at the battery and terminate at the light bulb. The implication very much being that the important distance in the geometry is the distance between the battery and the bulb.  He discussed steady-state solutions (either DC or AC), rather than transient states as he does in this video. The criticism I had of the original video is that the viewer is left thinking that ALL electrical energy transmission is from radiation, which is not right.  Veritasium doesn't seem to really understand the criticism on causality, at least not based on his discussion in this video. Again, the diagrams and discussion in the original video seemed to imply that the important distance is the distance between the battery and the bulb; *not* the switch and the bulb which is emphasized in this video. So, the questions about causality come in if you *move the switch to an arbitrary distance away and flip it*. The implication in the original video was that the light bulb would immediately because the *battery* was positioned only a meter a way from the bulb. So, I think at least some of the response (certainly mine) and concern about causality was to these diagrams of the Poynting vector imitating from the battery and terminating at the bulb *coupled with the discussion of the time it would take the bulb to light up after a switch is thrown*.    Now, in this video, Veritasium does rightly point out that there is energy that is transmitted via radiation from the wires when a pulse applied. Essentially, Veritasium has built a fairly unsophisticated transmitter/receiver system here.  If the wires were not connected at the end of the ten-meter run, you'd get essentially the same answer for the application of a pulse. In fact, that's how radios work (with a bit more sophistication in the receive circuit).   Importantly, Veritasium triumphs that he successfully transmitted 14 mW of power across the space of a meter. He said he was worry the transmission wouldn't be above the noise. This is a fairly valid worry because his antennas weren't necessarily optimized. But consider this, his setup wouldn't need to be changed *all* that much for the signal to be below the noise. I'm assuming that the wires (the antennas) could be approximated as non-directional, which means the field is going to fall off as 1/r^2. The Friis equation seems to indicate that transmit power also falls off as 1/r^2. So, if I'm doing this right, if we moved the wires just 5 meters apart, the signal would be 25 times smaller or less than a milliWatt. At 10 meter, the receive signal would be 100 times smaller, and so on. Now, technically it will take the signal d/c time to get there, just as in the 1 meter case, but it very rapidly becomes unimpressive.  Another issue is that the producers dismiss voltage and current as important actors in electrical circuits, seeming to describe these as crutches. Instead, they insist, it is the field. This is a confusing point since voltage is a measure of the field. This relevant fact seems to be dismissed.  Ultimately, the problem with this video is similar to the last. It gives the viewer the impression that *most* power transmission is accomplished by radiation, which is clearly not right. The models that we've developed with great success seem to work if we describe the field as mainly being confined to the wire for our steady state analysis. Yes, there are couplings that need to be modeled, but we know how to do that. For transient analysis of closely spaced wires, antenna theory is fairly well developed.   If all Veritasium was trying to communicate is that electricity is *not* a chain in a tube, I think they did a very poor job of this. Yes, electrical power transmission is in the field, but that field is generally thought as being relatively well confined to the wire. It's a change in the field that is moving at the speed of light, and *most* of that change is happening in the wire.

This is so much better than the last video.  The critical takeaway that the wire is acting as an antenna, initially, but as a circuit in the steady-state limit.  You could also consider the other thought experiment, where the wires are infinitely long, but parallel and 1m apart.  In this case the wire acts strictly as an antenna and there is no electronic circuit.  Yes, it transmits power, but it does so poorly compared to the wire in a closed, finite circuit.  I think you could do an excellent follow-up to this leading into antennas.   You're basically knocking on the door here already.  And if you need something else to think about, consider that the Ampere is a measure of Coulombs per second.  A Coulomb is a (large) finite quantity of electrons.  An electron has mass.  An electron cannot move at the speed of light.  If current is fundamentally the movement of electrons then current cannot move at the speed of light.

Oh my, 10 minutes in and he has contradicted himself about three times already. I'll go into one example. He says "electrons don't carry the energy, nor do they push each other through the wire. they are pushed by E-field created by the battery and charges on the surface of the wire". Those charges on the surface ARE caused by (presence/absence of) electrons, same as for the battery, the electrons interact (exert force/push) through those E-fields on other charges (mainly electrons). As those forces are exerted over a distance as the electrons move, work is done and thus the electrons must carry energy.  Whether you consider the energy to be in the E-fields (and B-fields) or in the work done on/through the electrons is a moot point, because IT IS the same system. Not unlike the 'is a photon a wave or particle' debate. The electrons communicate (energy) through E and B-fields.   Until now the video goes something like this: this (simplified) explanation is wrong. I have another explanation that I will pose as the correct explanation. The problem is that is *also* a simplified model of what is happening.   Pushing electrons is simplified microscopic modeling where you ignore the fields E-fields from surfaces charges on a wire is simplified macroscopic modeling, where you ignore the individual electrons.  The latter is more useful from an electrical engineering point of view (where you often don't care about what individual electrons do unless you get to nanometer sized transistors), but that doesn't mean the other model has no merit.  Still it's an improvement over the original video.  If he makes up for it in the rest of the video I'll edit my comment and leave a note later.

There are a couple of dirty tricks here to make the video cooler.( was very nice vidoe with HFSS sims)  1. Confusing voltage, power and energy. 4kohm lamp (unrealistic) has been chosen to end up with a small "voltage" ratio to minimize the difference in "power". With a 4k resistor, the initial power is 4mW, and steady-state power is 100mW (25 times more power). But if a 100-ohm resistor is used, the initial voltage goes down to 100mV( assuming transmision line impedance is constant), but the steady-state remains at 20v. 100uW compared to 4W not very cool (40000 times).  2. Sharp (nano sec ) switching to help produce high-frequency components to make transmission lines effects show more than usual. (No harm since they said they are not trying to be realistic)   4. Measuring he power on resistor that roughly matches the impedance of wire and then applying that amount to an LED separately. lED won't have 4k resistance   5. Wires look like large metallic tubes, not regular wires.  6. Capacitance in the measuring devices ignored.  7. Talks about wireless transmission and confusing AC with "step" signal. If the wires are open at the end (true wireless), the initial signal dies quickly since no actual wave is coming back. So, in reality, the Energy delivered by these capacitors only is 4mW*1us for a step signal. Which is very small.

I realized that the intuition that somehow EM fields must be responsible for transferring energy and not the movement of electrons may be because of not looking at electrical energy transfer as a thermodynamical process.   AT the microscopic (atomic) level the movement of charged particles (electrons, ions) can be driven by different physical forces, the electrostatic force, magnetic forces  or diffusion.  In a wire the electrons are moved by EM fields.   But this rises the question of what moves the electrons in a wire that is hooked up to a chemical battery, considering that batteries  do not generate EM fields.  The answer is similar to Einstein's explanation of diffusion.  Diffusion is directional (from high to low concentration) but this is not the result of a directionally oriented force acting in individual diffusing molecules or particles.  Instead, particles move in each direction with the same probability. Over time, however, this brownian back and forth increases the probability of finding any particle far away from its original location.  Hence, the spot of concentration is spreading out over time.  The energy that drives this is the low entropy : the energy stored in the uneven starting distribution.   The state of the system changes from a high to a low energy one.  In the case of the battery there are 2 oxidation/reduction reactions that are electrically coupled in the battery.  One requires an electron to enter the battery on one side and the other requires an electron to leave at the other side.  Both reactions are energetically favorable, which means that an electron at the first side is more LIKELY to transfer into the battery than to move outwards, and conversely on the other side.   Moreover, if an electron were to jump out of the metal wire on one end this would create a locally increased positive charge in the wire drawing electrons from more distant areas.  Since the electrostatic force is strong this can repeat itself only if the charge imbalance can be neutralized by electrons shifting their positions.  If we connect the ends of the battery (short the battery)  one end of the connecting wire is preferably losing and the other is gaining electrons and  this results in  a unidirectional NET flow along the wire. Of course any particular electron moves quite slowly along the wire but the net flow manifests itself very quickly.   Since current (I) is defined as the relocation of  a number of electrons multiplied by the charge of 1 electron per time, and potential (V) is defined as energy/charge ,   I*V = energy/time, which is electrical power (the amount of energy exerted per unit time).Consequently, I*V*time is the energy needed for (or gained by) the  transfer of 1Coulomb charge across a 1V potential for 1 s duration. Yet another clear evidence that energy is transferred by the movement of electrons.

Having watched both videos and several of the rebuttal/expanding discussions, I hold that you still should have simply acknowledged that it was a poorly worded question and tried to improve from there. My quick rant as a result, would be a brilliant conversation in person, hopefully not too PA over text!  Regarding the choice of components discussion: The debate you have relied on here that "14mW" of light is a "turned-on" lightbulb is still disingenuous at best and misleading. Any reasonable load that would be considered "on" at 14mW cannot reasonably be expected to also be considered equally "on" at 5 times the voltage. Clearly the vast majority of the voltage is seen during the steady state case, and thus it is as reasonable to hold up a bulb that will never turn on during the transient (which would be how most 'real' circuits would be designed, but that could have been a point of discussion if brought up better!). The argument around "for illustrative purposes only" is largely unneeded and nearly a strawman, as it is still perfectly reasonably to argue that without any clarification "turning on at any current" is misleading. *The component choice is irrelevant, the definition of "on" is what matters.* You have used (what I would argue is) a non-standard definition. ie that a voltage significantly lower than steady state, but arbitrarily larger than any noise, is 'on' and equally so to the steady state case.  Placing the video as a "thought experiment" does not change the situation where you have not explained well that we are looking at a transient. And again saying that this is not a question of "how best to wire a lightbulb in your room" is (I think) unnessesarially dismissive. It is on YOU to state that the goal is to describe how to make the light go on fastest, being called out that it does not make physical sense is a result of leaving out the perhaps 20 second explanation that you are arbitrarily defining a MUCH smaller voltage as "good enough".  Final Thoughts:  I feel that as an educational tool this all worked out fine, because of the other explanations and demonstrations. However, making the best of a mistake does not mean we cannot improve! The oscilloscope graphs were likely the most intuitive (and accurate) showcase of the phenomenon; I would take this as a demonstration that you cannot separate out a very specific effect (*without properly explaining that you are doing so*) without causing problems.  Possibly a much more useful goal of your thought experiment would be a discussion of transient vs steady state observations and "wireless" vs "wire guided" fields. The stated goal of showing that fields are the main actors is lost because the choice of "correct" answer has almost nothing to do with an "electrons flowing like water" vs fields comparison, but actually the question of "which field propagation causes how much observed voltage in the load". Caused by the less than desirable choice of setup given the explanation used.

The reason I felt the answer was misleading was not because it was impossible to find a light and battery combo that would turn on faster than 1 second. More because if you have a 5V light, you would typically find a 5V battery to plug into the circuit. Instead, you had to supply 20V. If you had a light that required 20V to turn on, it would not turn on until 1 second after the switch was closed. My assumption is that the load and the source were rated the same. Not that there was a chance you could find a load low enough and a source high enough to make it work. You said "If you want to choose circuit components such that the bulb never goes on, you are welcome to do that..."  I'm not trying to find components to break your answer, I'm trying to find components that a rational electrician would put together in the same circuit. Nobody in their right mind would put a 20V battery and and a 5V bulb in the same circuit without additional protection... such as 1 light-second wires (and I guess also a switch that turns back off after 1 second). Just like Mehdi said, if you have a bulb with a low enough threshold, it doesn't matter whether there's a battery within the same galaxy as the bulb, it will be on. In order to make the thought experiment more interesting than that, we have to set lower limits. Otherwise, it's a meaningless question. The most sensible lower limit to me, was that the voltage of the source matched the rated voltage of the load.

It's been known for 130 years that some energy goes directly across, by either magnetic induction, or electrostatic induction, or together by electromagnetic waves.  But that amount is trivial.   In fact, virtually useless.  You show about 20% of the voltage making it across.  That's about 4% of the power.    Useless except in the most trivial cases where transferring microwatts is acceptable.  In the 1910's this was actually tried, by charlatans  not unlike certain YouTubers, as a way to transfer power.  With 20 miles of wire on each bank of a river.  A little bit of power was shown to go across, but real scientists like Heaviside showed that it was just due to induction.   We are now 110 years past that bunk and debunking.  You'd think the issue would be settled and done.  But there now is  your original video which is highly misleading.  In reality the bulb would light up to 4% for a few nanoseconds.  While you were suggesting like full brightness.  Most people would call that "just plain wrong".   In science we have to be carefully quantitative, not just bandy about words like "lights up".   Science, not your claptrap.  Also your experiment is very flawed.  To do it correctly you need a $7,500 differential scope probe like the Tektronix TDP7000, with sub-nanosecond risetime, not what look like 400Mhz (2.5ns) probes, of unknown matching, of unknown impedance, unknown shielding, and with no visible ground system.   I'd estimate the probes are 50 times less capable than what's required to do an actual quantitatively valid experiment.   Plus one needs to do a slew of null experiments beforehand. This is getting ridiculous. Clickbaity and controversial for no good reason. You don't need a silly setup like this to explain the physics of what happens and you continue to make significant errors in your thought experiments and simulations. Introduction of unnecessary and overcomplicated abstractions like the Poynting vector don't make it any better. So let me sum up the main point: Current is propogated by surface charge, but for significant (or continuous) flow, requires a closed circuit, since the mechanism that propogates the surface charge is still electron movement. Simple, right?  For those who care, let me expand a little: The simulation with the "unconnected" wire is NOT the same as the broken circuit you're comparing it to. In the broken circuit example, the field would propogate along the unconnected segment that has now been connected to the battery, but since the wire is "neutral" and doesn't connect to the "charged up" section of wire on the other side (since it's not a closed circuit), the field generated is minimal and only on one side of the circuit. The system will then very quickly reach equilibrium again. This is not the case in the simulation, where you have a full circuit and another separate wire. Another way it differs is that it doesn't have the switch.. This is significant because the field propogation begins at the point of connection, where the circuit gets "closed". In the simulation it's like having a switch on either side of the battery, but then surely the wires begin in a "neutral" state and are not pre-charged as in your explanation. This also raises the question of the field propogating through the battery vs along a wire. What is the field propogation mechanism there? All a bunch of unnecessary overcomplication, requiring explanation on top of explanation.  Perhaps a more interesting thought experiment would be to have a wire with graduated conductivity, so the centre conducts well, but the outer surface doesn't at all. Is the current still propogated by surface charge and if so, where do you determine the "surface" to be?...

Great, thorough explanation (although a little bit defensive towards the end). My objective to the original was that there was too much hand waving, which made the explanations using a 12-volt battery and large lightbulb misleading for all but the most technical, even if one didn't object to the underlying premise. Something you didn't mention is that the size of the initial current in practice is not only affected by the distance between the conductors but the size of the conductors themselves. In the video, looks like you might have used some very large conductors in your demonstration. Many people did their original analysis using ordinary household wires, and thereby calculated a negligible initial current for a conventional lightbulb. Because many people experience the real world limitations of practical circuits everyday, thought experiments that ignore this experience can be more difficult to understand. The thoroughness of this video helps breakthrough the confusion. Thanks for your diligence and continued excellence.

I experience this a lot as someone deeply into aerodynamics, inorganic chemistry, amateur radio, physics and of course electricity.   In my classes that I took to become an Aircraft Mechanic (A&P) I got the unique opportunity of helping teach aerodynamics of fixed and rotary wing aircraft since I had the opportunities and learned it earlier, eventually I got to help teach some of this to pilots too.  I noticed something rather interesting. The pilots were taught less than the mechanics, and the mechanics less than the engineer, and the engineer far less than exists. The pilots jokingly resent the mechanics for knowing so much and just fixing planes like magic, the mechanics jokingly resent the engineer for designing things in a way not conducive to maintenance, and No one living really knows the extent of everything within the realm of aerospace engineering or aerodynamics. Derek is wrong and can't even admit it, but hides behind "...I could have been more clear..." BS.  His basic ignorance of the subject lies in using a battery, knife switch and light bulb.  None of what he claims is true for DC, i.e. a unipolar energy source that is not changing.  The act of closing the switch creates a pulse, which is not DC!  This DV/DT is equivalent to AC, think of it as the first 1/4 cycle of a sine wave, or half of a pulse.  It is clear on the 'scope trace that it has a rise time from 0 to 5 V, which is charging the inductance of his long copper pipe circuit.  This rise time can be used to calculate the inductance (or it can be directly measured with a precision inductance analyzer or vector network analyzer). This inductance creates a magnetic field which is coupled to the parallel conductor (very inefficiently) and results in the voltage at the load. "Overshoot" is also shown and mentioned looking at the 'scope.  Derek would have a difficult time explaining where this extra 5 volts, greater than the input, comes from and where it goes (hint: inductance).  This is why you can hear the spark plugs of a car on an AM pocket radio many feet away (this is essentially Marconi's  miracle invention: wireless radio).   The high voltage, high current, fast DV/DT creates magnetic field received by the radio's antenna and amplified. The ratio of this in voltage is about 15,000 volts at the spark to the radio's sensitivity of microvolts, the coupling efficiency of less than 1 Billion to 1.  Derek shows his total ignorance again at 14:22 conflating the nanosecond step (pulse) of his switch with the inductive charging of a phone (resonant @~100kHz to 200kHZ AC) and the toothbrush (50/60 Hz AC), both are magnetic coupled transformers with two windings.  More Ignorance at 21:32 where the circuit board designer is speaking about the importance of accommodating high frequency pulses (i.e. DV/DT) in PCBs (Printed Circuit Boards).  This is necessary because while most electronic circuits operate on DC, the rapid ON-OFF (MHz, with GHz equivalent rise/fall times) of the digital circuits can be severely corrupted due to the inductance of the copper traces.  There  are also requirements to meet strict global EMI standards, which requires paying attention to how the signals propagate on the PCB (EMI is interfering electrical noise, as in the car spark plug example above).  This is all necessary because the electrical engineers of the last 30+ years are not taught this at all.  They learn some basic "rules of thumb" to work with this "High Speed" stuff, but no understanding.    None of this has anything to do with his provocative previous video.  Was it unintentional ignorance, or intentional click bait??  Well, he DID get a lot of attention.  Hopefully Derek will get a dead battery in his car, then places some jumper cables in a loop over his engine wiring without connecting them to anything and then tries to start it.  Maybe the disappointment will encourage him to take classes in "Electricity 101-104".

Thinking in terms of fields is not obvious, and the idea was met with some inertia when Maxell presented it too. Lord Kelvin is reported to have said that Maxwell had 'lapsed into mysticism' when Maxwell presented his non-mechanical field theory. See Chapter 13 of Forbes and Mahon's book titled Faraday, Maxwell, and the Electromagnetic field for an account of Maxwell's presentation and how it was received.  While fields are definitely important and fundamental, it is also worth remembering that they are always generated and detected by charges. In fact, the electric field is defined as the force per unit 'test charge'.

Partly speculation:  It may not be the literal 'passing' of an electron through a circuit that carries the energy, but it IS electrons carrying the energy through the circuit though. They both generate and propagate the energy whilst moving to low potential.  The energy they're propagating just happens to literally be a form of electromagnetic energy, aka "light", traveling from one electron to the next as the electrons move to a more stable spot of existence   The electric field is the "leakage" of electrons as they try to balance across a high to low gradient. They're very leaky pots, and it's what they leak that both carries the electrons through the wire and is the force in the circuit. It's caused by the electrons moving through the circuit, solely because they would rather not move through the circuit. They do move, but only because electrons are being forced in with no where to go, and also because electrons are being taken out and leaving deficits.   For the sake of an ELI5 video things are fairly right, though I think some things like electrons bouncing off of a nucleus is a bit inaccurate - supposedly they can go through a nucleus as well. The previous video, responses, and this fallow up are a perfect example of theory vs practice. The theory states there will be power at the bulb, but in practice it's a worthless quantity (in comparison to what the whole system was setup for to begin with) so it practically speaking isn't "real". The people with sufficient theoretical knowledge knew there would be SOME power there, but it isn't the implied "useful" power as derek initially implied in his initial video and certainly not the same or even majority of the power as the circuit was made to operate at. When talking about these kinds of things that seemingly go against convention and practice the nuance is key and even stand-in props are important as it can convey the wrong message to the people who aren't aware of the nuances.

That is totally wrong. The transferred electric energy per unit of time in a wire transmission line is not the EM field in the wire but the total kinetic energy of the charge carriers (i.e. free electrons) in the conductor wire. Fields are potentials not energy.  To transfer electric energy and do work you need charge carriers. The more energy is do be transferred the more carriers you need,  E=QV  where E is the transferred energy, Q is the total charge and V the generated potential difference by the work done on the source (i.e. Electric Power Plant). As you can see from the equation, Q is provided by the charges (i.e. free electrons) in wires and and V by the Power plant generators. The more conductive (i.e. rich in free electric charge carriers) the wires are the more electric energy can me transferred to the consumer of electric power.  A dielectric wire is very poor to non-existing, in the amount of free moving charges (i.e. free electrons) it contains and therefore not suitable for the transfer of electric power. Thus, conductor wires are the best and only choice today for this job for electric power transfer. The confusion comes because it is wrongly communed by some popular science media lately, that large electric power is synonymous with large wireless EM radiation transfer which actually is not true. Electric power transfer depends on electric fermionic charges motion and not on photonic EM radiation.  On the other hand dielectrics like air are suitable for EM radiated signal transfer where power is not so much a concern but we just need to transfer information across space at relative large distances economically.  There are currently no alternatives for demanding electric power transfer and there will be no in the future wireless alternatives (at least what electricity concerns) simply because physics don't allow it.  The best development for more effective electric power transfer would be if we could use superconductive wire technology (i.e. lossless) in the future.

Hi Derek, I appreciate a lot your follow up video. When I first saw it, my initial reaction was to comment that a numerical solution to Maxwell's equation would settle it. This video corrects the original one IN PART, but it makes a DIFFERENT point. When the original video says that the bubble "turns on", every one understands that it turns ON like it would in the STEADY state, not during the transient, for which of course SOME of the energy will be transferred due to an antenna-like transient phenomenon. PLEASE do the QUANTITATIVE simulations to see this. The amount of power transferred through the 1 m gap BEFORE the field runs along the full wire distance is minute because the magnitude of the Poynting vector falls off with the square of the distance (and even 1 meter is sufficient to attenuate it). Besides, only high frequency "quick" transients have any chance to effectively radiate and be reabsorbed near the bulb. You refer to this when you say "wires are more efficient", but again, your are just hiding things under the hug, conveniently, in my opinion, since the original video implied a different point. You might keep the phrase "collide with the LATTICE" to hide some of the 20th century Solid State Physics that followed after Drude's model, phonons, etc, since they are not important to your point, which means to be more pedagogical, as I tend to understand it.

Time depends on physical length of whole circuit.  The initial current is really a demonstration of transmission line effects and capacitance/mutual inductance  between conductors....  If you arrange the thought experiment as a circle of length C with the load and switch  180 degrees apart the distance from load to switch is C/PI  then I'm thinking you will not see current flow till C or C/2  not at C/PI.

Another way to get around the "causality problem": If there is a break far away down the line, you basically have one transmitting and one receiving antenna. When the switch is pressed, a voltage wave in the transmitting wire will start to propagate. The receiving line can pick this up just as your phone communicates with a far away mast. When the voltages has evened out, no signal is any longer transmitted and the light goes out unless it is a closed circuit. I think that what this video cleared out is that for the first moments, we are looking at a dynamical problem whereas the closed-circuit model is valid when we have reached equilibrium.

Nice comeback!  This little experiment touches on three major aspects of electrical engineering.  Basic ohms law, transmission line theory, and RF theory.   Each of these are their own specialized fields.  And probably the most interesting part of this is that, ultimately, how we view circuits depends on what kind of data rates (changing signals on the line) we care about.   So in the old days when I was throwing together 1 MHz 6502 circuits I could have wires hanging out everywhere without much thought and it would work.  But increase that to 10 MHz 10 years later and suddenly we get into the realm of transmission line theory, where the impedance of the traces really begins to matter because reflections start to interfere with the signal.  Push that up into the hundreds of MHz and GHz another decade after that (talking about digital signaling here, not radio), and now we are well into RF theory where we have to care a lot more about where the electric field is actually going, which means we care about the full loop electric field for the signal line pair (now a pair instead of a single signal line that uses the power-plane or the ground-plane for the return),  And, ultimately, push it up even higher, into the Terahertz range, and now we are talking about photonic circuits and everything changes again.  Now signals are being sorted out by silicon combs.  -Matt

12:57 But if the circuit was broken somewhere, it WOULDN'T turn on, because in order for the switch to generate an electrical field, you would have to have a (in this example) positive charge on the other side of the switch to react to when closed. But if the circuit is broken somewhere, the electrons cannot rearrange themselves in a way to create a positive charge, making it impossible to generate an electric field by closing the switch. I think it's great that you admitted the shortcoming in your original video, massive kudos. Perhaps it comes down to semantics about what people consider 'on'. However, I have a bone to pick:  I have a massive, fundamental, issue with someone using simulations to demonstrate their fundamental understanding of something. A simulation is a tool you use once you know what the fundamental (or dominant) physics of your problem is. A simulation can only analyse the physics it was built to approximate. Statements like "You can see it does not flow in the wire" do absolutely nothing for me.  Does the software even attempt to solve for the field inside the wire? This is very poor arguing.  As a case example: I build fluid models (professionally), where you can choose a perfectly incompressible fluid or a weakly compressible one, or hell even a fully compressible one, you can choose to model surface tension or not, you can choose to make it iso-thermal or not, you can choose to make it turbulent or not, you can even choose to simulate phase change or not. Now imagine someone used one of those models, perhaps without surface tension, and then claimed that surface tension had no effect on a particular case? Would this be a reasonable argument? It's a classic straw man, you set it up to get the result you wanted.
What I still fail to grasp is how is this ANY different from a current including a magnetic field, which then propagates to induce an electric current in the other wire?

Yes, this is good. Clears up the vagueness of the first video. I just have one problem with this, maybe it's just semantics, but it's the statement  "the main actors are the fields, they are what carries the energy". Okay, suppose you have a light source shining on a light detector and you stick your hand in the way of the light beam. Now did your hand block the light or was it your hand's shadow? Well it's a pointless question because you can't have the shadow without the hand, and vice versa. Similarly those EM fields don't exist without the moving charge carriers. You can't look at the fields or the charge carriers in isolation, they only exist as part of the system of fields and charges. So can you really say that it's the fields which carry the energy when the fields only exist because of the charges? Fields moving charges, moving charges making fields... the whole system moves energy from point A to point B.

As with everything in science, it all depends on the level of application. Newton's Law of gravitation is perfect for sending missions to mars and calculating orbits, but Einstein's Relativity deepens into the actual reasons behind gravity showing that space-time is not a stage but the leading actor in the whole matter. This doesn't mean that Newton was wrong, it just means that he only could zoom in so far into the matter. This doesn't mean Einstein's Special and General Theory of Relativity is useless, it is in fact needed in many applications where those differences can impact the outcome, for example in practical things like GPS or interpreting correctly what you see through powerful telescopes where gravitational lensing occurs. In this case, is the same, some applications seem to show you can neglect this effect, but others will show you it is important to consider it and even exploit it. We are seeing this now with nanoelectronics and we are gonna see more of this as technology progresses. To be fair, I get why some people thought the previous video was misleading, but if you pay attention you realize he was just trying to expose a point, something fundamental about physics that not many people take into account and he is right.

Brilliant. There is still one remaining question that will cause arguments. The electric field inside the conductor, pushing the electrons. Electromagnetism lectures always say that "the electric field inside a perfect conductor is zero", the reason usually given because the free electrons move to cancel out any applied field. Indeed, a common equation says that the current density at each point of a material is proportional to the electric field, via the relation, J = conductivity x E, but on a perfect conductor conductivity is infinite, so any electric field would result in an infinite current - which is unphysical. The assumption of ideal perfect conductor is therefore complicating your explanation. Indeed, the existence of an electric field moving the electrons inside the conductor causes misconceptions in the limit of perfect conductors.

As you have said, Derek, the setup of your riddle was designed to be illustrative of the way the energy flows in circuits.  But, when do we use wired energy transfer? Do we use it to find out when a switch was closed? I don't think so! I think that is more in the "Information", rather than "Energy" domain. We often use wireless systems for that, and they actually work at the speed of light across the shortest path from the source of the information to the receiver of it. The receiver, usually, needs to be reasonably sensitive, in these cases. The wired method, usually, is reserved for the actual, not a symbolic, power transfer. So, let's, for illustrative purposes, modify your setup a bit.  Let's make your wires a light-day length, instead of a light-second. In addition, let's swap the lamp for a coffee maker (needs reasonable energy to operate...). Now, flick the switch On, Derek. Do you now expect to drink your coffee sooner than in 24Hours ? So, as I said in my comments on the first video, the light is lit by the tiny EM field emited by the "Antenna" you created. - The initial "burst" of current propagate through the antenna, starting after 1/c s and increasing until the current reaches the extermity of the antenna (after 1s). - After another (1+1/c) s, the current reaches the bulb and it becomes fully lit  So if the cable is cut at one extremity, that second step doesn't happen, instead, the current diminishes and the light turns Off. That is the main point for me. You say "we don't need the cable, we're already using wireless charging"... Except for that we have to use AC current, again, just as I said in my comments on the other video. But here all your experiements are done using DC. This is reminiscent of a demo that Walter Lewin did in one of his 8.02 lectures, where he showed that the voltage across a resistor simultaneously had two different values depending on how it was measured, in apparent contradiction of Kirchoff's voltage law. Maxwell's equations are fundemental; the "laws" we use in electrical engineering are only approximations, and most people don't appreciate the assumptions on which they are based and when those assumptions are violated.

Thanks for this great follow-up video and the inspiring explanations! In a spirit of constructive criticism I would like to point out two things that I think could and maybe should be improved.  First, at around 5:04 you show forces on electrons and talk about "equal and opposite forces". But the force arrows that are depicted are not in opposite directions, and since they depend on the distances to the atomic ions, they are not per se equal in magnitude.  Second, the image of the surface charges on the wire circuit around 6:23 rather corresponds to the "Simple circuit" setup in the VPython simulation, i.e. a circuit without a load. In contrast, the "Thin resistor circuit" shows that the surface charges are practically homogeneous on the outer wire, and there only is gradient in the thin resistor wire, which is closer to the situation with the light bulb.  Would you agree?

Electromagnetics is a field theory, so in the general case, solving the field equations is the only way to get an accurate model. In the presence of conductors, the field behavior is modified in such a way that circuit models can hide the mathematical difficulty of a full EM solution with little loss of accuracy. Then we can use lumped impedance models, or characteristic impedances together with Smith charts and/or Bergeron diagrams, to model transmission lines. Or we can use discrete component models if the dimensions of our circuit are small compared to our signal wavelengths.  The other key takeaway is that electrons flowing in wires don't transmit energy, they dissipate it. That is why Poynting vectors will tilt inward towards a conductor carrying a current. The dissipated energy comes from the field.  Hopefully everyone will get it now. But I expect there will be a few holdouts.

Rather than an esoteric thought experiment, a more practical question would be transferring power between a power source and a load while minimizing power loss to the surroundings. If we then add an arbitrary constraint (maybe there is controlled ground and airspace on the direct path between the source and the load) that we can only install equipment that takes a roundabout path between the source and the load, then how much power (as a percentage of the power source) is absorbed by the load as a function of time from when the power source was switched on?  Barring revolutionary breakthroughs in wireless power transmission, the equipment used will be some sort of electrical transmission line, since that will minimize power loss to the surroundings. And the transmission line will confine most of the power to be close to the transmission line. However, no transmission line is perfect, so there will be some power transmitted through the air as electromagnetic waves at close to the speed of light. So when the power source is switched on, there will be a small amount of power that will appear at the load with a delay of the time it takes light in the air to travel in a direct path between the power source and the load.   However, that amount of power will be overwhelmed by the amount that eventually reaches the load with a delay of the time it takes electromagnetic waves to travel the roundabout distance of the transmission line between the power source and the load (and electromagnetic waves travel along the transmission line at a large fraction of the speed of light).  I think the original thought experiment is unfortunate. While it does somewhat explore the concepts of electromagnetic power travelling through the air versus through conductive transmission lines, it does so in a vague and misleading way. And I am still not convinced that Veritasium understands that in any practical situation where one desires to transmit maximum electromagnetic power over a distance, that most of the power will be concentrated near an electrical transmission line and not travelling through the air far from any electrical transmission line.

Even setting up this big experiment, specifically to prove this effect, the result is you can power a tiny LED wirelessly for a nanosecond. The short story: It doesn't matter if its the electrons or electric fields that carry electric energy. Unless I'm not reading your scope right, it's taking 25ns for the output voltage to rise to 4V. That's stretching the phrase "a few nanoseconds" quite a lot! It's also a lot longer than the 1ns it would take light to cross what looks to be a 1 foot gap between the two sides of that circuit.   In the real world there are losses, and problems. Note that the input voltage rise time is 10ns, and not instantaneous. In an idealised circuit where switches close instantaneously, you'd then have a perfect Heaviside step function, which has infinite bandwidth. For the power in that step function to propagate perfectly, everything around it would have to have no losses across an infinite bandwidth too (in both the electric and magnetic domains).

ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING PEDANTRY WARNING!!! Sorry, I couldn't help myself. :D  You're SO CLOSE!!! It is true that it is the E-field in the wire that pushes electrons down the line and so the principle of the fields carrying energy is somewhat accurate. BUT! The E-field outside the wire only plays a part in those first few microseconds after closing the switch. Energy does not continuously flow through the air in this setup.  This is Antenna Theory.  Because you put the source and the load in the center of two long wires, they behave as dipole antennas. A transmitting antenna on the switch side and a receiving antenna on the light bulb side. As demonstrated by the simulations you showed, closing the switch releases a burst of electromagnetic radio energy from the transmitting antenna that is picked up by the receiving antenna on other side. The outward propagation of the radio pulse acts to generate and maintain the E-field in the receiving wire until it collides with the conducting E-field of the battery when they meet on the end. From that point on, the conducting E-field dominates while the radio generated E-field decays to zero.   And it does decay to zero.  Radio energy is only generated when electric fields are changing. That is why all radios are associated with a given radio frequency or electric oscillation. Once all the radio energy generated from closing the switch is dissipated and the circuit enters a steady state of direct current conduction through the wire, no energy is transmitted through the air. If you were to swap the battery for an oscillating power source working at a suitable frequency, only then you could continuously transmit power through the air. You wouldn't need the two sets of wires to be connected at the ends.  Note: Because this experiment is so dependent on antenna theory, it would not work if you shielded the wires (putting each wire in a grounded metal tube, not touching the walls). The shielding would block the radio pulse and you would only have the conducting E-field to rely on. It also wouldn't work if your two lobes of wire extended outwards in the same direction instead of opposite directions. In this case, the positive and negative sides of the radio pulse would couple together on the adjacent wires and mostly cancel out leaving very little radio energy to be picked up by the receiving side. (look up: differential signalling, twisted pair) In either of these cases, the light bulb would not light up until the conducting E-field had propagated all the way down the wires and back up the other side. @Veritasium you would have done well to immediately point out that V=IR only works for stable DC flows, and falls on its face when there's impedance, ie inductors, and your circuit is... wait for it... an inductor.  But so are all circuits.  And the shorthand you refer to is to avoid the complexity of dealing with impedance in simple DC circuits.
I still think that the way in which he talks about the issue is a bit weird. Things are framed as wires vs fields but the fields are a natural extension of the wires. The fields are created by the battery and by the wires. It's not "do the electrons carry the force or do the fields carry the force?" Cause the electrons are perpetrating the field. You can't have one without the other.   The real misconception I think the video is trying to address is the idea that fields are created by the motion of electrons. When in reality fields are created by relative offsets of electrons from protons. As an R&D electrical engineer, I really enjoyed watching this video. It's a difficult topic to address even among electrical engineers, because lumped models are extremely efficient, easy to understand and even a lot of high-level research can be done perfectly with them. Therefore, it's not uncommon for even electrical engineers to have a few or several misconceptions about electricity, since in most non-academic problems it's rarely "necessary" to use Maxwell's equations. But it's important to never forget that the true behavior of electricity lies within them, while everything else are simplifications/abstractions. This video was great in pointing out that particular point, as well as in providing the necessary evidence for it even for someone without a degree in physics or engineering.  Very good job!

A further question I want to ask is for a slightly modified set-up:  Instead of having the battery present on the open circuit initially, the positive and negative side of the battery is connected simultaneously to the wires that are connected to the bulbs. What difference, if any, in the time it takes for the current to flow within the bulb will that cause?  My guess is that it should still function similarly: as the two gaps are bridged, the simultaneous generation of the electric fields will reach the other side at the same time and add together, resulting in identical results.  A point of confusion that I encountered when thinking about this problem is the wires not being initially charged by the battery. This is resolved when I consider that the wires already have an initial unknown charge distribution, the sum of the differences in charge distribution between the wire and the positive and negative sides of the battery would be exactly the same as if the battery is already connected, with an open switch.

I'd used to assign battery charge loss (when disconnected) to chemical losses, but this makes it clear that you can't completely disconnect a battery from its own magnetic field, just reduce the transfer efficiency.
A better way to think of it, all open circuits are capacitors (or they all have a capacitance) because the space between them acts as a dielectric. When you close the switch you cause the fields created by each side to collapse. The speed at which this collapse can FIRST be theoretically detected by an increase in voltage is the distance between the switch and the load that is being measured divided by the speed of magnetic field fluctuations in a vacuum, which is equal to the speed of light (light is in fact just a specific form of electromagnetic radiation). Most of the energy of the wires is carried on the surface in the form of magnetic fields twisting around a wire in a cylinder shaped rotating magnetic field. The rotational direction is the path of travel for the current, if it is always rotating the same way, it is considered D/C and if that direction of rotation keeps reversing at a fixed rate, it is considered A/C. If a coil is formed, the current will move through the middle of it and will move the opposite way on the outside of it due to the sum of the rotational forces of all of the magnetic fields of each of the wires bundled together.

On one side of the coin we have the obvious observation that information and signals pass through air at roughly the speed of light. The information that the switch has been flipped travels at this speed. On the other side we have the observation that meaningful power (90% of steady state) appears gated by the amount of time taken for the system to reach steady state, which is in turn limited by the length of the conductor. Let's phrase the question another way. Can we reach 90% of steady state power delivery faster than the speed of light divided by the conductor length?

There is still an issue with this video's bit about causality. The simulations that demonstrate that a disconnected wire responds to the field are technically true, but it *assumes the wires are close together.* If the circuit were, say, a massive circle instead of being folded in half in a line then it seems like you *would* be receiving information about the bulb faster than the speed of light.

The theory that describes a voltage inside a conductor when it runs parallel to another conductor with an electric field in it. Basically this experiment is a giant capacitor.

The easy way to understand this is the transmission line model you show at 16:50.  Charging the transmission line caps is why you can't tell if the end is open or shorted until the filed reaches the end.    One correction, the field runs down the transmission line at less than the speed of light, referred to as velocity factor.  The end cap won't start to charge until the caps before it has started to charge, which is slower than the speed of light.  If you put the bulb at the end, turn on will be delayed until all the caps in the transmission line are charged.

At 13:20: What I had understood was that the reason for the light bulb to turn on was that the charges were "set up" on the wire "almost instantly" (sic) when the battery was introduced on the system. But if the wire is broken, then the charges wouldn't be introduced in the system. THE THING IS that this still doesn't break causality. The systems takes a while to be set up (he said himself, it's limited "by the speed of light"), and If the system is set up and you break the wire somewhere on the circuit, it will take the same amount of time that it took to set up the system for this "information" to reach the light bulb and possibly turn it off. Again, limited by the speed of light. So, basically, no instant communication folks.  TL;DR: That claim at 13:20 is false if the system was initially set up this way - with the wire broken.

Well this is still pretty defensive and somewhat misleading still. While it may be true that tiny induced current happens in the adjacent wire (regardless of whether it is connected). The actual power to properly light the bulb in the load doesn't happen until the current travels through the all along the wire. Ok so you might need to be aware of fields in unshielded wires inducing current in other wires. But the point is, that the suggestion in the original video was, that *only* the fields carry the energy from 'the ether' to the load and NOT in the wires. And also in that video it was said that thinking of current flowing like water in a pipe or a chain being pulled or electrons being pushed like balls in a tube was stated as being 'wrong'. Whereas back in the everyday real world, clearly the wires are essential for the vast majority of the energy to get to the load and light the bulb properly. Caused by those electric fields propagating *along* the wires. So that videos hypothesis was totally flawed. Which is fine. Just say it. That is the scientific method after all.  For the bulb to fully light requires that the electric field propagates along the wires. This is why we have wires in our homes.  Oh sure you can transfer electricity without wires in a transformer. Over short distances. With many turns if wire. With a lovely iron core to help the fields do that. But no-one is suggesting wireless transmission of power over greater distances (or even at 1m distance) is in any way efficient. If it was we wouldn't have national grids of electrical wires.

I've always had to think about the fields in electrical wires for IT work. If you place your network cables too close to poorly shielded electrical cables (or near fluorescent lighting in particular) the resulting induced noise can impede the network signal to the point of causing slow downs and even complete disconnection. Newer cabling standards are less susceptible to this, but it's still worth routing network cables separate of power wherever possible.

Great video, BUT it *still* doesn't emphasize properly that only a fraction of the energy is carried in that field that crosses the 1m gap. The vast majority of the energy will be channeled along the wire since the metal wire does a great job at channeling the field. Those induced voltages and currents across the air are small in comparison to what comes down the wire. I've seen a lot of questions here where people are confused about this point. Edit: Also note that he uses non insulated really beefy ‚Äúwire‚Äù (really a massive copper rod) for his demo. If he had used ordinary household electrical wire, the insulation would have attenuated the field so much that he would have seen very little induced current.

Veritasium is usually really good, but in this case misleading. The fact is that all electric circuits consist of infinite circuits due to how electromagnetic fields behave. The phenomena shown in the experiment is basic radio transmission (combination of near and far fields), where electromagnetic fields radiate energy through the 'ether' to a receiver located at a distance away. The physical arrangement of the conductors (i.e. parallel at one meter) provides the optimal coupling geometry, without worrying about impedance matching which is used in radio telecommunications, which is frequency dependent and correlated to free space impedance. This video is similar to the first spark gap radio transmission experiments, except they are introducing a long wire which is kind of a "red herring" for the sake of explaining induced currents in parallel wires--as it confuses people that there are actually two paths for current flow. One path is through the wire and the other is through the ether.

Mistake #1: "There are an equal number of negative electrons and positive metal ions in a given space, so their attractive/ repulsive effects cancel out." Nope. The reason that metals conduct and wood doesn't is because the metals have free valence electrons, which can freely move between adjacent atoms without being subject to the attractive forces of the positive nuclei. You're describing an insulator, not a conductor. Moving electrons create magnetic fields. Moving electrons cause an imbalanced electric field. You keep claiming it's not about the electrons, but it is. That is just induced current and not really the steady state current in the initial moments after the switch is closed. When somebody says that a bulb is on, they usually are implying that it is on with sufficient current flowing through it. This experiment just proved that an induced current will flow through the load, which is not really what is implied by turning "on" in everyday language. Additionally, the position of the switch with respect to the load is also important at coming to the 1m/c answer, which was not sufficiently emphasised in the earlier video.
This video is correct but there is a trick, now you are balancing the line (thus obtaining the full load as the E propagates) meanwhile in the original video the line was unbalanced.

This is closer to truth, but still missing some important facts. At the initial transient, charges (electrons) do indeed move *primarily near the surface* (not exactly ON the surface, there is depth involved) but the steady state result is charges (electrons) moving in the entire cross section of the wire.  The fields can't exist without the moving electrons, and the electrons can't move without the fields.  The explanation using characteristic impedance is useful and appreciated. At the initial transient, there is a simple equivalent circuit with resistors representing the energy flowing down the wire pairs, forming a simple voltage divider. You correctly show that a significant amount (but not 100%) of the energy does reach the load almost instantaneously.
While the EE is cool in this, so is the psych.  Questions and thought experiments like this, esp ones intended for edutainment, depend on presenting a scenario with both explicit and implicit idealizations, and leave it to the viewer to figure out which are being used by the speaker and which are not.
I think we oftentimes forget to mention, that all these models we use to explain and predict have their distinct purpose and frame. The high resolution models (Maxwells equations) are usually closest to what happens, but also mostly too impractical for most circumstances.

I do like to point out there are no such thing as E or B fields, as electromagnetism is one object and E or M is a relativistic alternative viewpoint humans make. All electric phenomena is magnetic and vice versa from the appropriate frame of reference. A magnet moving causing potential at slow speeds (relative to c) really hammers home how potent Lorentian effects are when it comes to electricity dense media like a metal bar. Similarly whether it's the charge or field acting as primary, since they both occur together, ascribing one as the cause and other effect is purely arbitrary to ease our human understanding.

I still believe the original video was deceptive for the following reason: Everyone who knows some EM knows that closing the switch will immediately send some EM waves to the other side of the circuit that will create some current, so the existence of a fraction of the original current is quite trivial. At the same time since causality has to respect the speed of light it is impossible that the full current can apply after 1/c seconds, after all who knows if the wires havent been cut. So it is trivial to state that some current applies. What you should have done is to QUANTIFY how strong this current is as a fraction of the normal one. If that is a surprisingly large number then you have something noteworthy to teach, and I think ~1/4 as in your example is quite high indeed. But without the quantification you aren't making much of a statement. Besides that not.stating that it doesn't matter if the wires are open or closed is deceptive because it makes it seem like this whole thing is about a closed circuit and not two antennas, which is imo a much better description.

Wrt average charge density being zero: only approximately. Any transient state of an electric system involves charge density fluctuations; and its only bound perfectly to the surface in a quasistatic approximation where the finite internal resistances are no longer important and charge can fully redistribute to the surface.   Its a bit chicken and egg to wonder if it is the EM fields or the electrons pushing the electrons along. While the only immediate cause of motion of electrons is EM fields; there is only one cause of EM fields; which is a nonzero density of charge. Any current or voltage source boils down to such a nonzero charge density, or relative motions thereof.

An objection to the illustrative animations:  We see electrons bouncing off the atomic nuclei of the lattice.  We see little negatively labeled circles impacting and bouncing off the large positively labeled circles.  This animation thus indicates a repulsion between them.  Why?  Electrons are negatively charged.  The nuclei are positively charged.  Shouldn't we see an attraction?  Shouldn't each electron move faster as it approaches a nucleus, and then be scattered off in some direction after the closest approach?  I think the energy should be transferred from electron to atomic nuclei via an attractive scattering process, rather than a repulsive bouncing-off event.

I believe this illustrates an important philosophical idea. As a physics student I would frequently encounter the notion that we use certain math and models because they work, that is there is a correspondence between the prediction a certain model makes and results from experiment. Not there is something wrong with proceeding that in order to gain understanding, but it's important to recognize when your model is just a convient tool and when it corresponds it actual reality. I wonder if there is not some opportunity to discover "new physics" if we reexamine old assumptions. Thinking of a circuit like water in a pipe is a convenient tool for conceptualizing and solving a certain set of problems, but it's not true. What mistakes are we making because we try to extend faulty and incorrect models into other aspects of physics?

This is how I understood the circuit to work, but I do have some issue with the explanation.  As was demonstrated‚Ä¶ You get the near instant current of the 1m/c but it is not at the full voltage and amperage that the circuit is cable of given the power source and components of the circuit.  After the energy of the field travels down the wires at the speed of light, the full power of the circuit will be in effect, and then you see full voltage and amperage of the circuit. This initial spike and then ramp to full power is what you see on the oscilloscope plot shown.  The only problem I have with the explanation as given, is that while yes, that initial energy you see in the experiment would in fact light up a LED, it would not power up any light source that actually exhibited the 1100 ohm resistance you used.  Had you actually used an LED that could run on the amount of power you seen, I believe the initial power would have been smaller. Or in other words, with a load of 1100 ohms, you see an initial 14mW of power, then the ramp to full power, but a smaller load (typical of a small LED capable of running on 14mW) would see a smaller initial power across the load, followed by the ramp to full 14mW power of the circuit.  Maybe I am wrong on that, and the 14mW seen is just a natural result of the other conditions of the experiment, that are independent of the load. And that a load of another value would have shown similar initial power across it.

Someone should take the analogy of the electron flow here and replace it with a hydraulic equivalence. Electric charge would be pressure difference, and you could actually do almost all of the same comparisons with a slight change in terminology.  The notion that the water isn't pushing on itself to go through the pipeline seems very disconnected from real experiences, and the same is true for electrons in DC steady state.  I will admit that the maths work out, and that this view of energy flow has its place in very high frequency applications, but even then we are talking about GHz ranges, which is a very niche field. Any explanation that mainly fits such a niche field should have a fitting disclaimer.
Someone once described electricity as "not so much a thing but rather a way in which things behave"  The conductor is "electrified" and not "carrying" electricity. The concept of negative and positive electron flow is what confuses most people. Also using water as an example of how electricity works is the worst thing any educator ever came up with. I tend to disagree with the possibility for the induced current to immediately light the bulb. Yes, if there were bridging capacitors along the length of the wire, then that is different. As you have stated, they will act as a dead short circuit for a short period of time. Without such capacitors, you have very little induced energy which reduces even more the greater the gap between source and load. If it were two individual circuits which were placed one over the other, you would get the same induced voltage across each separate circuit, regardless of which source was switched on. It would be a measurable change at each load, but only the load attached to the switched on source would eventually light up. Either way, no speed of light violation has taken place, because the induction was across a short distance at 'C' not over the full length of wire.
