When I was a systems engineering student, I had an electronics professor who told us that the explanations he gave us were based on a rudimentary model (analogy based on the flow of water) that allowed us to solve problems and predict the behavior of electromagnetic phenomena and not to worry about anything else. Despite having taken physics courses in which we talked about Maxwell's equations and Lorentz's force law, we were more comfortable using the analogies that involved the traditional model of the flow of electrons through a wire and we thought that at the quantum level this was a problem reserved for theoretical physicists. But when trying to solve problems involving electromagnetic induction, radio waves, etc. I clearly felt I had to deepen my knowledge and delve into how things really work. I only regret that, 22 years ago, I did not have access to explanations of this level, because when I finished the engineering degree I had more doubts than when I entered the course.

The disconnected wire simulation shows this quite well - The entire setup is a broadcasting and receiving antenna with extra stuff at the ends that eventually completes a loop, simply missing the circuitry to transmit additional information. If the initial question that created this discussion had been "How long does it take for a radio receiver to see a signal from a transmitter 1 meter away", then the 1 meter answer would always have been the clear answer. You obscured this point by putting focus on the amount of power received, because anyone with even a passing understanding of radio knows that power is sent through the air electromagnetically, but it's quite weak compared to the input power.  I feel that drawing this comparison is a much more natural way to understand the subject at hand.

In this experiment, the wires are ~1 ft apart. 1 ft/c is approximately 1ns. Your graph shows 50ns per division. You're not seeing 5V until ~30 ns after the circuit closes, or about the time light would take to travel the 10m length of the circuit. So the graph actually disproves the claim that you get appreciable current at time 1/c. The explanation of what is happening is good, though.

I think the major misconception is coming from the DC source, the moment the switch connects, the rising current behaves exactly the same as the rising current from an AC source. Any practical demonstration of a tesla coil will more than happily demonstrate what happens to a conductor in proximity to a changing electric field. Practically speaking, the circuit acts under inductive coupling until the circuit reaches DC steady state and the electric field quiesces. One would expect an active flux of photons to be emitted, and unsurprisingly, connecting a reasonably powerful DC circuit will creates noticable RF interference in nearby electronics, e.g. audible amplitude spikes in audio equipment.

Isn't this whole thing just an over examination of induction? The small voltage seen in the top wire when the switch closes is just the induction from the change in the current from the lower wire. It is very small and doesn't make sense to say that it would turn on the bulb. You would size your battery to have the voltage required by the bulb (a 12v battery for a 12v bulb), and the voltage given by the induction would be just a fraction of that, not enough to actually power it on visibly. Also, since it is not alternating current, the change in current only happens when the switch closes and thus the induction would stop very soon after that. Alpha Phenix's video shows this, when he does the experiment with the circuit cut at the curve of the wires.

The Physics based explanation at 5 minutes is at the same time a gross oversimplification and an unnecessary complication. You can't just assume electrons to be point particles and then talk about their effect on the overall field and claim it to be homogenous. Describing electrons as wavefunctions makes much more intrinsic sense when looking at how electric fields propagate around charge carriers. Following on from this, the constant reference to transfer of kinetic energy from moving electrons colliding with nuclei seems strange as universities would use language such as interact, as there is no tenable collision between the two bodies. Should an electron truly collide with a nucleus one would see the phenomenon of "electron capture". In a wire, this wouldn't happen as the weak force would forbid it. It is also not very useful to use terms such as "essentially the speed of light" when you're discussing events that occur around the speed of light, as you're discounting the entire timeframe of said event.  Lastly, why are we attempting to describe potential with sheep and sheepdogs when the use of a gravity analogy works much better and more concisely. The lightbulb is a dam, the wires are rivers above and below the dam and the battery is a pump that raises the water's potential but pumping it uphill. The whole analogy used in this video is claiming that the electrons do not transfer the energy, however, without electrons in the system, there is no energy transfer. I believe Derek has become confused by the wave particle duality of electrons. You can't have a river without water and you can't have an electric field without a source of charge.  It's a strange hill to die on. Everyone knows that electrical fields propagate from their source and that you could get energy out of the field by having charges (or a wire) within it. I don't understand the need to have a circuit at all when you could just use a capacitor to demonstrate the same effect then you don't have to worry about such small timeframes.

I don't think people were doubting the explanation, just the oversimplifications and inaccuracy of the explanation itself. For example, you say that that what carries the energy is not electrons, but the electric field. However, what you're failing to express is that the electric field is created by the surge or electrons (change in flux due to the electrons moving). This electric field, created by the electrons, is causing the electrons near the load to carry the energy to the bulb. So by this model, the electrons are in fact carrying the energy; not continuously through the circuit, but carrying energy nonetheless.

14:10 I still take some issue with how you responded to that point in particular. Most people that took issue with your original video (including me) are well aware that antennas exist and so knew that some energy would be transmitted directly from the switch, through free space and to the load. BUT the crucial point is that the way you presented it, it seemed as if you were saying that the Poynting vector would mainly or at least with a serious magnitude point directly away. You can clearly see that this is not the case in this simulation, the Poynting vector is highly localized around the conductor. Which brings me to yet another point, the initial assumption assumed (near) ideal conductors, this would even further localize the Poynting vector around the conductor with a minuscule magnitude Poynting away from it towards the load.  So the way you should have said it is that the majority of the energy is not just transmitted through free space but rather it is mainly localized around the conductor, with a very small part being transmitted directly through free space towards the load.

Regarding the broken circuit case: you're assuming a charge potential exists across the switch to the free section of wire, but this charge is not guaranteed to exist or to be any particular value, so it's not strictly analogous to the case of a free section of wire next to an unbroken circuit.  IF the free section of wire was initially hooked up to the circuit long enough for the charges to settle, and then the circuit was broken in a way that the static charge did not dissipate, this is when you'd see the movement of charges identical to the unbroken circuit case until the field changes hit the break in the wire and reflect back.

You still have a pretty large misconception: you have assumed that electrons are objects. In reality a "single electron" can exists all the way through the circuit,  because in conductors there are delocalized electrons. But the "single electron concept" is a faulty assumption in itself. If you assume that electrons are objects with each with their own probability distribution in space, and you also assume that the Pauli exclusion principle holds, you can solve the Shr√∂dinger equation in matter. The results are really enlightening, because  it turns out that the solution, the electron cloud, is actually _independent_ of how you mix the electrons (mixing as in multiplying them with an orthogonal or unitary matrix). Electrons similar to photons only behave as discrete objects if you force them with an experiment. Inside the conductor, they have free reign, so much that not even nature can tell which electron has bumped into the given atom, because they are fundamentally not being distinguished.

Great visualization of current being about mass flow and not speed. üòÅ  One further error to correct from a battery engineer: there is a difference between current induced by a field and current generated from an electrochemical battery. You show the electrons passing through the battery, but in most batteries we use at home, electrons are drained from the anode material and deposited at the cathode, with whole ions moving around in internal fluid to balance the charge. While this doesn't affect the speed of the electron, the voltage and current are heavily dependent on the potency of the overall reaction and movement speed of these balancing ions.

As I pointed out in the last video, I think the main sticking point was, while your explanation is correct, it didn't make it clear enough that the electrons flowing through the wire are not just pawns that have no role in the energy transfer, but that their flow enables the creation of the charge distribution and current that create the fields that in turn transfer the energy. If the electrons were not flowing all the way through the wire, they would stop where the wire stopped and then lead to the creation of a charge and current distribution that would create a field that didn't transfer any energy, at least after the first moments.  So the electron flow is still vitally important for explaining the process, not just a passive side effect.

After a video was posted in which Muller is shown driving a wind-powered car, equipped with a huge spinning propeller, faster than the wind, UCLA physics professor¬†Alexander Kusenko¬†disagreed with the claim that sailing downwind faster than wind was possible within the laws of physics, and made a¬†scientific wager¬†with Muller $10,000 that he could not demonstrate that the apparent greater speed was not due to other, incidental factors. Muller took up the bet, and the signing of a wager agreement by the parties was witnessed by¬†Bill Nye¬†and¬†Neil deGrasse Tyson. In a subsequent video, Muller demonstrated the effect with a model cart under conditions ruling out extraneous effects. Kusenko conceded the bet.

I very much liked this 2nd video. Specifically the explanation about the "simplified math" that is utilized to design / analyze electric circuits.  I think this whole thought experiment does exactly what it should do, taking a look at the theoretical possibilities, vs the practical and then expanding on the how and why. To me there was always an intuitive sense that if you have a physical particle like an electron that has to travel across a distance, then that should take a certain amount of time, and given that it is a particle, it seems like this should take an amount of time that is longer than a beam of light. So in a thought experiment, you can create an ideal condition (superconductors etc.), but in practicality it can't be demonstrated.  I always thought that mathematics is just a language we use to describe natural phenomenon as best we can. The more complex the math we use, the better it explains the phenomenon, but it does not necessarily need to be that complex to describe it enough for practical applications. Hence, a thought experiment vs. a practical application is like complex math vs. simple (i.e. practical).

i believe electroboom's explanation does not contradict your point at all. in his simulation using transmission line model there is indeed small voltage bump (relatively large to leak current) which comes instantly after the switch is closed (due to direct capacitor connection to the bulb). his argument is just that this initial voltage bump, although larger than leakage is still small enough that it cannot turn on the bulb.   and for the voltage to gradually steps up from the initial bump (with ladder shape) waves need to reflect back and forth the transmission line which takes some time.   you only brought up his argument about the leak current which is quite unfair in my opinion. he brought up the leak current argument because in the initial problem you said that the bulb turns on at any current level.  i believe electroboom did not dispute that the field reaches the lamp at 1/c (in his simulation he shows that voltage is indeed induced almost instantaneously ). he just argues that this initial instantaneous field which only induces small voltage bump will not be enough to turn on the lamp, which i believe is a reasonable argument  in conclusion,  1. yes indeed the fields get into the lamp within 1/c second. this field as you said, carry energy to the lamp. this fact is completely correct 2. however, whether this initial field carry ENOUGH energy to turn on the light bulb or not is a completely different matter.  3. electroboom argues that this initial field which only causes small voltage bump to the bulb will not be enough to turn on the light, and we have to wait until the voltage steps up higher for the light bulb to turn on

The thumbnail of the original video says that electricity does not flow inside wires. This, even after the second video, is not fully addressed clickbait.  You totally do not address conductor thickness or frequency. You do not mention alternating current (at least in the second video).  Your example of inductive charging showing that wires are optional doesn't mean that electricity doesn't flow in wires. You can not build an inductive charger without wires, and when you build one you design it for a certain frequency. They do not work for DC.  If you performed your experiment with one end disconnected, you did not show the footage. With one end disconnected, there would not be full battery voltage across the switch, so closing the switch would do almost nothing. This would be a failed assertion in your original video that you did not address here.  Even in microwave waveguides where it's clear that energy is being transmitted outside of wires, wires are vital at both ends of the waveguide, and the energy transmitted inside the waveguide is electromagnetic radiation. Not "electricity".  While you have effectively shown that electrons are like sheep pushed along by electric fields, wires are a vital piece of the equation, electricity flows in wires.  In DC power transmission lines, the entire cross-section of the conductor "carries" current. And nearby conductive elements are irrelevant as long as the dielectric strength of the insulation is sufficient. And I'm not referring to a brief moment when the transmission line is brought into service or shutdown, I'm referring to years of service between those brief transient conditions.

At 19:00 we see this amounts to about 4 volts out of 20. 20% is nothing to sneeze at, but if the question is framed as "How long does it take the light bulb to *turn on* ?" that creates some (imo unfair) ambiguity. The knee-jerk interpretation is a binary one where the bulb is either on or off. It would be more comprehensive to ask "How long does it take for the light bulb to turn *fully* on?" In which case, the original video is _still_ wrong.  To get the answer this and the previous video come to, one should ask, "How long does it take for the bulb to shine with some noticeable brightens/appreciable fraction of its final luminosity?"

Aspiring Electrical Engineer on his third year here. I don't think anyone was refuting the fact that "of course the current on one side creates a field that induces a current on the other side before it reaches trough the loop" but rather the question and the assumptions beforehand were misleading because although you use lumped elements in the circuit you showed, you also used transmission line model without specifically saying they were real wires thus transmission lines. In lumped element models the actual wires/lines are irrelevant as long as they don't have any Reactance which would get modeled by using a lumped capacitor or a lumped inductor. So all of this could have been avoided if you worded the question better, by clarifying that the cables were real cables and that only *some* part of the energy would get transferred as the induced current and that the full power would come after the electric field traveled the entire circuit during the explanation, which was a BIG detail you didn't include on your original video.
I think you did that not-so-clear/open-to-debate first video as a well planned activity bait. You got all the activity and interaction because of that only. ;)

People really need to remember that most engineering-centric views of the world are, at their core, useful simplifications.  Just like how an electrical engineer doesn't need to think about quarks when discussing how semiconductors work (since it is more or less "irrelevant"), an electrical engineer also doesn't need to "fully" consider how energy is actually dissipated to a load, but instead must simply understand and be able to model (with a sufficient degree of accuracy) what is happening.  As a computer engineer, I also like to think of this as an abstraction, similar to how someone writing software really doesn't need to understand "exactly" what the CPU is doing in order to sufficiently write a piece of software (unless you are obviously writing low-level code which interacts with assembly or something).

@Electroboom
It's clever, I admit, but you have mistaken 2 different things for each other.  I accept and admit when you first connect the battery, that an induced current at 1m will indeed be possible, but it will not sustain at the rate you suggest.  Instead, the induced current will drop away LONG before the actual circuit current activates the bulb permanently.  In fact, you could not tell that brief initial induced activation apart from random interference from other sources of sufficient power.  Finally, I notice that your light and battery aren't a meter apart.  I suspect that if they were, the initial induced current would not even be noticeable above background noise, indeed it would just be part of the noise itself.  Do we need to get into details like ideal zero resistance wires or voltage sources powerful enough to overcome a light second of normal wire that might cause larger initial induction spikes (which, again isn't part of the actual circuit, but rather represent unintended background interference)?

Bravo! Finally we bring this back around and have to explain why they need to use ideals. The actual mechanics behind the electrical event is soo thrilling, especially when you know how it really happens.
1) In your initial video, you represented the flow of energy coming from both ends of the battery's terminals to the load. But what happens when one of the battery terminal wires is grounded and one of the load wires is also grounded? Both ends of this circuit would be at zero potential. Energy will still flow and hence does not require both wires. Only one wire is sufficient.   2) Any common wire has resistance. There will be some radial inflow of energy corresponding to the energy lost as heat. Thus it makes sense that some energy directionally points to the wire, as the wire acts as a "sink" of EM energy, transforming it as heat. To bring the point home more powerfully, I would suggest you do a follow up with a superconducting wire. Now, this radial component will be eliminated, as superconductors do not dissipate EM energy as heat - and most of the energy will be flowing from one pole of the battery to the load, tangentially all around the wire,  where most magnetic and electric fields are located, as per Poynting vector. There will be no more radial component of energy being dissipated inside the wire as it is superconducting. Its as it a spatial mechanism of "cogs and gears" was activated in a thin sheath around the wire. The wire is only akin to a 3D road channeling the energy. Hence you were absolutely correct in your initial assertion "ENERGY DOES NOT FLOW IN THE WIRE".

As far as I understand it, it's like this:  For a suitably long cable (say 30 light minutes) the distance is so great that this acts initially as a light bulb in series with 2 capacitors and a DC source and a switch.  When you connect that switch, the capacitor fills, during which the bulb lights. Eventually it fills and acts as a regular circuit.  Basically it's the same as DC across a capacitor, current flows on the opposite side while it fills and as it isn't really a capacitor, it lights and stays lit.
